DOC.HEAD: Accord Reached on Expanded U.S.-Soviet Air Travel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 5 grafs after 16th graf, bgng: A three-sentence xxx to UPDATE with U.S. official saying Soviets are dismantilng disputed radar installation.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit-Bush Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American and Soviet negotiators completed a pre-summit agreement to expand commercial air travel between the two countries while working Monday to expand an accord to cut long-range nuclear missiles. The negotiators also were trying to revive slumping talks on reducing tanks and troops in Europe. A brief press notice at day's end said simply they had met for 2} hours and would continue the discussions on Tuesday. There was no word on the outcome. The weekend talks at the State Department were aimed at providing President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev with a solid basis for declaring a reversal in the U.S.-Soviet weapons competition at their summit meeting that opens in Washington in three days. Four U.S. cities and six Soviet cities will be added to current airliner routes between the two countries under an agreement reached Sunday and to be signed at the summit. U.S. officials said Monday that the agreement could quadruple air travel between the two countries and, for the first time, provide regular cargo service. It will allow six additional U.S. airlines to operate as well as a new Soviet airline to participate in service between the two nations. Only Pan Am and the Soviet airline Aeroflot now fly U.S.-Soviet routes serving New York, Washington, Moscow and Leningrad. Additional U.S. cities to be provided service under the new agreement are Anchorage, Alaska; Chicago, San Francisco and Miami. The new Soviet cities are Kiev, Minsk, Magadan, Khabarovsk, Tbilisi and Riga in Latvia. In addition, the two sides agreed to allow at least 100 annual charter flights over the North Atlantic route and to consider up to 100 charters across the Pacific. U.S. officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the final details involved a compromise on the percentage of rubles paid by Soviet travelers that Moscow will guarantee to convert into U.S. dollars. The United States originally insisted on 15 percent while the Soviets only wanted to guarantee to 6.5 per cent. Negotiators settled on a compromise that 8.75 percent of the space on U.S. airliners flying out of the Soviet Union would be purchased with rubles convertible to dollars. A number of U.S. carriers have expressed interest in competing with Pan Am for the expanded service, including Delta, United, Alaska Air and Northwest. The two countries' arms control negotiating teams met in three sessions Sunday totaling 6{ hours. While the Soviets awaited further instructions from Moscow, the U.S. delegation headed by Under Secretary Reginald Bartholomew met separately Monday. The Soviet delegation, led by Deputy Prime Minister Viktor P. Karpov, an experienced arms control negotiator, initially was sent here to take up a half-dozen unsettled strategic weapons reduction issues. But a U.S. official, declining to be identified, said the talks also were dealing with cuts in U.S. and Soviet troops, tanks, artillery and airplanes in Europe. There was no word from officials on either side on the results. A three-sentence notice to the press Sunday night said the delegations had met from 11 a.m. to 1:30 p.m., resumed at 3:30 p.m. for two hours, and met a third time from 7:30 p.m. until 9:30 p.m. Meanwhile, in another sign of U.S.-Soviet cooperation, U.S. officials said on Monday the Soviets had recently informed the Bush administration that they would begin dismantling the Krasnoyarsk radar facility in eastern Siberia. ``We recently saw signs that this is going on,'' said one of the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Reagan administration, in two reports to Congress, said the installation violated the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty which imposes strict limits on radar. After protesting initially, the Soviets eventually relented and said they would correct the infraction by dismantling the facility. The treaty limits U.S. and Soviet anti-missile defenses on the theory a potential aggressor would hesitate to launch a first strike rather than face devastating retaliation Bush and Gorbachev are due to make a declaration at the summit that U.S. and Soviet long-range missiles, bombers and submarines will be reduced as part of a treaty scheduled for completion by the end of the year. The holiday weekend talks were designed to expand the declaration to cover weapons still in dispute and to determine how to verify compliance with the pact. Among the issues are whether restrictions are to be imposed on Soviet Backfire bomber and whether to bar the Soviets from modernizing their SS-18 intercontinental ballistic missiles. Under the proposed treaty the Soviets would cut their arsenal of the heavy ground-based missiles from 308 to 154. However, Secretary of State James A. Baker III tentatively agreed in talks May 16-19 in Moscow to permit some new flight tests and limited production of replacement missiles under the numerical ceiling. The trip by Baker involved concessions on both sides while settling long-standing disputes over air-launched and sea-launched cruise missiles. Last Friday, Gorbachev warned at a news conference in Moscow that he might review his arms control policies if the United States and its allies insist that a unified Germany belong to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. U.S. officials, demanding anonymity, said Gorbachev gave a similar warning privately to Baker to explain a slowdown in negotiations over another treaty _ to cut U.S. and Soviet troops and tanks in Europe. However, Gorbachev sent the delegation headed by Karpov here in an apparent effort to maintain the momentum of Baker's talks in Moscow. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said Friday he had been told by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze that the Soviets were ``keen on concluding these negotiations soon.'' The Soviets are apprehensive about a stronger Germany, especially since their allies in the Warsaw Pact have been showing signs of easing away from the Soviet orbit.

DOC.HEAD: White Breaks Long Silence On Reason For Controversial Party
DOC.TEXT: Breaking a long silence, former Boston Mayor Kevin White said an aborted 1981 birthday party for his wife was designed to raise funds to supplement his salary. The party was ostensibly organized to honor White's wife, Kathyrn, but White said Sunday during a television interview it ``was an idea artificially hatched to make up for a problem. The problem was I could barely survive on my salary.'' The ex-mayor said the establishment of the party fund was not improper, but when the process appeared to be ``abused'' and ``it was wrong,'' he called it off. White, a Democrat, angrily denied charges of corruption at the time, but they played an important role in his decision not to run for re-election in 1981. He had served 16 years as mayor. The party was investigated by the State's Ethics Commission and the U.S. attorney's office. White was censured, but not fined. White's statements on WHDH-TV's ``Boston Common'' program contradicted the testimony by Carolyn Galvin Connors, Mrs. White's sister, who said the idea for the birthday party came from their mother. Connors eventually received more than $100,000 checks from people she did not invite, The Boston Globe reported Monday. Theodore V. Anzalone, the former mayor's chief fund-raiser, was charged in connection with a money-laundering scheme which prosecutors claim was linked to the party. Anzalone's conviction for currency law violations was later overturned. White said Sunday he was making $40,000 a year as mayor. ``I was living on $40,000 a year for 10 years with no raise,'' he said. He said being ``mayor was my life. So this was an artificial way in which some kind of fund probably could be established.'' White's salary was increased by $25,000 to $65,000 less than four months before the date scheduled for the April 1981 party.

DOC.HEAD: NY Republicans in Disarray on Eve of Today's Convention
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Convention begins after noon EDT. Lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: A schism developed in New York's troubled Republican Party on the eve of today's convention to nominate a challenger to Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo. Only last week did GOP leaders find a candidate in little-known economist Pierre Rinfret. Then on Monday, conservative Republican Herbert London handed the party a new problem by refusing to be Rinfret's running mate. Instead, the New York University professor said he hoped to run for governor as the candidate of the state's tiny but influential Conservative Party. ``I think this is a year for a crusade. This is a year to attack both the Republican and the Democratic parties,'' London said. Normally, Republicans and Conservatives agree on a ticket. A split would make it easier for Cuomo to win his expected re-election bid for a third four-year term. Michael Long, state chairman of the Conservative Party, welcomed London. ``I'm tickled pink,'' he said. ``This is not going to be a campaign, but a crusade for the middle class, the working taxpayer, to retake New York.'' London's decision came one day before the start of the Republicans' three-day convention in this community north of New York City. Cuomo is considered a potential 1992 presidential contender _ if he's not upset in his bid for re-election. Democrats meet next week to nominate him. The governor's advisers have taken delight in the Republicans' problems in finding someone to challenge Cuomo. ``They've made it so clear that they're reaching to the bottom of the barrel,'' said Andrew Cuomo, the governor's son and chief political adviser. ``Why should anyone give them credibility?'' London admitted he has little chance of winning but said his candidacy is ``a way of putting the Republican Party on notice.'' He has maintained that his conservative views, including his anti-abortion stance, are unacceptable to the state GOP leadership. Rinfret is reported to be pro-choice, as is Cuomo. Rinfret has refused interviews. ``Everyone has to do what they have to do,'' Elizabeth DelTorto, a spokeswoman for state GOP Chairman J. Patrick Barrett, said of London's move. Rinfret, 66, heads an economics consulting firm and has never run for office. He was an unpaid adviser to Presidents Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon. London, 51, ran a brief and little-noticed campaign for the GOP nomination for mayor of New York last year. Barrett said a major factor in his support for Rinfret is his willingness to spend his own money on the race _ up to $500,000 by one report _ and his ability to raise money on Wall Street.

DOC.HEAD: A Year After Tiananmen, Chinese Students in US Less Politically Active
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A year after the massacre that left their friends dead and bloodied on Tiananmen Square, the fervor of last June has faded and many Chinese students in the United States have put away their protest signs and reopened their books. Chinese students here still push for democratic reforms, but many are split over what road the movement should take. And some former activists even suggest their counterparts in China pushed the government too far and are partly responsible for the infamous crackdown. Xu Chenggang, 38, a graduate student in economics at Harvard University, watched the televised images of the tanks rolling into the Gates of Heavenly Peace, as the square is called in Chinese. He saw his friends maimed and killed. Like many others, he was roused to action. ``In that time, in my mind, the most important thing was to stop the killings, so I got very active and emotional,'' Xu said. ``For two months, I went to rallies and meetings.'' Then came a change of heart. Xu returned to his studies. ``I realized it was impossible to overthrow the government,'' he said. ``I think I thought it would be better to view this as a long historical movement.'' The 7-week-old democracy movement was crushed the night of June 3-4 when the Chinese government ordered troops to capture Tiananmen Square. Hundreds, perhaps thousands, were killed in the ensuing chaos. Xu admires the courage and persistence of the students in the democracy movement. He thinks, however, their influence is limited, and he lays part of the blame for the deaths at their feet. ``They were too uncompromising, they were not organized and they pushed the government too far,'' Xu said. ``The fault is the government's, but the students should have foreseen what would happen.'' Pei Minxin, 32, a doctoral student in political science at Harvard who remains politically active, said perhaps 80 percent of the 40,000 Chinese students in the United States took part in protests against their government after the Tiananmen massacre. Now, he admits, that number has dropped by at least half. ``They have to be students first _ not activists first,'' Pei said. ``Chinese students work in labs, they teach, and all that takes away time from activism.'' But while the democracy movement has lost steam, it has not stopped. Student dissidents who escaped China after Tiananmen continue their work. Prominent activist Wu'er Kaixi, for instance, has moved from the Boston area to Paris, where he works with a pro-democracy organization, Pei said. Some protest groups begun last spring have become going concerns. With its phone bank, fax machine and computers, the student-run China Information Center in Newton, Mass., served as the main communications link between protesters in this country and in Tiananmen during the uprising. Now the center's staff is busy creating an archive with artifacts and video footage from China's democracy movement, as well as a computer database for student activists in this country. Last fall, the center incorporated. ``People still think demonstrations are the only way to go forward. We don't believe that,'' said Liu Yuan, its president. ``We want to open a debate. We think this is what we can do.'' In Chicago, students produce a half-hour radio show each day with news otherwise censored by the Chinese government. The show is broadcast from stations near China and reaches up to 70 percent of the country, said Li Sanyuan, one's of the show's founders. The broadcast gets its news from U.S. newspapers and from sources inside China. A typical show recently carried a report of a factory strike in the city of Chongqing in south-central China. ``The government wants to tell people all the good things, but they might not be true,'' Li said. ``In certain places, people don't have food anymore. That information could trigger pro-democracy movement.'' A pro-democracy newspaper set up by Chinese journalists and students in Los Angeles has a circulation of 30,000 and is published every 10 days. It is distributed in China and several Western nations. ``We get into China three ways _ fax, mail and smuggling,'' said editor-in-chief Ben Tang. ``We are in at least 20 major cities there.'' Many students, however, continue to be frightened to speak up, both because they want to return home someday and because they fear reprisals against loved ones in China, Pei said. The students' fears were heightened recently by reports from a Chinese bureaucrat who defected to the United States. He said the Communist Party planned to send officials to U.S. college campuses to court sympathetic students and intimidate the Chinese activists. ``They saw what happened in China. They know politics is a risky business,'' Pei said. ``We lost quite a large number of people, especially after the new revelations.'' Pei said students no longer believe change will take China by storm as it has Eastern Europe, so their concerns are less urgent than last spring and their goals have become long-term. Key issues now are economic sanctions against China and whether the country will continue to enjoy favorable trading status with the United States, he said. Here, there is disagreement. Some students said they support strong economic sanctions against China for the crackdown. Xu, however, said sanctions would hurt fledgling entrepreneurs and joint business ventures with the West. ``Joint ventures are really good things,'' Xu said. ``Removing those things would remove the seeds of the revolution.'' Pei said student emotions ``have cooled a little bit since last June. Some people say tough sanctions, others say less. People differ on how the movement should proceed.'' The students do agree that the long march toward democracy in China began in earnest last June 4. ``Before last spring, democracy as a goal was illegitimate,'' Pei said. ``Now it's been branded by blood into the national consciousness.'' The gains made, they also note sadly, came at a high price both for the students who stood in the square that night and those who stood with them from afar. ``I'm one of the so-called extreme counterrevolutionaries,'' said Pei, whose parents, sisters and brother are back home in Shanghai. ``It would be suicidal to go back.''

DOC.HEAD: Precede PHILADELPHIA
Ferry Takes Stranded Passengers to Shore
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with passengers arriving on land by ferry, other details. Picks up 5th graf pvs: `The ship ...'
DOC.TEXT: The party's over for some 1,000 passengers on a luxury liner that ran aground in the Delaware Bay. The cheering passengers arrived on land by ferry Monday night, their luxury cruise nearly two days late and 100 miles short of its destination. ``It wasn't a bad party,'' said a female passenger who was met by friends and family at dockside. The ferry Delaware brought the passengers from the stranded 642-foot Regent Star to shore at 10:17 p.m. The luxury liner was originally scheduled to dock in Philadelphia at 8 a.m. Sunday. The cheering subsided quickly when officials informed the passengers that transferring them to buses would take another two or three hours. Dorothy Klausmeyer and Mary Poniaoski of Baltimore were able to leave quickly because friends and family met them. They said the adventure was a bit frightening at first, but said passengers quickly adjusted, with help from free food and drink. Other passengers were not immediately available to a group of waiting reporters because buses drove onto the ferry and boarded people while on the ship. Buses were standing by to take passengers back to their cars, which were at airports and bus stations in Washington, D.C., Philadelphia and the New York City area. The ship got stuck on the sand bar early Sunday after a small fire knocked out power. It was carrying 1,360 people, about 300 of whom were crew members. Nobody was in danger during the two days atop the sand bar, said Coast Guard spokesman Lt. James Weakley. Ann Burguieres, a spokeswoman for Regency Cruises, said ship officials had described the mood on board as jovial, with free food and drinks being served. ``It's more of an inconvenience factor,'' she said. ``They're always well stocked. There is always plenty of food and drink on a cruise.'' Coast Guard spokesman Dave Oney confirmed, ``The ship had plenty of food and water, and also party conveniences.'' When the lights went out in the disco, passenger Kathleen Hopkins said, ``everybody was singing `Hot, hot hot,''' and later sang Christmas carols and played an improvised version of ``The Newlywed Game.'' ``People started chanting `Drinks, drinks drinks,''' and free mimosas started flowing, Hopkins said. Another passenger, Barbara Sowden of Wilmington, Del., said by phone: ``It just gave us a great opportunity to party hardy a little longer. We don't need a band, we make our own music.'' The Regent Star, sitting a mile off Fortescue, N.J., had been in the final leg of a seven-day cruise from Montego Bay, Jamaica, when it ran aground. The ferry Delaware, which normally runs between Lewes, Del., and Cape May, N.J., was pressed into service during the busy Memorial Day weekend when the Coast Guard determined that pushing the Regent Star off the sand bar would increase the risk of a fuel spill. Oney said the ship's anchor was believed to be under the hull and could puncture the fuel tanks. The ship carried 30,000 gallons of diesel fuel and 240,000 gallons of fuel oil, he said. None had leaked as of Monday evening. The fuel would have to be transferred to higher tanks before another effort could be made to free the ship, Oney said. Tugboats had tried to move the liner Sunday but failed. It was the ship's first trip up the Delaware Bay. The Regent Star usually stays in the Carribbean, Burguieres said, but was brought north for a series of summer cruises between New York and Montreal.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Troops Clash With Armenian Militants; 21 Reported Dead
With PM-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with day of mourning declared; pickup 5th graf pvs, `Armenia was...'
DOC.TEXT: Soviet troops sent to Armenia to quell ethnic unrest killed at least 20 people in gun battles with Armenian nationalists in and around the republic's capital, an Interior Ministry spokesman said today. The violence exploded in Yerevan as additional Interior Ministry troops arrived in the city. A mass rally was scheduled for today by the Armenian National Movement to commemorate Armenia's 1918 declaration of independence, said Satenik Paramadjan, a spokesman for the movement. Armenia was annexed by the Soviet Union in 1920. The Armenian government and the republic's Communist Party declared Tuesday a day of mourning, Radio Yerevan said in a report monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp. in London. Rafael Popyan, a leader of the Armenian National Movement, said there were several clashes in Yerevan and its outskirts late Sunday and this morning. Soviet soldiers ``just came into the city shooting,'' he said. The first clash occurred Sunday when Soviet troops returning from a patrol were fired upon by Armenian militants at Yerevan's main railroad station, said Soviet Interior Ministry spokesman Yuri Makarov. The soldiers returned the gunfire, killing five of the attackers, Makarov said. A sixth militant died later at a hospital. Makarov said 20 Soviet soldiers were wounded in the shootout. The official Tass news agency said one civilian bystander was also hospitalized with bullet wounds. An Armenian National Movement spokesman disputed the official version of the clash, saying the Soviet soldiers had started it by opening fire on a group of Armenians. After the railway station shootout, unrest continued throughout the day in Yerevan as crowds in the thousands roamed the streets, according to a duty officer at the Armenian National Movement headquarters in Yerevan contacted by telephone. The bloodiest clash occurred as a convoy of 15 armored personnel carriers headed toward the city center from a nearby base, Popyan said. He said Soviet troops opened fire on a crowd of people who attempted to block the road the convoy was traveling on with a barricade of parked cars. According to a preliminary report, 14 civilian gunmen were killed and more than 30 injued in the clash at the barricade, Makarov said. A busload of Soviet soldiers also fired on the headquarters of the Armenian National Movement early this morning, killing a person sleeping in a car outside, members of the movement said in a telephone interview. ``No one inside was injured, but an activist who was sleeping in his parked car was shot dead,'' Paramadjan said. There was no immediate confirmation of the death from Soviet authorities. The clashes were the latest outbreak of violence in the tense Caucasus republic, but the incidents marked the first time the clashes spread to a public place in Yerevan. Tass said the railway station shootout began after the soldiers were attacked by about 15 armed men as they were returning from escorting a passenger train to Kafan, 120 miles southeast of Yerevan. The southeastern corner of Armenia near Kafan has become one of the tensest areas in the dispute between Armenians and Azerbaijanis over control of the Nagorno-Karabakh region. Armenia has been locked in a bitter dispute for more than two years with Azerbaijan over control of Nagorno-Karabakh. That region is predominantly ethnic Armenian, but legally belongs to Azerbaijan. Several hundred people have been killed and hundreds of thousands forced to flee their homes in more than two years of ethnic attacks and clashes involving civilians and soldiers. Soviet soldiers are stationed in both republics to quell violence, but militants on both sides see the troops as an occupying force. Sunday's violence came three days after militants fired on soldiers at military checkpoints and on a patrol in Nagorno-Karabakh, killing one serviceman and wounding four. Tass said soldiers killed one attacker and wounded six in the incidents. On Friday, the general commanding the Interior Ministry troops told Tass that he was trying to end the strife in Armenia by political means. But Col. Gen. Yuri Shatalin warned ``the Interior Ministry troops were ready to carry out the responsible task of disarming armed detachments in the republic.''

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Nominated in Third Round for Russian Presidency
DOC.TEXT: Populist Boris N. Yeltsin renewed his bid for the presidency of the Russian republic today and offered to create a coalition government with his conservative opponents. Yeltsin, speaking to the 1,060-member Russian Congress, which will choose the republic's president, invited members of the Communist Party bloc and others to ``work out a deal that would please the majority of Russian deputies.'' Russia, the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics, stretches from the Baltic to the Pacific and includes Moscow and many major cities. Its language predominates in the Soviet Union and it contains much of the Soviet Union's wealth of natural resources. Yeltsin also called on the Congress to reject the central Soviet government's program for a transition to a partial market economy, which was announced last week. ``The Congress must take the citizens of Russia under its defense,'' he said. The plan, which will double food prices, has set off widespread panic buying, and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev went on television Sunday night to try to calm fears. Gorbachev, who opposes Yeltsin's plan to give the republic more autonomy, has urged the Russian congress not to elect Yeltsin. Yeltsin's main rival is Krasnodar regional Communist Party chief Ivan Polozkov. Neither received the required majority of 531 votes in rounds of voting on Friday and Saturday. Polozkov was among the nominees again today, as was Russian Premier Alexander Vlasov, who had dropped out during last week's nominations. Some lawmakers said Yeltsin's coalition offer might give him the votes he needed to win election. Discontent over the central Soviet government's economic program also boosted Yeltsin's chances, said one of his backers, lawmaker Leonid Gurevich of Murmansk. ``I think he has even more support because during the break on Sunday, many deputies had a chance to talk to their voters and saw the greater tension resulting from price rises and empty stores,'' said Gurevich. Some economists have estimated that up to 40 million people could lose their jobs as a result of the reforms, expected to drive many inefficient businesses into bankruptcy. Under the three-step reform plan, to be implemented through 1995, 60 percent of state enterprises would be sold to the public sector, and controls would be lifted on 60 percent of prices. Other prices would remain under state control.

DOC.HEAD: Problem With Shuttle Unit Being Tested; Not Expected To Delay Launch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CLARIFY that problem apparently in equipment related to display unit, not unit itself.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CSP1
DOC.TEXT: A still-unexplained problem has developed with a computerized display unit in space shuttle Columbia, but it is not expected to delay this week's launch, a NASA official said today. Technicians replaced the so-called ``heads-up display,'' which projects data used by the shuttle's commander during landing, on Sunday night, but that did not fix the problem. NASA tried to determine today what was wrong with the display unit's related equipment. ``That's really our only real problem. Everything else is going very smoothly,'' NASA test director Al Sofge said at a morning briefing. Columbia is scheduled to lift off at 12:38 a.m. EDT Wednesday. After the unit was removed, it tested normally and the replacement unit was not working, prompting NASA officials to suspect a related piece of equipment _ the display unit's electronics package, Sofge said. Sofge said officials should know by midday whether the problem indeed lies with that electronics package. If necessary, technicians will replace the device, about the size of a videocassette recorder and located in the middeck. It will take about eight hours to replace the electronics package and another eight hours to test it, Sofge said. That work can be performed while other countdown procedures continue, he said. There is ``a very remote possibility'' the problem could lie with yet another part, the display unit's power control assembly, but even that wouldn't necessarily delay the launch, Sofge said. ``If it turns out that it is the PCA, we still think we can go ahead and change that out and make the launch date,'' he said. The mission already has been delayed two weeks because of repairs to the shuttle's cooling system at the launch pad. Columbia's seven astronauts, meanwhile, say they are eager to get started on a mission to explore high-energy ultraviolet light and X-rays emitted from stars and galaxies. ``Everything's big on this mission,'' Columbia commander Vance Brand said Sunday. ``We have a big crew. We have a lot of days on orbit, nine or 10, and we think a lot of good and important things to do.'' The crew _ the biggest since the 1986 Challenger explosion _ arrived late Sunday morning in five trainer jets from Johnson Space Center in Houston. The countdown began as planned at 1 a.m. Sunday. ``We know we have a great ship, and we're ready to go,'' Brand said. Air Force forecasters were predicting an 80 percent chance of favorable weather at launch time. Columbia will be carrying a $150 million observatory called Astro that will be operated round-the-clock by four crew members who are astronomers. Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes and one X-ray telescope will scan space from Columbia's payload bay as the shuttle orbits 218 miles above Earth. Because of the flight's duration, five sets of fuel storage tanks will be used instead of the customary three to provide power to the orbiting shuttle, Leinbach said. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration loaded the on-board tanks with liquid oxygen and hydrogen this morning. Technicians on Sunday finished restocking the X-ray telescope with argon, needed to keep its heat-sensitive instruments cold. Columbia has six days in which to lift off, after which the flight will be delayed a week so more argon can be added. It will be the first mission since 1985 to use components of Spacelab, a research facility designed for orbiting shuttles. Crewmen will use Spacelab computers in the rear flight deck to operate Astro, anchored in the payload bay. No spacewalks are planned, although astronauts Mike Lounge and Jeffrey Hoffman are prepared to venture outside the cabin if one of the telescopes needs repairs or readjustment. Astro will probe ultraviolet light and X-rays emitted from stars, the Comet Austin and other matter in space. Little is known about those kinds of radiation because the wavelengths cannot penetrate the atmosphere and thus cannot be studied from the ground.

DOC.HEAD: Two Australians Killed In Apparent IRA Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st, 6th grafs to reflect that comments by officials made today; pickup 7th graf pvs, `My deepest...'
DOC.TEXT: Masked gunmen shot and killed two Australian tourists traveling in a British-registered car in what appeared to be a case of mistaken identity by the Irish Republican Army, authorities said today. The attack Sunday apparently was targeted at British military personnel based in nearby West Germany, but the victims had no military connections, said Alan Patterson, a spokesman for the British Army on the Rhine. The two men, the wife of one and girlfriend of the other had just dined at a nearby Italian restaurant when three masked gunmen sped up in their car and attacked with automatic weapons, said Roermond Police Chief J. Kuijpers. One of the slain men was standing outside the tourists' car and the other was sitting inside it with the women, who escaped injury, police said. In Canberra, Australia, the Department of Foreign Affairs identified the men as Nick Spanos of Sydney, and Stephen Melrose of Brisbane, both 24. The women were identified as Melrose's wife, Lyndal, and Spanos' girlfriend, Vicky Coss. ``This has all the hallmarks of an IRA attack,'' Britain's armed forces minister, Archie Hamilton, said in a statement released in London today. ``My deepest sympathy is with the families of those who have been killed in this despicable act upon defenseless people. This is typical of the IRA's total lack of regard for human life.'' National Police spokesman Louis Steens also said the style and location of the assault pointed to IRA gunmen, who have carried out other attacks on British troops in the area, frequented by British soldiers stationed at bases in nearby West Germany, a 10- to 15-minute drive away. ``We've had it confirmed by the Dutch police that the victims were not British service personnel,'' but may have become targets because of their British-registered car, Patterson said from British Army headquarters in Moenchengladbach, West Germany. Australian Embassy spokesman John Monfries said the two couples were just driving through Roermond, ``perhaps on a weekend trip.'' The shooting ccurred in the city's historic market square. Police immediately alerted all crossing points on the relatively open West German and Belgian borders, Steens said. One victim was shot in the street as he prepared to take a picture, while the other was hit in the back seat of the Citroen car, whose rear side window was shattered by bullets. ``I heard the shots as the bullets hit the windows. It all happened very quickly. There was a man with a machine gun standing in the square firing at the car,'' said restaurant owner Paul Reyngoud, who saw the attack. ``I saw two women running away from the car, shouting and screaming for help. One of them was sobbing and shouted that she had been married for only nine months,'' Reyngoud said. In addition to the man firing the shots, ``there were two other men in the car. They were all dressed completely in black, black shirts and black trousers with balaclava helmets,'' he said. Police in the Belgian town of Leopoldsburg, 35 miles from Roermond, later found the gutted wreck of a Mazda sedan used by the attackers. Last year, IRA gunmen shot and killed two dependents of British servicemen stationed in West Germany in attacks aimed at the soldiers themselves. In May 1988, the IRA claimed responsibility for the deaths of three Royal Air Force enlisted men in two coordinated attacks in Roermond and Nieuwbergen, 30 miles to the north. The almost exclusively Catholic Irish Republican Army is fighting to push the British out of Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland, join it with the Republic of Ireland and set up an all-Ireland socialist state.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Warns Iraq Would Use ``Weapons of Destruction'' Against Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Saddam speech, EDITS to trim; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein warned Israel today that Iraq will use ``weapons of total destruction'' against the Jewish state if it attacks Iraq with similar weapons. Saddam spoke at the opening session of an emergency Arab League summit to muster support for what he says is a Western and Israeli campaign against his country. The summit will also seek ways to stem the large-scale emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel. ``We declare that if Israel commits aggression and attacks, then we will hit back strongly,'' Saddam said. ``If Israel uses weapons of total destruction, then we will use weapons of total destruction against it and we will never give up Palestine,'' he said. He did not specify what weapons he was talking about, but the Arabs claim the Israelis have up to 200 nuclear weapons. Iraq has been building an arsenal of long-range missiles capable of hitting Israel. Saddam has said Baghdad has stocks of binary chemical weapons, and in March he threatened to use them against the Jewish state if attacked. Today he accused the United States of financing and encouraging ``Israeli aggression and expansionism.'' ``The United States bears a basic and primary responsibility for the policy ... practiced by the Zionist entity against the Arabs,'' he said, speaking in Baghdad's ornate conference center. King Hussein of Jordan, one of Saddam's closest allies, appealed to Arab leaders to help his Hashemite kingdom revive its wavering economy and buttress its military power. The Arab League meeting comes days before the summit in Washington between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and the Arab leaders were expected to draft a letter to the superpower leaders. Conference sources said Arab foreign ministers appeared in agreement that the letter should urge Gorbachev to block the expected emigration of as many as 750,000 Soviet jews to Israel over the next few years. The Arabs fear many Soviet Jews will settle in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, which the Palestinians proclaimed their homeland in 1988. Jordan, which neighbors the West Bank, is concerned large-scale Jewish settlement in the region will drive Palestinians into Jordan and destabilize the kingdom. The summit was intended to be a show of Arab unity, but divisions and rivalries were apparent. There was disagreement between the hard-liners led by Saddam and the moderates, including Egypt and Saudi Arabia, over how tough a line they should take against the United States. The conference was boycotted by Syrian President Hafez Assad, Saddam's archrival in the Arab world, and by President Elias Hrawi of Lebanon. Syrian troops control two-thirds of Hrawi's war-torn country. Morocco, Algeria and Oman were represented by senior government officials. Assad said he would not attend the summit held in the capital of his Arab rival because it was too hastily convened without a proper agenda addressing the myriad problems facing the Arab world. The opening of the summit was delayed by an abortive last-minute attempt by Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi to persuade Assad to attend the conference in the name of Arab unity. Gadhafi arrived in Baghdad on a flight from Damascus, the Syrian capital, at midday today without Assad or any other Syrian representative, Libyan diplomats reported. Syria and Iraq are ruled by rival wings of the Arab Socialist Baath Party. Assad has stonewalled Arab bids to end his 11-year-old feud with Saddam, a major obstacle to Arab efforts to forge a new unity. Contrary to tradition, the opening statements by the 15 kings, sheiks and presidents attending the conference were not broadcast. A 16-page U.S. State Department memorandum delivered to the 21 Arab League foreign ministers last week touched off an uproar by urging the leaders to avoid ``excessively ardent language,'' focus on direct Arab-Israeli peace talks and avoid denunciations of Soviet Jewish emigration. The memorandum also accused Iraq of violating international conventions banning the use of chemical and biological weapons. In Jerusalem, Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's aide, Avi Pazner quoted Shamir Sunday as saying he hoped the summit would ``not pour fuel on to the fire, but to the contrary will also contribute to improving the atmosphere, maybe by agreeing to negotiations with Israel.''

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Democracy Forces Appear Headed for Victory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with more official and unofficial results, EDITS to trim; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Burma's military government conceded today that the leading opposition party appeared headed for victory in a nationwide election and promised to relinquish power once a new constitution was approved. But observers have said that process could take years, and one government official indicated the military government might restrict the actions of the new Parliament. Officials at the National League for Democracy headquarters said unofficial returns from Sunday's election showed they won 230 of the 485 seats in the National Legislature. The vote was the first multiparty election in 30 years. In an earlier statement, Col. Ye Htut, a spokesman for the military junta, told reporters that unofficial returns showed the League carrying 100 of the 485 constituencies by a two-thirds majority. The latest official tally announced by state radio said the League had won 18 constituencies, while the pro-military National United Party had yet to win any. Two smaller pro-democracy parties each won one constituency. Final results will take up to three weeks to compile. The military rulers called Sunday's elections but banned the League's two top officials from participating. One is under house arrest, the other in jail. The party says hundreds of other members are also imprisoned. Diplomats and other analysts have said the government's main goal in holding the elections is to attract foreign investment to the impoverished country and to obtain foreign aid. Most foreign aid to Burma was suspended to protest the bloody 1988 military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement that left thousands dead. Western diplomats contacted in Rangoon said reaction to the early election results was tempered with caution. ``There is euphoria in the party but it is not so evident in the streets,'' one diplomat said on condition of anonymity. ``Burmese have had too many shocks in the past few years and they are waiting to see what is the final result I think.'' Prior to the voting, critics pointed to arrests, intimidation and detentions of major opposition figures and expressed skepticism about the prospects for a fair election. But there was relatively little violence on Election Day. The Working People's daily said 15 people were hurt in a grenade attack Sunday in Thanbyuzayat, 80 miles southeast of Rangoon. It blamed the attack on ``unscrupulous destructive elements'' attempting to disrupt the elections. Some dissidents from Burma's many ethnic minority groups, fighting the central government, had called off earlier plans to disrupt the polls. Ye Htut said the military rulers would step aside after lawmakers draft and enact a new constitution and a new government is elected under that document's laws. ``The army will abide by the new constitution,'' he told reporters. ``It is totally up to the elected members (of the new legislature). They can move as quickly as they like and take power,'' said another military spokesman, Kyaw Sann. However, Deputy Foreign Minister Ohn Gyaw told reporters the military council may establish temporary ground rules for the Parliament. He declined to elaborate. Victory celebrations by pro-democracy forces were reported in several large cities. Officials of the National League for Democracy expressed hopes for the release of their leaders, barred from participation in the elections. Aung San Suu Kyi, the popular daughter of independence hero Aung San, is under house arrest, and Tin Oo is in jail. ``It is an excellent day for Burma. We are making a new history I hope,'' said Bahan, a executive committee member of the League. ``We had expected a win but not so much of a landslide as this.'' ``We hope with this mandate by the people we can go on to change to a democratic system very easily and peacefully,'' he said. Myint U, another League official, said the party wanted to temporarily adopt the constitution Burma had after its independence from Britain in 1948. From then until a military coup in 1962, Burma had been a democratic, multiparty state. Sunday's election, contested by 93 political groups and 2,297 candidates, was to fill the National Legislature, which is to draft the new constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Gorbachev is `Pretty Darn Strong'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; editing throughout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he will welcome Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ``with open arms'' to this week's summit, but he promised to stand firm on America's principles about how to keep Europe stable and the world at peace. The president reviewed a colorful, ragtag parade of fire engines, school bands and a veterans' brigade through Dock Square in this seaside resort where he has spent nearly every summer of his life. Eight veterans fired a 24-gun salute, and two buglers from Kennebunk High School played ``Taps.'' Bush, basking in the sunshine and surrounded by his wife, children and grandchildren, called it a ``little piece of Americana'' and said he was going home this afternoon to prepare for the summit ``refurbished by this beautiful four days right here in our beloved Kennebunkport.'' Looking to Thursday's opening meeting with Gorbachev, Bush said, ``There's no question that we have a better chance now for a lasting world peace, but there's still some enormous problems out there. And this country must remain strong, we must remain committed to the values that have made us great over the last 200-plus years.'' ``I go to the summit with open arms to welcome the president of the Soviet Union. But we must stand for our principles when we discuss world peace. We must stand on our principles when we discuss the stability in Europe or the future of the countries around the world that yet are not free,'' he said. ``That's exactly what I plan to do.'' Earlier, Bush told reporters he believes Gorbachev is ``pretty darn strong'' despite the widening economic crisis in the Soviet Union. Bush, before teeing off for a final round of golf on his four-day weekend vacation, said, ``He has enormous problems, but it's not our business ... to sort out the other person's economic problems. We've got some of our own.'' Asked about the possibility of Gorbachev's being overthrown, Bush said, ``I don't think that's my business to sort that out. I deal with the Soviet leader that's there in place coming to the United States to discuss these matters.'' ``This man has survived. I've given him, I think, appropriate credit for the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe,'' Bush said. ``My own personal opinion is that he's pretty darn strong there,'' the president added. Gorbachev went on Soviet television Sunday night to appeal to his countrymen for calm in the face of panic buying triggered by Moscow's plans to double the prices of food and other goods. Asked if he was ready for the summit, Bush, leaning against a golf club, smiled and said, ``I've got some more work to do, but I'm been reading my briefing books.'' Bush said he was ``almost through the first one, and I'll get the second one done tonight. And then we'll have two days of intensive consultation to bring us up to date on where we go. But I think I know the issues.'' Bush said he wasn't expecting any surprises form Gorbachev and had none of his own to bring to the table. On a separate matter, the president was asked if he thought sailor Clayton Hartwig was owed an apology by the Navy, which has reopened its investigation into the explosion last year aboard the USS Iowa that killed 47 seamen. The initial Navy report said Hartwig, who was killed in the explosion, probably triggered it intentionally because he was upset over the breakup of a friendship with another sailor. ``If the man is proved innocent of these allegations, clearly there should be a statement to that effect. But I can't judge it,'' said Bush. Bush was flying back to Washington in mid-afternoon with his wife, Barbara, and their weekend house guest, Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner and his wife, Honey. Skinner also was in Bush's early-morning foursome as they got in their last 18 holes at the Cape Arundel Golf Club with local pro Ken Raynor and Bush friend Spike Heminway. Bush teed off last after the three others hit long drives. The president predicted his own swing would be ``like a fine Bordeaux,'' but then topped the ball and hit it only 30 yards. He took a second swing and lofted that ball far down the fairway. Bush and Gorbachev are to sign an agreement Friday to destroy chemical weapons and outline limits on cruise missiles, which have been an obstacle to agreement on a strategic nuclear weapons pact. U.S. and Soviet negotiators met in Washington on Sunday to try to expand the agreement. Bush acknowledged that Gorbachev ``may be mad with me over some things.'' But he called the Soviet leader ``the kind of man you can talk very frankly with. ... I want to narrow the differences.'' Bush said Soviet pressure against the breakaway republic of Lithuania is an issue that is ``troubling that I don't want to sweep under this rug.'' Bush was interviewed Thursday by Soviet television journalist Valentin Zorin. ``If we argue, we'll do that pleasantly. He's a tough guy,'' Bush said. ``Listen, I've been around him enough to know that he drives his point home. Well, I can do the same thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Ten Health Groups Agree on Diet Guidelines
DOC.TEXT: You've heard it all before: To live long, eat right. Sounds simple, but the experts all seemed to have different ideas about what was right. After holding what amounted to a ``food summit'' last year, 10 health agencies _ five private and five public _ have now come up with a list of jointly recommended dietary guidelines. They call it ``The Healthy American Diet,'' with six general diet principles for everyone over the age of 2: _Eat a nutritionally adequate diet consisting of a variety of foods. _Reduce consumption of fat, especially saturated fat and cholesterol. _Achieve and maintain a reasonable body weight. _Increase consumption of complex carbohydrates and fiber. _Reduce intake of sodium. _Consume alcohol in moderation, if at all. Children, adolescents and pregnant women should abstain. The health organizations, ranging from the American Academy of Pediatrics to the U. S. Department of Agriculture, also recommended that some segments of the population, mostly women and the young, take additional measures. To avoid dental cavities, especially for children, the groups recommended fluoride in drinking water and limited between-meal snacks containing sugar. Adolescents and young women should eat more high-calcium foods, such as low-fat dairy products. Children, adolescents and women of childbearing age also should include iron-rich foods, such as red meat, fish and cereals, in their diets in order to avoid anemia. Many of the groups, such as the American Heart Association, already had recommended diets. But the experts' diets often differed slightly from organization to organization. Dr. Alan Chait of the University of Washington in Seattle thought it was possible people didn't know which to follow. Chait, who also is chairman of the heart association's nutrition committee, said a common message on diet recommendations should ``go a long way to reduce confusion among the public.'' The groups' joint report said nutritional deficiencies such as not enough vitamins used to be the nation's top dietary problem. Now it is eating too much food of the wrong kind. Variety and moderation, the groups said, is the key to healthy eating. Other groups that helped develop the guidelines are the American Cancer Society, the American Diabetes Association, the American Dietetic Association, the Centers for Disease Control, the National Cancer Institute, the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute, and the Department of Health and Human Services.

DOC.HEAD: One Killed, Nine Wounded in Marketplace Bomb Blast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with one victim dying of wounds, U.S. State Department comment; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A pipe bomb exploded today in an outdoor market crowded with holiday shoppers, killing an elderly Israeli and wounding nine, police and hospital officials said. Israeli officials linked the blast to the start of the Arab summit. The bomb went off about noon in the Mahane Yehuda market in downtown Jerusalem. Shimon Cohen, 72, who was struck by shrapnel in the liver, died several hours later at Jerusalem's Shaarei Zedek Hospital, said hospital spokeswoman Orna Cohen. She is not related to the victim. Immediately after the explosion, a crowd of about 200 angry shoppers gathered near Mahane Yehuda, and dozens of Israelis tried to attack young Palestinians who were detained by police, shouting ``death to the Arabs'' and ``burn them, burn them.'' In one incident, a crowd of about 25 Israelis surrounded a police van and pounded on the vehicle in an effort to get at one Arab who had been detained. However, in other cases, Israeli stall owners sheltered Arab workers from the wrath of the crowd. ``We will not allow any acts of revenge,'' Police Commissioner Yaakov Turner said on Israel Radio. At the police station near the market, ahowever. Police commander Arieh Bibi said the device that exploded in the Jerusalem market was a pipe bomb. National Police Commissioner Yaakov Turner said it had been placed in a garbage can. Israeli radio reports said the victims ranged in age from 8 to 72. ``I felt like it was a dream. Everything was blurred,'' said Aviel Abuhatzeira, 8, speaking from a hospital bed after being treated for shrapnel wounds to the right thigh. His father was slightly wounded in a leg. Yoram Shaptai, a vendor, said he was weighing grapes for a customer when the bomb exploded in front of his stall. ``Suddenly I heard a bang ... the grapes blew out of my hand in all directions. The woman fell down and I was slammed into the wall,'' he said. Yoav Lemer, a photographer working for The Associated Press, was knocked to the ground and kicked by three vendors as he tried to photograph a group of Arabs being detained. The vendors only allowed Lemer to go to the hospital for treatment after he gave them his film.

DOC.HEAD: Basque Terrorists Blamed for Post Office Blast; No Injuries
DOC.TEXT: A bomb believed planted by Basque separatists exploded in a post office in this northern city early Monday, causing slight damage but no injuries, a police spokesman said. An anonymous caller telephoned a warning to the local travelers' aid office about 10 minutes before the explosion, which came after midnight, said a police official speaking on condition of anonymity. No group immediately claimed responsibility, but the spokesman said police believed the blast was the work of the Basque separatist organization ETA. ETA seeks independence from Spain for the three-province northern Basque region. Since the start of its 22-year-old campaign for independence, ETA has claimed responsibility for killing more than 600 people and for many bombings.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes In Building Next to Spanish Embassy; Two Hurt
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded in an office next to the Spanish Embassy, and the official ANGOP news agency said two children were injured. The explosion late Sunday in an insurance company building shattered windows but did no serious damage. Few people were in the area at the time because of a curfew. Officials said the embassy did not appear to be the target. The rebels of Jonas Savimbi's UNITA _ the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola _ have claimed responsibility for four bomb attacks this year in Luanda and have stepped up sabotage in the area surrounding the capital. Previous bomb attacks have targeted military installations of the Marxist government and the state oil company Sonangol. UNITA, which receives about $50 million annually in U.S. aid, has been trying to force the government to share power since Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975. Talks to end the conflict resumed in April, but fighting continues.

DOC.HEAD: Three Bombs Go Off In Central Athens; No Injuries
DOC.TEXT: Three powerful bombs shook a wealthy residential area of Athens early Monday, causing damage but no injuries, police said. There was no immediate claim of responsibility. The bombs were planted under cars parked near the Athens Hilton hotel, a police officer said, speaking on condition of anonymity. A security official at the Hilton said there was no damage to the hotel. Police said the bombs damaged several other buildings and some cars in the district of Ilissia, and electricity was cut off in some areas. The district is the site of several diplomatic missions, including the U.S. Embassy. On Thursday, three bombs went off in the fashionable Kolonaki district, which borders Ilissia, and one person was slightly injured. No one claimed responsibility.

DOC.HEAD: Legendary Loch Ness Creature a Monster Moneymaker, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: The fabled Loch Ness monster is worth $42 million in annual tourist revenues to Scotland, a published report said Monday. Half a million tourists visit the Highlands lake each year in hopes of seeing the creature, although there is no scientific proof it exists, said The Times of London. It quoted Mackay Consultants of Inverness as saying the monster myth is also good for about 2,500 tourist-industry jobs. ``We were amazed by the results of our research, which certainly puts the monster forward as one of the main attractions of Scotland,'' said a director of the firm, Tony Mackay. He said reports of monster sightings help keep up tourist interest. The latest was last month, when a visitor from Glasgow claimed to have caught a glimpse of the creature, affectionately known as ``Nessie.'' The legend of large creatures living in 750-foot-deep Loch Ness has been around since the sixth century. One theory holds that the monster is actually a dinosaur species called the plesiosaur, known from fossil remains as a large water reptile with a small head, long neck, short tail and four paddle-like limbs. But no such remains have been found at Loch Ness.

DOC.HEAD: Greece, United States Said Close to Agreement on Bases
DOC.TEXT: Greece and the United States on Monday opened a final round of talks expected to lead to a pact permitting the continued operation of U.S. military bases here. Government spokesman Vyron Polydoras said the talks were expected to last until the end of the week. He refused to provide any details about the expected content of the agreement but said it would cover eight years rather than five, as the previous pact did. That accord expired in December 1988. The new agreement will need the approval of the 300-member Greek Parliament, but the conservative government of Premier Constantine Mitsotakis controls enough seats to win the vote. The previous round of talks ended in Washington on Friday. The United States has four bases and 20 smaller facilities around the country.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Train Robbers Executed
DOC.TEXT: Eleven convicted train robbers were reported Monday to have been put to death as China continued an anti-crime campaign that has led to dozens of executions in recent weeks. The official Legal Daily said a court in central China's Henan province exercised ``the iron fist of the law'' in sentencing the 11 to death. It said the executions were immediately carried out after the sentencing Saturday. The usual method of execution in China is a bullet to the back of the head. The newspaper said those executed had carried out robberies on major train routes, including the Beijing-Canton and Beijing-Shanghai lines. Cities around China have been holding rallies to announce death sentences or imprisonment for people caught in the current anti-crime drive. The report said that when the train robbers were sentenced to death, ``the masses clapped and cheered on being avenged.'' A Shanghai court last week sentenced 10 people to die on various murder and robbery charges. In Canton last month, 10 people were executed for selling tainted liquor, and 11 others were put to death for robbery and murder after being paraded before the public. In March, a Shanghai court handed down 15 death sentences at one time to people involved in robbing taxi drivers. China does not release capital punishment figures, but it is estimated that more than 1,000 convicted criminals are executed every year.

DOC.HEAD: Train Crash in Suburban Station Kills One, Injures 200
DOC.TEXT: A train packed with commuters slammed into another train stopped in a station outside Lisbon on Monday, killing one person and injuring more than 200 people, police said. The accident was on the Sintra line, one of Lisbon's two major commuter rail routes. Police said a train bound for Lisbon from the suburb of Cacem struck a standing train in the Cruz de Pedra station at about 8:45 a.m. An 80-year-old woman was killed, police said. Most of the injuries were not classified as serious, but Soares Costa, director at Santa Maria hospital where most of the injured were taken, said two people were in critical condition. ``It was like an earthquake when we hit,'' said Jose Muralhas, a passenger on the moving train. He said at the time of the crash, most people were already standing, getting ready to get off the train. A spokesman for the state CP railroad company, Americo Ramalho, said he could not confirm reports the moving train's brakes failed. The Lusa news agency quoted Soares Lopes, assistant director of CP, as saying the moving train went through an amber warning signal and a red stop light without slowing down.

DOC.HEAD: System Designed to Create Perfect Building Climate
DOC.TEXT: University researchers have developed an air-conditioning system they say is so sensitive it can adjust a building's temperature according to the type of clothes the occupants are wearing. The Adelaide University research team hopes the system will revolutionize building climate controls by ensuring that office air will never be too cold or too warm. The team leader, professor Sam Luxton, also believes the system will stop the spread of respiratory infections because it eliminates the circulation of stale bacteria-ridden air in air conditioning. Three world patents have been taken out on the technology, which is being installed in a shopping mall in central Melbourne and a 50-story building in Perth. Luxton said the new technology could result in energy savings of 15 percent to 40 percent. ``The problem with most air-conditioning systems is that air must be cooled too much to remove moisture,'' Luxton said. ``The result is that you either have people shivering saying it's too cold or else saying it's stuffy and they feel they can't breathe.'' The research team's solution involves varying the size of components in the cooling system and, in doing so, eliminating the need for stale air to be recirculated to keep rooms warm. Recirculated air, which bypasses filtering systems, is thought to be a major carrier of bacteria that cause respiratory infections. Another feature of the new technology is a computer program that allows the system to adjust the temperature according to the season. The way it works is a closely guarded secret, but Luxton said it involved a ``sensing'' system, which calculates the amount of clothes people are wearing. He said many air-conditioning systems are programmed to maintain a constant temperature year-round or are adjusted manually each season. But the set temperature may be too cold or too warm, depending on the type of clothes being worn, he noted. Luxton said the technology took more than 20 years to develop.

DOC.HEAD: Two Arrested For Painting Swastikas on Chief Rabbi's Home
DOC.TEXT: Two-high school students were arrested Monday for painting swastikas on the home of Denmark's chief rabbi, police said. The teen-agers were caught as they were about to paint on the walls of the Copenhagen synagogue, said criminal inspector Joergen Frederiksen. Police found several swastikas daubed on the house of Chief Rabbi Bent Melchior, less than a half-mile from the synagogue. Frederiksen said the two were charged with ``vandalism of political character'' and released. Neither has a criminal record, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Lawmaker Slain Amid Renewed Violence in Karachi
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with 22 killed, Ms. Bhutto traveling to Karachi; pickup 9th graf pvs, `The soldiers...'
DOC.TEXT: Marauding gunmen today killed 22 people, including a member of parliament, in a wave of bloodshed that has gripped Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's home province, authorities said. Sen. Moshin Siddiqui, a leading opposition lawmaker, was shot to death while going to a hospital to visit survivors of sniper attacks Sunday that left at least 40 people dead in the province's capital and 75 wounded, police said. Southern Sindh Province has been hit in recent years by kidnappings, assassinations and sniper attacks that have left more than 2,000 people dead. The 65-year-old legislator's death intensified calls by his Pakistan Moslem League and other opposition parties for the government to declare a state of emergency in Sindh Province, governed by Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party. At least 21 other people were gunned down and 40 wounded today in sniper shootings and clashes between rival ethnic groups and security forces deployed throughout the port city of Karachi, authorities said. Authorities clamped an around-the-clock curfew in three more districts of the city today including the area around Karachi's international airport and deployed army troops to enforce it. Army-supervised curfews were imposed on three other districts on Sunday. Ms. Bhutto flew to Karachi tonight and may also visit Hyderabad, the province's second-largest city, sources said on condition of anonymity. Hyderabad, 150 miles to the north, has been brought to a standstill by ethnic-related violance. The army rolled into the city on Sunday after security forces opened fire on a procession of about 10,000 people who defied a curfew imposed to stop the bloodshed. At least 60 people died and nearly 300 were wounded, authorities said. The soldiers, considered a neutralizing force between rival ethnic groups, were greeted by Hyderabad residents shouting ``Pakistan Live Forever'' from their houses. Authorities said the congested city was calm today for the first time in two weeks. Heavily armed soldiers patrolled the streets, stood guard on rooftops and checked all vehicles to further prevent random shootings, which have plagued the city of 3 million since May 15 and claimed at least 135 lives. Military officials have said they received hundreds of letters in recent months from Sindh residents asking the army to take control of the province and restore law and order. Officials have said the problem must be solved by the civilian government and not the military. Police blame the current violence on a militant faction of the Mohajir Qami Movement, a small political party representing descendants of Moslem Indians who immigrated to Pakistan during the 1947 partition of the subcontinent. The Movement is demanding recognition as Pakistan's fifth nationality, along with the Pathans, Punjabis, Baluch and Sindhis. Critics say the violence has escalated beyond the local government's control. Opposition politicians in Parliament have repeatedly called for the dismissal of the provincial government and declaration of a state of emergency, a move that Ms. Bhutto's government has resisted. But after today's shootings, members of Ms. Bhuttto's party said the government shared the blame for the continuing lawlessness. ``Organized gangs have become the order of the day. No road in the province is safe and safety of life cannot be assured,'' said Makhdoom Khaleeq-uz-Zaman, a member of the National Assembly, the law-making lower house of Parliament. Ms. Bhutto has acknowedged the provincial government has not done enough to halt the iolence. But she accused neighboring India of stirring up much of the trouble in Sindh and in the eastern province of Punjab. New Delhi denies the allegations and blames Pakistan for violent secessionists movements in the Indian Punjab and Jammu-Kashmir, its only Moslem majority state.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to include Bjt tag
Iran-Contra Figures Do Battle
DOC.TEXT: Message to Washington hostesses: Don't invite Caspar Weinberger and Robert McFarlane to the same party. The two prominent personalities of the Iran-Contra period have been engaged in unusually strident personal attacks on each other for their respective roles during the Reagan administration. ``McFarlane is a man of evident limitations,'' Weinberger writes. ``He could not hide them, but he attempted to do so by means of an enigmatic manner, featuring heavily measured, pretentious and usually near impenetrable prose.'' McFarlane, in turn, derides Weinberger's newly published memoirs as an ``astonishing, anti-intellectual, ad hominem tract; a mean-spirited assemblage of distortions and falsities, of which I am the chief though not the only target.'' At issue are the recollections of both officials of the 1985-86 period when Weinberger was secretary of defense and McFarlane was national security adviser and later a diplomatic trouble shooter on Iran for President Reagan. Weinberger has written a book, ``Fighting for Peace,'' on his years at the Pentagon. A chapter of the book was excerpted by National Review magazine, which also published McFarlane's response. Weinberger portrays McFarlane as obsessed with McFarlane's plan to try to improve relations with Iran. McFarlane was able to use his easy access to Reagan to distort reality and to override the objections of Weinberger and Secretary of State George P. Shultz to the Iran initiative, Weinberger says. ``To the best of my knowledge, McFarlane kept these matters as secret as possible, talking only about the advantages of a new working relationship with Iran _ when, that is, he discussed these initiatives at all,'' Weinberger wrote. McFarlane plunged ahead even though there was nothing to indicate a significant change in Iran's attitude on the American hostages in Lebanon or any shift in Iran's ``virulently anti-Western, anti-American attitude,'' the former Pentagon chief says. Weinberger implies that McFarlane in September 1985 approved the Israeli transfer of American arms to Iran without Reagan's approval. McFarlane responds by saying the independent commission headed by former Sen. John Tower and the Joint Congressional Committee both concluded that Reagan did approve the transfer. McFarlane dismisses as an ``outright lie'' Weinberger's assertion that McFarlane passed intelligence on Iraqi positions to Iran during the Gulf war. He accuses Weinberger of a ``tilt'' toward Iraq, ridiculing the former defense secretary's suggestion that Iraq had ``rational, limited aims.'' McFarlane accepts responsibility for the error of the Iran initiative but says Weinberger was too passive in his opposition. ``There is no doubt ... that if Mr. Weinberger had expressed the depth of his apparent conviction by an offer to resign or by resigning, the operation would have come to a halt,'' he wrote. He also blames Weinberger for the inability of the Reagan administration to develop a coherent politico-military strategy. That, he says, was a ``direct consequence of Secretary Weinberger's personal animus toward Secretaries of State Alexander Haig and George Shultz and his ambition to succeed them.'' In a brief rebuttal to McFarlane's response, Weinberger says he finds ``absurd and breathtakingly wrong'' McFarlane's assertion that Weinberger was a ``party to our getting into this (Iran) quagmire.'' The quotes that Weinberger says McFarlane manufactured cannot change what really happened, Weinberger says. ``No diversionary dust in the form of easily refutable charges about the record of others can change the history I set forth in `Fighting for Peace,''' he writes.

DOC.HEAD: Democracy Party Vows to Return Power to the People
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with pro-democracy party claiming victory in 241 districts. Pickup 5th pvs, `Results of...;' One name cq for Bahan.
DOC.TEXT: Burma's main pro-democracy party said Monday it was assured of an absolute majority following national elections, and the military regime pledged to return power to the people after 30 years of authoritarian rule. Officials of the National League for Democracy said the party had won 241 of the 485 National Legislature seats contested Sunday. They said an absolute majority was certain when final, official results were compiled in about three weeks. The vote was Burma's first free election in three decades. Results of 20 district races were announced on state radio, and the League for Democracy had won 18 of them. In most districts, the pro-democracy party won about 75 percent of the votes, while the pro-military National Unity Party managed only 10 percent to 15 percent, the radio said. The ruling military junta conceded that the League for Democracy had scored a major victory in both urban and rural areas, and it promised to relinquish power as soon as a new constitution is approved. ``Any government that is formed according to the constitution will be strong and stable. It is totally up to the elected members (of the new legislature). They can move as quickly as they like and take power,'' said spokesman Kyaw Sann. But officials of the regime said they believed the drafting of the document would take time. They refused to speculate on how long it could take. Several hundred people gathered in front of the ramshackle headquarters of the League for Democracy, which was festooned with strings of lights and red posters. ``It is an excellent day for Burma. We are making a new history, I hope,'' said Bahan, an executive committee member of the National League contacted in Rangoon. ``We hope with this mandate by the people we can go on to change to a democratic system very easily and peacefully.'' ``We came to pray for an NLD victory,'' said one young woman visiting the Shwedagon Pagoda, an ancient edifice with soaring golden spires overlooking the city. Sunday's election was contested by 93 political groups and 2,297 candidates. It was to seat a 492-seat National Legislature, which will draft a constitution. Balloting was carried out in 485 constituencies and postponed for security and other reasons in seven. Burma's rulers called the election after suppressing a pro-democracy uprising in 1988 in which thousands of people were killed. Western diplomats contacted in Rangoon said some people's reactions to the results were tempered with caution, given the military's past record. ``There is euphoria in the party, but it is not so evident in the streets. There is a certain buoyancy perhaps, but people aren't exactly drinking themselves blind drunk in the streets or anything like that yet,'' said one diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Burmese have had too many shocks in the past few years and they are waiting to see what is the final result, I think,'' he said. The league's gains came despite the house arrest of Aung San Suu Kyi, who helped form the party during the dramatic events of 1988, and the imprisonment of party co-leader Tin Oo. ``One gets the impression that although she was not able to contest this election, her influence, her aura, her persona have in fact been a very dominant factor,'' Australian Ambassador Geoff Allen said of Ms. Suu Kyi. ``First of all we are going to release all the political prisoners including Aung San Suu Kyi and Tin Oo,'' Myint U, a league official, said when asked what the party would do if it scored a commanding victory. Before the election, some critics charged the vote would not be free and fair. They noted widespread arrests, intimidation and the detentions of major opposition figures. There was no official turnout given, but some unofficial estimates in Rangoon said the turnout in the capital was more than 60 percent. Some observers are skeptical the military will easily hand over control after more than a quarter-century of almost total power. The Australian ambassador said in an interview that the polling had ``gone off much better than most people had anticipated,'' but that the election as a whole had been ``flawed'' by the detentions and other past events. ``What has been very encouraging is the way the Burmese people have come out and shown in a dramatic way that they are not really happy with the status quo ... and are basically looking for a very different future,'' he said. ``In that way it has been a most dramatic outcome.''

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Renews Bid for Russian Presidency
With AM-Soviet-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin on Monday renewed his bid to become president of Russia, the Soviet Union's largest republic, after failing to muster enough votes in the first two rounds of balloting. In the last round of voting Saturday, Yeltsin fell 28 votes short of the 531 votes he needed in the Russian Congress. On Friday, Yeltsin captured 497 votes. The populist politician told the 1,060-member Congress on Monday he was willing to form a coalition with his opponents. He invited members of the Communist Party bloc and others to ``work out a deal that would please the majority of Russian deputies.'' Yeltsin's opponents in Tuesday's contest will be the republic's current premier, Alexander Vlasov, and Valentin Tsoy, a little-known businessman from the Soviet Far East. Vlasov has the support of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who has urged the deputies not to elect Yeltsin. Russia, the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics, stretches from the Baltic to the Pacific and includes Moscow and many major cities. Its language predominates in the Soviet Union, and the republic has more than half the country's population. Yeltsin called on the deputies to reject the central Soviet government's program for a transition to a partial market economy, which was announced last week. ``The Congress must take the citizens of Russia under its defense,'' he said. The economic plan, which will double food prices, has set off widespread panic buying, and Gorbachev went on television Sunday night to try to calm fears. Discontent over the economic program has boosted Yeltsin's chances, said one of his backers, lawmaker Leonid Gurevich of Murmansk. ``I think he has even more support because during the break on Sunday, many deputies had a chance to talk to their voters and saw the greater tension resulting from price rises and empty stores,'' said Gurevich. Some economists have estimated that up to 40 million people could lose their jobs as a result of the reforms, expected to drive many inefficient businesses into bankruptcy. Under the three-step reform plan, to be implemented through 1995, 60 percent of state enterprises would be sold to the public sector, and controls would be lifted on 60 percent of prices. Other prices would remain under state control.

DOC.HEAD: Northeast Recreation Areas Hit by Budget Cuts
DOC.TEXT: With the summer fun season under way, fewer lifeguards, dirtier restrooms, pricier parking and litter pile-ups threaten to mar outings in the Northeast as state recreational areas feel the bite of budget cuts. Final budget figures are not yet in, but service cutbacks are being considered in several states, including New York, Connecticut and New Jersey. In Massachusetts, even an ersatz Henry David Thoreau was in danger at one point of being laid off.
