Most parks will remain open, but with reduced hours and staffing. ``The grass is going to get a little longer and the restrooms are going to get a little dirtier,'' said Anthony Cantele, a Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection official. Most states in the region have been grappling with budget difficulties in the past couple of years because of an economic slowdown in fields such as real estate and finance. Last year, Connecticut decided to close 13 of its 92 state parks, but public opposition spurred Gov. William O'Neill to overrule the order. Park funds instead were cut by 8 percent. A 10 percent cut was imposed for 1990. The Massachusetts Department of Environmental Management, which oversees state parks and beaches, has been tentatively allocated $29 million for overseeing state recreation facilities this year, down from $33.2 million just two years ago, said spokesman Peter O'Neil. Along the 3.8-mile-long Salisbury state beach, fewer than than 20 lifeguards will oversee waters previously covered by 50 to 55 guards. Could that be dangerous? ``Absolutely,'' O'Neil said, adding that the department was checking with attorneys about the situation's possible liability problems. ``There have been no drownings when lifeguards are on duty since 1980,'' O'Neil said. ``There are 50 to 60 documented saves each summer.'' Massachusetts has 146 forests and parks, seven ocean beaches, 20 swimming pools and seven historical parks. About 80 jobs, vacant through attrition, probably will not be filled, and O'Neil said only about 800 seasonal employees would be hired, down from the usual 1,300. New Jersey, which has an extensive state park system, also faces staff cuts because of a possible $1 million reduction in the department's $23.4 million budget. Greg Marsh, New Jersey director of division of parks and forests, said a proposed $2 increase in parking fees would eliminate the need for layoffs. Some officials warn that reductions in park maintenance may harm the envirnoment. ``What we're really concerned about is illegal dumping,'' O'Neil said. ``In the past, folks would see someone in uniform and keep on going. Now, they might not keep on going.'' Marsh also fears increased litter problems. A small pile of trash at the side of a road attracts a large pile quickly, he said, adding that park rangers will urge campers to carry their own trash from campsites. New York's 150 state parks, which include 65 campgrounds, will be open, but with reduced hours, said parks department spokesman Robert Arnold. Budget woes almost forced Massachusetts to halt a Walden Pond summer program that hires a tour guide to play famed naturalist Henry David Thoreau, O'Neil said. The guide ``IS Henry David Thoreau,'' always speaking in the present tense when he tells visitors about the life of the famous philosopher, O'Neil said. ``We now think he's going to be back.''

DOC.HEAD: National Gallery to Display Rubens Painting
DOC.TEXT: A major early painting by Peter Paul Rubens, ``The Fall of Phaeton,'' will go on permanent display at the National Gallery of Art on Wednesday _ the 350th anniversary of the death of the 17th century Flemish master of the Baroque. The 3-by-4 oil, which depicts a dramatic scene from Greek mythology, was bought by the gallery last year from an undisclosed private collection in London for a sum that director J. Carter Brown described only as in the multimillion-dollar range. The painting was cleaned to restore its original colors to their former brilliance, and joins the eight other works from Rubens' later period in the National Gallery's permanent collection in the West Building. Except for its inclusion in an exhibition in Cologne, West Germany, in 1977, before it was cleaned, ``The Fall of the Phaeton'' had never been displayed publicly. Little is known of its ownership since Rubens painted it in 1605 while studying in Italy. Brown and Arthur Wheelock, the gallery's curator of northern Baroque painting, said the painting is important because of what it tells about Rubens in the early, formative stage of his development as the greatest Baroque artist. ``This was the springboard of his career into full-blown Baroque,'' said Brown, who praised the painting's ``extraordinary command of three-dimensional space'' and a sophisticated composition that conveys ``swing and power and grandeur.'' The painting shows a scene from Ovid's ``Metamorphoses'' in which Apollo's son is thrown from his horse-drawn chariot in the heavens by a blinding thunderbolt hurled by Jupiter. Wheelock said the cleaning revealed pink hues not previously seen in the painting, and an X-ray examination by gallery conservators showed that Rubens had painted over one figure in the lower right-hand corner of the scene. Brown also announced the acquisition of the gallery's first work by the 17th century Dutch painter Aert van der Neer, a nocturnal landscape titled ``Moonlit Landscape with Bridge'' that was painted in 1650. Both the Rubens and Van der Neer paintings were bought with income from the gallery's permanent acquisition fund.

DOC.HEAD: Cruise Liner Runs Aground; 1,360 Stranded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with plans to pull ship of sandbar postponed indefinitely; discussions under way to get passengers transferred off ship. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PX3
DOC.TEXT: The effort to shove a grounded luxury cruise liner off a sand bar in the Delaware Bay was postponed indefinitely today because of fears of a possible fuel leak, a spokesman said. Attention shifted to finding a way to transfer 1,000 stranded passengers and whatever crew members aren't needed from the grounded Regent Star, said Coast Guard spokesman David Oney. ``Arrangements are being made now to offload the people,'' said Oney. Exactly how that would be done hadn't been determined, he said. The Regent Star lost power and ran aground about a mile off of Fortescue, N.J., at 1 a.m. Sunday. An attempt to have tugboats push it off as high tide Sunday afternoon was a failure. A second attempt was scheduled for this afternoon, but Oney said it was called off because of fears that the ship's anchor, underneath its hull, would puncture the hull and fuel tanks inside, causing an oil spill. ``We heard earlier that they had moved the fuel, transferred it to higher tanks,'' Oney said. ``When we found out that they hadn't made the transfer, that left us with the danger of a rupture.'' No one was injured in the grounding, and passengers _ at least at first _ were reported to be taking the mishap as a chance to have another day of shipboard fun. Oney said passengers might be transferred to shore on one of the ferries that regularly operate between nearby Cape May, N.J., and Lewes, Del. Another possibility would be to use Coast Guard vessels, he said. A spokesman for Aspen Shipping, the agent for the Regent Star, referred all questions to the Coast Guard. Richard Wilkie, the captain of the port for the Cape May-Lewes Ferry, refused to take a telephone call. The Memorial Day weekend is one of the busiest for the ferry, on a major route to seashore points. The Regent Star is carrying 1,360 people, but at least 300 of them are believed to be crew members. The 642-foot Regent Star was heading from Montego Bay, Jamaica, to Philadelphia after a seven-day cruise, the Coast Guard reported. A small electrical fire in a switchboard apparently caused a power failure early Sunday morning and the ship drifted into the sandbar, said Petty Officer John Brazell. Passengers who found their vacation extended by a day were in good spirits Sunday. ``The lights went out in the disco, everybody was singing `Hot, hot, hot','' Kathleen Hopkins, a reporter at The Daily Journal of Elizabeth, N.J., who was on board, said by phone. Later, they sang Christmas carols and played an improvised version of ``The Newlywed Game.'' ``People started chanting `Drinks, drinks, drinks,''' and free mimosas were flowing, Ms. Hopkins said. ``Nobody's really scared, everybody is having a good time.'' ``It just gave us a great opportunity to party hardy a little longer,'' Barbara Sowden, from Wilmington, Del., said by phone. ``We don't need a band, we make our own music.'' The Coast Guard directed marine traffic away from the area.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Adviser Says Gorbachev Strong Despite Turmoil
With AM-Summit-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will go into his meetings with President Bush in ``a strong position'' despite political turmoil at home, a Soviet veteran of recent superpower summits said Monday. Nikolai Shishlin, an adviser to the central committee of the Soviet Communist party, spoke at a Soviet Embassy news conference called to discuss cultural and other issues in advance of the summit. Gorbachev is due to arrive on Wednesday and begin talks with Bush on Thursday. In Moscow, the Soviet leader made a hastily scheduled television appearance Sunday night to appeal for calm in the face of a wave of panic buying caused by government plans to triple bread prices on July 1. Bush, speaking to reporters near his home in Kennebunkport, Maine, before returning to Washington after a Memorial Day weekend break, said he believes Gorbachev is ``pretty darn strong'' despite the economic crisis. Shishlin spoke in response to a question about how the summit might be affected by the outcome of elections in the Soviet republic of Russia, in which Boris Yeltsin, a critic of Gorbachev's policies, was a leading candidate. Speaking through a translator, Shishlin said, ``I believe that for all the tumultuous political process that has developed in Soviet society, for all the posturing and emotion that is building up inside the country, for all the painful and critical nature of the moments we are living through, the expansion of perestroika is proceeding.'' ``Regardless of the result of elections in the republic of Russia, the position of Gorbachev at present is a strong position and a position of authority,'' he said. Shishlin was described by the embassy as an expert of world history and a journalist who has been on the faculty of various higher educational institutions in Moscow and taken part in recent Soviet-American summits. He was also described as host of a television program called International Panorama.

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats Ask for More Funds to Investigate S&L Fraud
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is being asked by 170 House Democrats to step into the worsening savings and loan crisis more and request additional funds from Congress to investigate prosecute fraud in the industry. The Democrats, led by Rep. Charles E. Schumer of New York, sent a letter Friday to Bush saying the $50 million appropriated to the Justice Department to investigate and prosecute S&L fraud isn't enough to handle the backlog of thousands of potential criminal cases. An additional $100 million is needed, said the Democrats, including some lawmakers who last week accused the Justice Department of dragging its feet on prosecuting thrift fraud. Sean Young, a White House spokesman, said over the weekend that Bush had not received the letter yet and would have no immediate comment on it. Bush said at a news conference last Thursday the savings and loan crisis ``causes me great concern'' and that policymakers' first priority is protecting depositors against losses. The administration last week dramatically raised its estimates of how much new borrowing the government needs to clean up the savings and loan mess. Instead of the $50 billion forecast a year ago, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said between $90 billion and $130 is now needed. Including interest on the money borrowed, the cost to taxpayers of covering the S&L losses is expected to exceed $325 billion over the next 30 years. Brady unveiled the new estimate the same day that Bush's son, Neil, was testifying before the House Banking Committee on the $1 billion collapse of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association. Neil Bush was a director of the failed Denver thrift. The panel's chairman, Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, said he plans to ask Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to testify before the committee later. Democrats on the House committee, including Schumer, have criticized the Justice Department for earmarking only $50 million to investigate S&L fraud instead of the $75 million that Congress last year authorized for the task as part of the bailout legislation. ``The American people are being asked to foot the bill of a bailout that may well exceed several hundred billion dollars,'' the House Democrats wrote in their letter Friday to Bush. ``They demand in return that the criminals who looted the thrift industry be brought to justice.'' They asked Bush to reevaluate the number of personnel needed to vigorously investigate and prosecute alleged fraud and embezzlement and seek increased appropriations from Congress to meet those needs. ``At this time, we believe that the Department of Justice requires close to $100 million in additional funds to meet these personnel needs,'' their letter said. Justice Department officials have claimed they already are spending nearly that amount. In addition to the $50 million from the bailout legislation, department officials say they are spending a roughly equivalent amount from previously appropriated money on investigating S&L fraud.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Wins Suspension Of Crippling Railroad Strike
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, who won fame leading a shipyard workers' strike a decade ago, persuaded rail workers Monday to suspend a strike that had crippled train service in northern Poland. Service resumed after Walesa made a late-night appeal to the workers, who had threatened a 90-minute nationwide walkout later Monday. The workers agreed to return to their jobs while the government reviews a list of demands, including pay raises. A week of sporadic labor disputes had stalled freight and passenger transport, paralyzed Poland's Baltic ports and posed a threat to the Solidarity-led government. ``On our road to democracy, there are various dangerous curves, and the railway workers' protest was one of them,'' Walesa said. ``We all have to ... draw conclusions from it.'' The agreement calls for government review of the strikers' demands for pay raises and reforms of the rail system. Until now, the government has insisted that giving into the rail workers could set off a series of wage demands that could hurt drastic economic reforms under way. The Transport Ministry said after normal rail traffic is restored, the management of the state-run railway will meet with unions to discuss their grievances. Passenger service was expected to be normal by Tuesday, but freight traffic bottlenecks were expected to take longer to clear up. Walesa said he would meet with the strike committee in two weeks to assess progress. The rail workers' strike committee, in a communique, called on the Solidarity-backed government to reshape its economic reforms so the ``burden of the crisis is spread over the whole society.'' Poles have been reeling under the impact of big price increases combined with a sharp drop in real wages. The economic reform effort is using ``shock treatment'' to jolt Poland's moribund centralized economy into a market system. The program includes cutting the subsidies to state industries _ including the railroad _ that allowed them to charge unrealistically low rates and grant pay raises without regard to profitability. Government spokesman Zbigniew Augustynowicz welcomed the suspension of the rail strike, saying it ``certainly makes the situation easier.'' ``This is a fulfillment of what the government expected,'' he said. ``The government has always said it would not talk under the gun of a strike.'' Walesa went to strike headquarters in the northwest city of Slupsk at midnight Sunday for talks that stretched into the early hours of Monday. Strikers had asked him to return following his first failed attempt to settle the dispute the night before, Walesa aides said. Walesa said the agreement suspending the strike included ``no promises that would be impossible to fulfill later.'' The labor dispute had cast a shadow over national local government elections, which drew only a 42 percent turnout on Sunday. The settlement, even though temporary, relieves a crisis for the government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. Mazowiecki had appealed for an end to the strike, saying the hardships already suffered under the 5-month-old economic program would increase if there were exceptions to the anti-inflation drive. Walesa, who holds no government post but wields tremendous personal influence, became an emissary for the government despite his own differences with Mazowiecki on the pace of reforms. A decade ago, Walesa was an electrician in the Gdansk shipyard, where Solidarity was formed during labor upheaval in which Gorbachev played a leading role. Solidarity was crushed after the Communists imposed martial law in December 1981. It was restored to legal status in April 1989. The government had no direct comment on Walesa's role. It said only through an aide in the press office that ``every initiative leading to the ending of strikes is valuable.'' During Walesa's meetings with workers, he assured them he was not an ``agent of the government'' and would join their fight if negotiations do not work. ``Your demands are right but the form that you are doing it in ... A strike in the present situation is anarchy on the road to the construction of a democracy,'' Walesa told the workers early Sunday. The strikers' demands include pay of up to $79 a month, which is 110 percent of the average national wage. They also pressed for dismissal of the holdover Communist managers they contended were incompetent and hindering reforms. The strikes began May 20 as wildcat sit-ins. The government initially refused to negotiate because the workers were not represented by any legal labor organization. But by mid-week the cause was taken up by the OPZZ labor federation, which was created by the Communists in 1982 when Solidarity was banned. Walesa said the legitimate difficulties of the rail workers were being manipulated by the ``people who led this country to ruin,'' referring to the Communists. More than 40 years of Communist Party rule ended in August when Parliament approved a Solidarity-led coalition government headed by Mazowiecki, a former opposition activist.

DOC.HEAD: Ten U.S. Soldiers Hurt When Anti-Personnel Mine Explodes
DOC.TEXT: A mine exploded during a U.S. Army training exercise Monday, and 10 American soldiers were injured, two seriously, a military spokesman said. Lt. Col. Jim Gleisberg, spokesman for the U.S. Army 7th Corps, said the accident occurred at the rural Wildflecken training area, 55 miles east of Frankfurt. He said in a telephone interview from Stuttgart that the soldiers belonged to the 9th Engineer Battalion and apparently were training with the M-16 anti-personnel mine when it exploded. The two soldiers who were seriously injured were taken to a military hospital in Schweinfurt, 30 miles south of the training area, Gleisberg said. He said he did not have details of any of the soldiers' injuries. The names of the troops were not released pending further investigation. The 9th Engineer Battalion is part of the 7th Corps, which is based in the southern city of Stuttgart. U.S. Army units regularly use the Wildflecken area for training.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Shoppers Testy on First Day of New Passport Rules
LaserPhotos MOSB1,MOS5
DOC.TEXT: Cashiers shouted ``Passports!'' at crowds of testy shoppers on Monday, the first day of new rules that barred non-Muscovites from the capital's besieged stores. Tempers flared over the rules, which were intended to curb a wave of panic-buying that started after the government announced Thursday it was raising prices as part of a transition to a market economy. Shouting matches erupted between cashiers and shoppers who did not know about the rules. Long lines moved slowly as the internal passports were scrutinized for the stamp that proved residency. ``Passports, citizens, passports!'' demanded a cashier at food store No. 44. ``Moscow or Moscow region only!'' She refused to take the money of people who had forgotten their documents, but softened her stance toward an elderly man who said he was a veteran of World War II. At supermarket No. 30 on Gorky Street, about 70 people jammed the front door after the lunch break. Three policemen waved truncheons to clear a narrow path so shoppers could exit once they had their purchases. The police hit no one with their truncheons. ``I quite agree with the passport measures!'' said Valentina Guskova, a 63-year-old pensioner from the Moscow region who was shopping in a bread store on Gorky Street. ``Those people from other regions, they used to flock to Moscow and strip shop shelves bare. Today, I can at least buy something for my grandchildren here.'' Besides the residency requirement, which already has been adopted by other large cities, rationing was introduced on some goods and tightened on others. The residency requirement will be in effect in Moscow for two weeks. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in a speech Sunday night in which he appealed for people not to panic, said ``an anxious mood has arisen in the country in connection with the consideration by the Supreme Soviet (parliament) of the government's report on the transition to a market economy.'' He gave no indication he planned to change his plans to move forward on what his aides are calling ``regulated market economy.'' Gorbachev, in his speech, gave assurances that the needy would be compensated and that those thrown out of work would be retrained for new jobs. Some economists have estimated that up to 40 million people could lose their jobs in the reforms, which are expected to drive many inefficient businesses into bankruptcy. The plan calls for bread prices to triple, to $1.09 a loaf on July 1, and for other food prices to double on average starting Jan 1. Bread makes up about 20 percent of the average Soviet diet, according to Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov. The three-phase reform plan, to carry through 1995, calls for about 60 percent of state enterprises to be sold to the private sector. In the immediate future, 15 percent of prices will be freed, with controls to be lifted toward the end of the period. Many prices would remain under state control, and many industries would stay in state hands, over the opposition of radical reformers. During debate in the Supreme Soviet on Monday, many lawmakers argued that it did not go far enough, especially in increasing the production of consumer goods. The government Tass news agency reported an abundance of goods such as smoked meats, fowl, fish and sausage in Moscow stores Monday. Spot checks also found some exotic goods such as Vietnamese vodka and Nicaraguan rum. Cashier Tatyana Andruykhina, who blushed as she was seen hiding a bottle of the rum under her counter at supermarket No. 30, said the new rules will make her job harder. ``Now I've got to check people's passports in addition to the usual duties,'' said Miss Andruykhina, 19. Tass said the passport checks were not being universally enforced in all stores, despite notices on the doors that such documents were required. V. Kazakov, who described himself as unemployed, told Tass that he could not find the special department set up by the Moscow City Council to protect needy Muscovites. ``I lost my passport three years ago and had no necessity to get a new one,'' Kazakov said. ``And now, should I die of hunger?''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Gorbachev Looks Strong, But U.S. Won't Yield on Trade
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday that Mikhail S. Gorbachev is ``pretty darn strong'' despite economic woes plaguing the Soviet Union. But Bush virtually closed the door on giving Moscow trade benefits during summit talks this week. ``I go to the summit with open arms to welcome the president of the Soviet Union,'' Bush said, winding up four days of vacation to return to Washington for talks beginning Thursday. In this seaside resort where he has spent nearly every summer of his life, Bush was the star attraction at the Memorial Day parade of veterans, school bands and fire trucks through Dock Square. Basking in sunshine and surrounded by his wife, children and grandchildren, Bush called it a ``little piece of Americana.'' Some people in the crowd of several thousand people flinched when a military honor guard unexpectedly fired a loud rifle salute near the president. Bush told the crowd that as he meets with Gorbachev, ``things have changed dramatically. There's no question that we have a better chance now for a lasting world peace. ``But there are still some enormous problems out there,'' he said. ``And this country must remain strong.'' Bush has made an effort in the days before the summit to emphasize that Gorbachev _ despite his problems _ is a powerful world leader who has the authority to make deals with the United States. Administration officials reason that even if Gorbachev is replaced, his successors would be bound by any agreements he signs. Gorbachev went on Soviet television Sunday night to appeal to his countrymen for calm in the face of panic buying triggered by Moscow's plans to double the prices of food and other goods. ``I think we spend too much time trying to figure out how long a leader in any country will be there,'' Bush said, answering reporters' questions at a country club as he teed off for a final round of golf. ``I mean, this man has survived,'' Bush said. ``I've given him ... appropriate credit for the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe, conducting himself in a manner that none of us would have predicted possible two years ago. ``And so I'll deal with him,'' Bush said. ``And my own personal opinion is that he's pretty darn strong there. And I say that after talking to an awful lot of Soviet experts.'' Sharp differences over German unity and Soviet coercion of Lithuania threaten to put a cloud over the summit. A major Soviet goal for the summit had been to win most-favored-nation trade status with the United States, giving Moscow the lowest possible tariffs on its exports to the United States. In fact, improved trade is probably more important than arms deals for Gorbachev, given his economic problems. Bush noted that Moscow has not enacted a law protecting Jewish emigration, which he had demanded as a price for ending trade barriers. ``So I don't think that issue will be an action item (for the summit),'' Bush said. ``I expect it will be talked about because as they move toward a free market economy, trade with the West is vitally important to them. ``And I'd say that certain items are very important to us, as well,'' Bush said, singling out pressure on the Baltic states as an issue ``that concerns me enormously.'' Bush said he did not expect any surprises from Gorbachev and had none up his sleeve. Asked if he was ready for the summit, Bush, leaning against a golf club, smiled and said, ``I've got some more work to do, but I've been reading my briefing books.''

DOC.HEAD: Market Bomb Kills One, Injures Nine, Sparks Israeli Outrage
Laserphotos JRL1,2,3,4
DOC.TEXT: A pipe bomb exploded Monday in a market filled with people shopping for the Jewish holiday of Shavuot, killing an elderly Israeli man. Israelis chanting ``Death to Arabs!'' tried to attack Palestinians held for questioning. The noon explosion injured nine people at the packed Mahane Yehuda market. A top aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir blamed the Palestine Liberation Organization and said the attack was timed to coincide with the Arab summit in Baghdad, Iraq, which opened Monday. ``The PLO is sending a message to the Arab summit in order to dramatize its call for Arab support for the Palestinian uprising and to show that it still has teeth,'' Yossi Ben-Aharon, director general of Shamir's office, told The Associated Press. In Damascus, a Syrian-backed Palestinian group headed by Col. Said Mousa issued a communique claiming one of its fighters planted the bomb. Mousa is an enemy of PLO leader Yasser Arafat and cooperated with Syria in driving him out of Lebanon in 1985. The communique from the Fagah-Uprising faction said the bomb was aimed at Jewish settlers in Jerusalem. Police rounded up 87 Palestinians after the explosion. Just outside the market, about 200 angry shoppers surrounded police vans as officers pushed the Palestinian detainees inside. Dozens of onlookers tried to attack some of the Palestinians, shouting ``Death to the Arabs!'' and ``Burn them, burn them!'' At one point, a crowd of about 25 Israelis beat on a police van carrying an Arab detainee. Some Israeli stall owners sheltered Arab workers from the wrath of the crowd and police stepped up patrols to prevent reprisals against Arabs. Journalists also were attacked by angry Israelis. Photographer Yoav Lemer, who was taking pictures for The Associated Press, was hospitalized after three men knocked him to the ground and kicked him. Two followers of the anti-Arab Kach movement of U.S.-born Rabbi Meir Kahane were arrested in the attack. The pipe bomb was hidden in a bag inside a garbage can. Officials said Shimon Cohen, 72, suffered internal injuries and died in Shaarei Zedek Hospital several hours after the blast. Three other victims were in moderate condition and the rest suffered slight wounds. The death raised to 44 the number of Israelis killed during the 29-month Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. At least 711 Palestinians have been slain by Israeli soldiers or civilians during the revolt. Moshe Abuhatzeira, 41, said he brought his 8-year-old son, Aviel, to the market from the West Bank settlement of Elon Shvut to buy sandals for the boy. They were talking to friends when the bomb went off. ``I heard a big noise behind me. My boy was screaming `Dad, Dad.' I carried him in my arms and put a lot of pressure on his wound so he wouldn't lose too much blood,'' said Abuhatzeira, who was injured slightly in the right knee. The child was hospitalized in moderate condition with shrapnel wounds in the right thigh. Most of the shoppers were stocking up for Shavuot, the Jewish harvest festival that begins Tuesday. In Washington, the State Department called the blast a ``cowardly and barbaric act (that) demonstrates again the importance of engaging in realistic and workable steps toward a viable peace process.'' Faisal Husseini, the most prominent pro-PLO leader in the occupied lands, denounced the bombing. ``I condemn any attack against civilians whoever they might be, and I condemn those behind this attack,'' he told Israel's Itim news agency. Some Israelis said they believed the bombing was a reprisal for the May 20 massacre of seven unarmed Palestinian laborers by an Israeli gunman, who authorities said went berserk. The massacre touched off a wave of Palestinian rioting in which 16 Arabs died. Arafat demanded Friday that U.N. observers be stationed in the occupied lands to safeguard the 1.7 million Palestinians living there. About 30 members of the Kach group staged an anti-Arab demonstration Monday in Rishon Lezion, site of the massacre. At least twice at many Israelis from the Peace Now movement came to heckle the speakers, but police kept the two sides apart.

DOC.HEAD: Teens Sought in Rock-Throwing Spree that Injured 7
DOC.TEXT: Maryland state police searched Monday for three teen-agers who threw large rocks through the windshields of more than 25 cars on a suburban Washington highway, injuring seven people, one critically. Destiny Morris, a 15-year-old girl from Hagerstown, was a passenger in one of the cars struck by the rocks early Sunday morning. She was listed in critical condition Monday at Southern Maryland Medical Center in Clinton. Ellis Morris said Monday that his daughter suffered a fractured skull. ``The doctor feels that she may not make it,'' Morris said. ``It doesn't look good at all.'' Morris said Destiny was coming home from Ocean City with some friends. ``On the way back, they got sidetracked and had to turn around and come back. When they did, they ended up with this _ kids throwing rocks through windshields,'' he said. ``This little girl's not even 16 years old yet,'' Morris told The Washington Post on Sunday. ``She doesn't even know what life is all about, and the doctors are telling me she might not make it because somebody threw a rock ... It just doesn't make sense.'' State Police Sgt. R.A. Jones said fliers were distributed seeking information about the incidents. The suspects are three teen-age boys believed to be between 14 and 18 years old. The incident occurred about 2:30 a.m. Sunday on I-95 in Oxon Hill,, outside the District of Columbia. Witnesses reported that three teen-agers were throwing of rocks weighing between 5 pounds and 15 pounds at approaching cars. State police say the teens face charges of attempted murder, assault and battery and malicious destruction of property. Motorist Robert Brannigan, 27, of Baltimore said he saw a body lying in the road. ``At first, I couldn't see him because it was so dark,'' Brannigan said. ``I thought someone was hurt. ... When he started to get up, he had a boulder over his face and he started running toward the car. I swerved. It was the wildest thing.'' The rock crashed through Brannigan's rear window, but no one was injured. ``It was a real mess,'' Sgt. Vernon Herron said. ``Those cars were moving at 55 mph, and when a big rock hits you at that speed, it's a very, very serious incident. It's not fun and games.''

DOC.HEAD: IRA Says It Mistakenly Killed Two Australian Tourists
DOC.TEXT: The Irish Republican Army said Monday its gunmen shot to death two Australian lawyers on vacation in the Netherlands after they ``tragically mistook'' them for British soldiers. The two 24-year-old victims were ambushed Sunday night after returning to their car following a meal in an Italian restaurant. ``The IRA accepts responsibility for the deaths,'' said an IRA statement released in Dublin on Monday. ``The active service unit involved tragically mistook the men for two British Army personnel. The IRA deeply regrets this tragedy.'' The statement did not explain how the mistake was made. However, Dutch television said police believed the attackers were confused by British license plates on the Australians' car. The victims, Stephen Melrose and Nick Spanos, died in a hail of machine-gun fire. They were Australian citizens but were based in London. Two women with them were unhurt, said police spokesman Louis Steens. They were identified as Melrose's wife, Lyndal, and Spanos' girlfriend, Vicky Coss. The attack took place in the central square of Roermond, a southern town frequented by British soldiers stationed in nearby West Germany. In 1988, three British servicemen died in coordinated IRA attacks in Roermond and in Nieuwbergen, 30 miles to the north. Steens said the Australian couples were on vacation and had arrived in Amsterdam from London on Sunday. They ``just wanted to see a part of Holland'' on their way to France, he said. Witnesses said up to four people were involved in the shooting, Steens said. Steens said the 40-member police team assigned to the case was being assisted by Royal Air Force police and West German police. The almost exclusively Catholic Irish Republican Army is fighting to push the British out of Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland, join it with the Republic of Ireland and set up an all-Ireland socialist state.

DOC.HEAD: Problem with Display Unit Won't Delay Launch, NASA Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sofge is correct.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CSB2
DOC.TEXT: An electronics problem with a computerized display unit in the space shuttle Columbia resulted in extra last-minute work for NASA on Monday, but was not expected to delay this week's launch. ``That's really our only problem. Everything else is going very smoothly,'' said NASA test director Al Sofge. Columbia is scheduled to lift off at 12:38 a.m. EDT Wednesday carrying seven astronauts and a $150 million observatory known as Astro that will be used to study ultraviolet light and X-rays emitted by stars and other objects. Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration noticed Sunday that the so-called ``head-up display,'' which projects an image of data needed by the shuttle's commander during landings, was displaying incorrect information. Technicians replaced the display, but that did not fix the problem. Officials determined Monday that the unit's electronics package was at fault and began the eight-hour job of replacing it. The package is about the size of a videocassette recorder and is located in the shuttle's middeck. The display unit will be tested for eight hours after the new device is installed. ``We can do it in parallel with all the other (countdown) activities without impacting those activities,'' Sofge said. Air Force forecasters were predicting an 80 percent chance of favorable weather at launch time. The nine- to 10-day mission _ the first one in five years to be devoted entirely to scientific research _ already has been delayed two weeks because of repairs to the shuttle's cooling system. Additional delays could mean even more changes to Astro's observing schedule. Because of the delay, fewer observations are planned of Comet Austin, which is receding rapidly from Earth. The comet is believed to be on its first trip through the solar system. ``It's sort of fading quickly. We're hoping we can still get some observations in, but we're not as optimistic,'' said Arthur Davidsen, chief investigator for Astro's Hopkins Ultraviolet Telescope. Jupiter and some stars cannot be studied now because they are too close to the sun, Davidsen said Monday. If Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes or one X-ray telescope point toward the sun, their instruments could be damaged. ``We'll still make use of every second on the shuttle,'' Davidsen said. One target _ a quasar 10 billion light years from Earth _ is in a better position now than it was a month ago, Davidsen said. The quasar will be the faintest object observed by Astro. The four astronomers in the crew will use computers to operate the ultraviolet telescopes round the clock. The X-ray telescope will be controlled by computer commands sent from Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. Astronomers expect Astro to complement the work of the Hubble Space Telescope, deployed last month in a 380-mile-high orbit during the last shuttle flight. The Hubble cannot detect X-rays and cannot see as much detail in ultraviolet images as Astro. NASA program scientist Ed Weiler sees Hubble as a basic toolbox and Astro as extra tools. ``You can do most jobs at home with that basic toolbox. But there are always unique things you want to do which might require a ratchet wrench or a power drill,'' Weiler said Monday. ``(Astro) is the ratchet wrench, the power drill.''

DOC.HEAD: North Korean Turns Over Soldiers' Remains in Emotional Ceremony
LaserPhotos SEL2,3
DOC.TEXT: The bodies of five American servicemen killed nearly 40 years ago in the Korean War were returned to their countrymen Monday in an emotional Memorial Day ceremony marking them heroes. Five brown caskets and five small boxes containing buttons, dog tags, boots and pieces of uniforms were turned over to eight U.S. congressmen by Communist North Korea, the enemy in the war. It was the first return of U.S. Korean War dead from the North since 1954. More than 8,000 Americans from the 1950-53 conflict are still unaccounted for. U.S. Rep. Ben Campbell, D-Colo., peered down at one of the caskets as it was opened ceremoniously to be checked and saw a skeleton beneath a white silk cloth. ``All I could think was that one or two of these unidentified might have been one or two of my friends,'' said Campbell, who served 13 months in Korea in the Air Force. The return of the remains is widely seen as a gesture by North Korea to improve relations with the United States. The two countries do not have diplomatic relations. U.S. military officials said the remains would be flown Tuesday to Hickam Air Base in Hawaii for a hero's welcome and the painstaking process of identification, which could take several months. Pallbearers in suits and ties, wearing white gloves and lapel pins of North Korean leader Kim Il Sung, handed the caskets over to the congressional delegation in the truce village of Panmunjom inside the Demilitarized Zone separating the two Koreas. The caskets were draped with blue flags of the United Nations, the flag under which American forces fought in Korea. An Army chaplain read a prayer saying ``we have come to take them home to family and friends, to a hero's welcome.'' Several old soldiers wept. The transfer came after Rep. G.V. ``Sonny'' Montgomery, D-Miss., chairman of the House Veterans Affairs Committee, signed a document with North Korea confirming he received the remains. ``This is a historic occasion ... recognition for Americans who fought in Korea, recognition that has not come for 40 years,'' Montgomery said. He said the United States hoped more remains would be returned. Americans discounted speculation there might be American prisoners still alive in North Korea, saying both Soviet and North Korean diplomats had assured them it was untrue. ``I feel happiness, sadness, bitterness,'' said Lt. Col. Don Byers, the last active duty servicemen stationed in Korea who fought in the war. ``I want to know where the rest are. Why five? Why not 500?'' The American-led United Nations Command in Seoul says 33,629 U.S. soldiers were killed and 103,284 wounded in the war. More than 2 million Koreans were killed. The Command includes the United States and 15 other nations that fought on South Korea's side after North Korean forces invaded across the 38th parallel dividing the Korean Peninsula on June 25, 1950. The remains of the five returned Monday were unearthed in 1987 and are those of two U.S. Air Force members and three Army members. All five were believed to have been prisoners of war and died in Hwanghae Pukto province south of North Korea's capital of Pyongyang. The U.S. Defense Department tentatively has identified two of the dead as Army 1st Lt. Jack J. Saunders, 27, of Ogden, Utah, and Army Cpl. Arthur Leo Seaton, 20, of Chester, Pa. Rep. Curt Weldon, R-Pa., said Seaton's family lived about a mile and a half from where he grew up and that he had talked with family members before flying to Korea. Standing at the head of one coffin during the ceremonies, he said, ``These are heroes.'' Other members of the congressional delegation were Democratic Reps. James Bilbray of Nevada, Frank McCloskey of Indiana and Bob Traxler of Michigan and Republican Reps. Bob Stump of Arizona and Gerald Solomon of New York.

DOC.HEAD: House Grapples With Subsidies for Millionaire Farmers
DOC.TEXT: The House Agriculture Committee is dealing with growing opposition in Congress to millionaire farmers who receive federal subsidies. Reps. Timothy Penny, D-Minn., and Dan Glickman, D-Kan., proposed last week that the 1990 farm bill be amended in committee to cut off subsidies to farmers who gross more than $2 million a year. The idea rankled members who view subsidies not as a welfare program for needy farmers but as the government's way to ensure a steady supply of food in an industry that, by nature, is cyclical. ``Our intention is to hear what people think about the issue,'' said Glickman, chairman of the subcommittee on wheat, soybeans and feed grains, the mostly highly subsidized crops. The size of government subsidies have been gradually falling since the all-time record of $26 billion in 1986, but efforts to cut the federal deficit have put a tighter squeeze on farm programs. Rep. Jerry Huckaby, D-La., said the Glickman-Penny proposal would be ``the beginning of the end of the farm program.'' Rep. Pat Roberts, R-Kan., another critic of the plan, called Glickman ``a legislative activist who needs to find the woolly bears of the farm bill and expose them on a weekly basis.'' Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., said the proposal challenged the philosophy of the farm program. ``This program is designed to help the family farmer balance supply and demand,'' he said, contending that the Glickman-Penny proposal would make it a welfare program. Several members argued that gross revenues weren't an indication of a farmer's wealth, because production costs often absorb so much of a producer's income. ``The livestock business, for example, is low profit,'' said Rep. Denny Smith, R-Ore. ``Returns are 2 to 4 percent. You have a huge investment for a small turnaround.'' John Campbell, deputy undersecretary of agriculture, said the Bush administration was responsible in part for starting the debate over the subsidies. ``Our preference would be to stay on course,'' he told the committee. But he said that if agriculture spending was not brought down, the administration may support a move such as that suggested by Glickman and Penny. A coalition led by Reps. Richard Armey, R-Texas, and Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., has announced it will fight some subsidy programs when the bill gets to the floor. Armey has said he'll introduce an amendment to cut off payments to any farmer who has annual profits over $100,000. Since the food shortages and farm failures of the Great Depression, the federal government and agriculture have been intertwined through a farm bill that is passed every five years. Supporters of the programs say participation by wealthy farmers assures they will cooperate with the government in areas they may not otherwise be so inclined. For example, subsidy programs often include requirements that certain acreage be set aside for conservation or supply management. Penny said the $2 million figure he and Glickman proposed as a cutoff for federal subsidies was based on limits allowed under the disaster payment legislation passed last year to aid drought victims.

DOC.HEAD: Former New Jersey Gov. Robert B. Meyner Dies At 81
LaserPhoto NY90
DOC.TEXT: Robert B. Meyner, a country lawyer who became New Jersey's first governor elected to successive four-year terms, has died after a long illness. He was 81. Meyner, who gained national attention during his terms in office from 1954 to 1962, had been in declining health since suffering a stroke in 1986. He died in his sleep Sunday at his home in Captiva, Fla., said his wife, Helen. ``He lived a very full, rich life, giving an awful lot to a lot of people,'' Mrs. Meyner said Monday by telephone from Captiva. A Democrat, Meyner campaigned tirelessly to win the state's highest office at a time when Republicans dominated state government. He was the first Democratic governor since 1940. Meyner surprised some by keeping a number of Republicans in his Cabinet, saying he had to find the best people to fit the jobs. A fiscal conservative, Meyner was credited with keeping a balanced state budget, and with ably administering basic state needs such as water supply and land management. He oversaw the completion of the New Jersey Turnpike in the mid-1950s. His success in the state put him in demand for speaking engagements across the country. From 1958 to early 1960, he was considered a possibility for the Democratic nomination for president. He left office because state law prohibits governors from serving three consecutive terms. In 1969, he was nominated for another term, losing to Republican William T. Cahill. Meyner gave credibility to the governor's office and the state Democratic Party, said former Gov. Brendan Byrne, Meyner's secretary from 1956 to 1958. ``He took a boss-controlled Democratic Party and insisted on a public integrity which remains the standard in New Jersey,'' said Byrne, a Democrat who was governor from 1974 to 1982. In addition to his wife, who served in Congress from 1974 to '78, Meyner is survived by a brother and two nephews. Gov. Jim Florio issued a statement Monday praising Meyner as being ``among the first of our governors in recent memory to speak out on New Jersey pride and New Jersey's spirit.'' A memorial service will be held June 15 at St. Philip and St. James Roman Catholic Church in Phillipsburg.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Former Haitian dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier has moved out of the luxury villa on the Cote d'Azur that has been his exile home for four years to more spacious quarters a few miles away, sources said Monday. Duvalier's new residence in Vallauris has tennis courts, a swimming pool and is closer to the Mediterranean than the villa in Mougins, where he had lived since June 1986. It is owned by an Ivory Coast diplomat, said sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. Duvalier reportedly will pay a yearly rent of about $145,000. Duvalier, 38, lives with his wife, Michelle, and their two children, Nicolas, 8, and Anya, 4. They arrived in France on Feb. 7, 1986, after being forced to flee Haiti. The Haitian government has pressed charges against Duvalier, saying he absconded with $120 million of the nation's money. The French government originally said Duvalier could stay one week. But no other country would accept him, and he has remained in France with no clear status.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A longer version moved on the sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: A collapsed lung is expected to keep baseball Hall of Famer Harmon Killebrew hospitalized for at least 10 days, his brother says. Killebrew, 53, underwent surgery Friday at Scottsdale Memorial Hospital in Arizona, said his brother, Bob. ``The problem was a gastric ulcer that ruptured in his stomach,'' Bob Killebrew said. ``The fluid backed up into his chest cavity and collapsed his lung.'' He requested privacy and the release of no information, Bob Killebrew said. He said his brother, who has a home at Payette, Idaho, was in Phoenix on business. Killebrew hit 573 home runs in a 22-year major league career that included years with the Washington Senators, Minnesota Twins and Kansas City Royals.

Cecilia Peck has her mother's strong Gallic nose and dark-haired beauty, and her father's square jaw, but she is her own person, as she demonstrates in her first starring role. The 32-year-old daughter of Gregory and Veronique Peck portrays a young Arab worman in the film ``Torn Apart,'' which takes place in Israel during the country's wars with its neighbors. A childhood friendship with a Jewish boy, played by Adrian Pasdar, blossoms into romance when he returns from America to serve in the Israeli army. ``I had been to Israel once before, to visit the Hebrew University in Jerusalem,'' Ms. Peck said in a recent interview. ``I saw Israel from that perspective, of the Jewish people who settled there and made that country what it is. That was quite an extraordinary experience. ``I went back this time to play an Arab girl, so I saw the other side of the country and the other culture that inhabits that land. I spent time with Arab families, and they talked to me about their lives and their hopes for the future and their marriages and their children.''

American tenor saxophonist David Murray will be awarded the second International Jazzpar Prize, the awarding committee said Monday. ``Murray will receive the prize which is given to an internationally known and fully active jazz artist who is specially deserving of further acclaim,'' said Arnvid Meyer of the Danish Jazz Centre. He is chairman of the award committee, made up of leading jazz experts from Europe and the United States. The prize, which carries a cash award of $30,000 and the Jazzpar bronze sculpture, will be given to Murray in a ceremony next March. Muhal Richard Abrams, a pianist, clarinetist, arranger and composer from Chicago, was awarded the first Jazzpar Prize.

Chester Zardis, a renowned string bass player who has performed with New Orleans jazz giants since the 1920s, was honored with a rousing 90th birthday bash. Zardis celebrated with friends and other musicians while Danny Barker's band entertained at the Sunday night dinner at the Palm Court jazz club in the French Quarter. He had performed Thursday and Saturday at the Palm Court and Friday at Preservation Hall. ``Thank you, Chester, for making so much music in the world,'' said Barker. Zardis learned the bass when he was sent to the New Orleans Waifs Home _ the same school where Louis Armstrong learned to play. Since then he has played with traditional New Orleans jazz bands like King Oliver and George Lewis, as well as working with other musicians such as Count Basie.

DOC.HEAD: Two Gubernatorial Primaries Lead Ballot in Arkansas
DOC.TEXT: A policeman-turned congressman takes on a wealthy former utility executive in Tuesday's Republican gubernatorial primary while Gov. Bill Clinton attempts to avoid a runoff in his bid for the Democratic nomination. U.S. Sen. David Pryor, a Democrat seeking a third term, is unopposed for renomination but faces a write-in candidate in the November general election. Rep. Bill Alexander, a Democrat seeking a 12th term, faces a stiff primary challenge from attorney Mike Gibson in the 1st District. The Republican gubernatorial race pits Rep. Tommy Robinson, a former police chief and sheriff from Jacksonville, against Sheffield Nelson of Little Rock, who led Arkla Inc., a natural gas utility, from 1973 to 1984. Arkansas voters may participate in either primary without making a commitment for the November general election and some traditional Democrats may opt for the GOP primary since Both Robinson and Nelson switched parties last year. Clinton faces five opponents, including Tom McRae, former president of the Winthrop Rockefeller Foundation, named for a former governor. A poll released Friday showed Clinton with 55 percent and McRae 22 percent, with 19 percent undecided and the three other candidates with 3 percent or less. To avoid a runoff, Clinton must get more than 50 percent of the vote. If no Democrat does, the two top finishers will square off June 12. Kentucky also has a primary Tuesday, in which Democratic voters will decide whether state schools Superintendent John Brock and former Louisville Mayor Harvey Sloane gets to challenge incumbent Republican Sen. Mitch McConnell in November. Two of Kentucky's Democratic congressmen also face primary challenges: 10-term incumbent Rep. Romano Mazzoli in Louisville's 3rd District, and Rep. Chris Perkins, seeking to retain the eastern Kentucky seat held by his father, the late Carl Perkins, for three decades. Arkansas state Auditor Julia Hughes Jones estimated voter turnout would top 600,000, the highest for a primary since records were first kept in 1966. The state has nearly 1.2 million registered voters. The main issue in the Republican campaign has been business deals between Arkla Inc. and Arkoma Productions, owned by Nelson's pal Jerry Jones, who grew up with Robinson in North Little Rock. In December 1982, Arkla sold a half-interest in its gas drilling leases on 20,500 acres in Arkansas to Arkoma for $15 million. Arkoma eventually spent an additional $35 million on drilling and other costs. In 1986, Arkla bought back its leases along with the rest of Arkoma for $174.8 million. Robinson, 48, said it was a sleazy deal and severed his long financial ties and friendship with Jones. Nelson, who left the company in 1984, said that if his successors had bought Arkoma in 1985 they could have gotten it for $85 million. Clinton, 43, was the nation's youngest governor when he was first elected in 1978. He lost his bid for re-election in 1980, but was elected again in 1982, 1984 and 1986. Blacks are guaranteed more representation in the Legislature because 31 legislative districts were redrawn, including 10 new majority-black districts in eastern and southern Arkansas. Half of those 10 seats are being sought by only black candidates. That means there will be at least one more black in the Senate, for a total of two, and three more in the House, up from five, when the 1990 elections are over.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Shakes Armenian Towns
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake rumbled across northern Armenia in the same region that was devastated by a December 1988 temblor that killed 25,000 people, the Tass news agency said Monday. Several buildings were damaged in Sunday's temblor but no injuries were reported, the news agency said. Tass said the earthquake, which struck at 10:28 p.m. Moscow time, measured 6.5 on the 12-point Soviet scale. In Boulder, Colo. Russ Needham, a geophysicist with the U.S. Geological Survey said the quake measured less than 5 on the Richter scale. A temblor of 5 on the Richter scale can cause considerable damage. The epicenter of the earthquake was near Spitak, in northern Armenia, a town that was demolished in 1988, Tass said. ``Several villages have been damaged,'' Tass said. The news agency said there was damage to buildings in the towns of Stepanavan and Kirovakan. Tass said the temblor was also felt in the Armenian capital of Yerevan. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs.

DOC.HEAD: New Soviet Film Breaks Glasnost's Last Taboos
DOC.TEXT: A film that equates criminals who rape and murder without mercy or regret with the Communist Party's actions over 72 years is already a sensation before it opens at Moscow movie theaters. The new documentary, ``This is No Way to Live,'' by Stanislav Govorukhin, breaks most of the last taboos left in the glasnost era. Govorukhin rolls the tragedies of Communist rule, the humiliation of Soviet life, and his personal indignation at the fate of his country into an indictment so powerful it would seem authorities would have to ban the film. But the authorities have changed. The Foreign Ministry staged a screening. Moscow City Council deputies have pledged to bring the movie to cinemas. Govorukhin said President Mikhail S. Gorbachev himself proclaimed the film ``wonderful'' after a private viewing. ``For the life of me, I can't understand how Gorbachev could like it,'' he said, sounding distressed. ``This is No Way to Live'' begins with graphic scenes of rape and murder in a style familiar to viewers of Leningrad TV's ``600 Seconds,'' a daily program that frequently shows grisly crime scenes. Then it moves into Part 2: ``Criminals in Power.'' Beginning with the 1918 murder of czar Nicholas II and other members of the royal Romanov family, it presents viewers with one Bolshevik crime against the people after another. It documents the mass slaughter of the ``bourgeoisie'' under Lenin; the artifically created famines; the tens of millions of deaths and imprisonments under Stalin; the destruction of churches and liquidation of the priesthood; the distortion of people's consciousness with ideological propaganda; and the impoverishment of the vast, rich country through idiotic mismanagement. The scenes shift next to the ``disgusting humiliation'' of everyday Soviet life, with its lines, shortages, poverty and moral bankruptcy, and the crooked bodies crated by such conditions and ``70 years of the wrong genetic policy.'' ``The crimes of Hitler's regime cannot begin to measure up to all this in scale and cruelty, especially if you consider that it was done against one's own people,'' Govorukhin says in the film's narration. Against footage of the post-World War II Nuremburg trials of Nazi leaders, he raises the prospect of a similar national trial of Communists. He says the organizers of a crime should bear the brunt of punishment. The Moscow News weekly predicted Thursday that Govorukhin would be accused of ``malice, mockery and painting everything black'' by ``the very people whom he proposes for a national trial.'' Judging by two preliminary screenings and commentaries beginning to appear in the Soviet press, however, it is mainly Govorukhin's unrelieved gloom, not his political views, that upsets audiences. One viewer at the Foreign Ministry showing remarked that ``We all already know we can't live this way. What we need to know is how we should live.'' Govorukhin, a tall, balding man with a deep voice, offered no apologies for his downbeat views at question-and-answer sessions after the screenings. ``Personally, I'm a pessimist,'' he said. ``I have no basis to think everything will get better quickly. There's no one in this whole country except absolute idiots who doesn't think tomorrow will be worse. And when people have no hope, and God has been taken away from them, what can you expect?'' Govorukhin, well-known as a journalist and director of commercial films, said he made ``This is No Way to Live'' mainly as a ``letter to the Supreme Soviet'' legislature. He wants wide distribution for the film, but he was most concerned it be seen and understood by the country's leaders. Soviet lawmakers already have had several screenings, and chances are most will see the film as its fame grows. Two of Moscow's biggest cinemas have also committed themselves to showing it. Members of the Russian Congress saw the film earlier this week, and its influence has already been felt on the floor. A deputy from the Russian town of Saratov quoted Govorukhin from the podium on Wednesday, saying ``If a country is this rich and the people are this poor, that's a crime.'' Another deputy noted the film ``threw in our face the horrible but honest truth. We can understand it differently but we all agree: This is no way to live.'' Govorukhin said legislators told him the documentary made conservative deputies more conservative and radicals more radical, but in all it managed to move the center slightly toward more reformist views. ``If that's so, then it has played its role,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gaviria's Election Win Points to Readiness for Political Change
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Colombians took a stand against drug terrorism when they elected Cesar Gaviria president, but there was another message as well. Gaviria's victory in Sunday's election served as a warning to Colombia's political elite: Start listening to the people, and get ready for changes. During his campaign, Gaviria _ who took up his candidacy when his predecessor was assassinated _ became a symbol of resistance to the drug traffickers. But he also appealed to millions of Colombians who were fed up with the country's political aristocracy. The election results suggest that voters took his populist message to heart. Two political parties _ the Liberal Party and the Conservative Party _ have controlled Colombian politics for more than 100 years. Leaders have traditionally snuffed out attempts to make the parties more responsive to the people. But on Sunday, the Conservatives went down to their wost defeat ever. As for the Liberals, their candidate _ Gaviria _ won. But he comes from a faction that bucked the party's Old Guard. Colombia's 100-year-old constitution allows little political voice outside the two main parties. But Colombians voted by a 9-to-1 margin in favor of an overhaul of the constitution. Commentators said the vote for Gaviria was a vote for change. ``Gaviria has committed himself to carrying out the political and social transformation that Colombians yearn for,'' the Bogota daily newspaper El Espectador said Monday. ``Colombians want to clean out the system and bring democracy close to the people,'' Clara Lopez, a former Bogota city council president, told The Associated Press. Gaviria was closely aligned with Luis Carlos Galan, a federal senator who frequently disagreed with the political chiefs of the Liberal Party. Galan later became the party's presidential candidate, advocating a political reform and a tough stance against the drug traffickers. He was killed by drug-backed assassins in August. Gaviria took Galan's place as the party's candidate, and also kept alive Galan's ideas for shaking up Colombia's antiquated political structures. The election results indicated the shakeup was starting already. Former guerrilla Antonio Navarro, whose M-19 Movement laid down its armss in March to join the political process, received a respectable 12 percent of the vote. It was the best showing of a left-wing presidential candidate in Colombia's history. ``The support his candidacy received clearly shows that immense possibilities of a peace process, and the generous payment of the Colombian people to those who seek peace,'' Gaviria said in his victory speech Sunday night. Twelve percent was considered a good showing for Navarro, but the same figure was seen as a big defeat for the Conservative Party. Some political analysts said the weak showing could be the party's downfall. One former member of the Conservative Party's old guard, Alvaro Gomez, got about 24 percent of the vote. But Gomez ran as an independent because of a feud with the Conservatives. Another sign of readiness for political change was the approval of an assembly to debate changes in Colombia's 104-year-old constitution. Among the proposals are electoral changes guaranteeing that minority parties get representation in congress and cabinet posts. Proponents of reform also seek to overhaul Colombia's justice system, which has fallen prey to corruption and intimidation by drug traffickers. Gaviria has said the assembly must represent a wide spectrum of society. It will include not just the political parties, but labor unions, peasants, educators, university students, lawyers, judges, the military and the Catholic church. ``I hope that this will be an instrument of reconciliation between Colombians,'' Gaviria said.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Tom Wells, the bureau chief for The Associated Press in Colombia, has been based in Bogota since 1978.

DOC.HEAD: American Mormon Missionary Fatally Stabbed in Dublin
DOC.TEXT: An American missionary for the Mormon Church died in a hospital early Monday after being stabbed in the heart while walking home, police said, Gale Stanley Critchfield, 20, of Payson, Utah, was attacked late Sunday night in Clondalkin, outside Dublin, after making a series of house-to-house calls, police said. Critchfield was one of 160 workers with the Mormon Missions in Ireland. Its president, William P. Martin, said his death was ``extremely distressing and tragic.'' Police said they had not determined the motive for the attack.

DOC.HEAD: Sources: Bodies Offered in Prisoner Swap Not Those of Israeli Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Lebanese Shiites offered to trade what they said were the bodies of two Israeli soldiers for Israeli-held Shiite prisoners, but sources said Monday the bodies were actually those of pro-Israeli Lebanese militiamen. The offer of a swap, from the Shiite Moslem militia Amal, was initially published in the Beirut daily al-Anwar on May 12. The move came after Iran and allied groups in Lebanon demanded a gesture from Israel to encourage the freeing of more Western hostages in Lebanon. Two American hostages _ Frank Reed and Robert Polhill _ were freed in April, the first U.S. captives to be released in 3{ years. The liberal Israeli daily Haaretz quoted unnamed sources as saying the bodies in question were actually those of Lebanese members of the South Lebanon Army, a 2,500-member force trained and equipped by Israel to patrol a buffer zone in south Lebanon. The South Lebanon Army holds more than 300 Shiite prisoners at the al-Khiam prison in south Lebanon. Sources who demanded anonymity said Israeli experts had concluded the bodies being offered were not those of any of the Israelis missing in Lebanon. The sources declined to give details, but said South Lebanon Army commander Antoine Lahad expressed no immediate interest in arranging a trade on the basis of Amal's offer. Lahad has said any prisoner exchange must involve missing South Lebanon Army militiamen and Israeli soldiers. Four Israeli soldiers are missing in action since the 1982 Lebanon war and three other servicemen are believed to be held by Shiite groups linked to the pro-Iranian Hezbollah militia. Most of the Western hostages in Lebanon are believed held by factions of Hezbollah, a fundamentalist Shiite Moslem group that gets considerable financial support from Iran. One of the groups demanding the release of Palestinian and Shiite Lebanese prisoners in Israel is the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, which claims to hold two Americans. They are among six Americans missing in Lebanon. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for the Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: South Africa Says Discriminatory Law To Be Scrapped
DOC.TEXT: The government said Monday that within days it will move to scrap the law that allows segregation of public facilities such as swimming pools and libraries. The announcement marks the latest in a series of reforms by the government of President F.W. de Klerk. But in another development that appeared to be part of the government's campaign to get the African National Congress to renounce political violence, the ruling National Party accused Nelson Mandela of holding outdated policies and not providing clear direction to his supporters. The rare public criticism of Mandela on Monday came two days after the ANC leader accused de Klerk and his government of not moving fast enough to dismantle apartheid. In Cape Town, Planning Minister Hernus Kriel said he would introduce legislation this week in Parliament to repeal the Separate Amenities Act, which allows for the segregation of a wide range of public facilities. Anti-apartheid groups have said they would welcome the repeal of the act as one of several steps the government must make to dismantle its policies of racial segregation. Despite the law, restaurants, movie theaters, hotels, parks and public transportation all have been integrated in recent years. But some conservative communities have used the Separate Amenities Act to maintain whites-only swimming pools, libraries and recreation centers. De Klerk, who assumed power in August, said last year that the Separate Amenities Act would be eliminated during Parliament's 1990 session. The act does not cover schools and neighborhoods, which along with politics are the main institutions still segregated by law. The country's 28 million blacks have no voice in national affairs. De Klerk says he wants to end discrimination in South Africa and negotiate a new constitution with black opposition groups. The de Klerk government earlier this month declared public hospitals open to all races, although some aspects of the policy remain unclear and full implementation is expected to take months. De Klerk also has opened beaches to all races, allowed peaceful protests, legalized black opposition groups and released some political prisoners, including Mandela. In addition, the government has opened four small neighborhoods to all races and says it plans to change the law segregating residential areas, possibly by next year. Mandela and the ANC leadership, meanwhile, were criticized by the National Party's official mouthpiece, The Nationalist, for ``ambivalent and hesitant'' leadership. ``Mr. Mandela's utterances ... have only served to underscore this organization's confusing profile on important issues such as the armed struggle (and) political violence,'' The Nationalist said. ``The time has come for leaders like Mr. Mandela and others to give clearer, stronger direction and bolder leadership to their followers to show it is possible for the ANC to rise above predictable, outdated populist rhetoric,'' it added. The government has urged the ANC to renounce its largely dormant and ineffective guerrilla campaign. The ANC says it will continue to support armed resistance until apartheid is ended. On Saturday, Mandela said de Klerk was not moving fast enough to end apartheid. He also said he felt the president ``is not strong enough to end the violence going on.'' Police said Monday they found the bodies of 12 blacks killed in a vicious faction fight that involved some 400 combatants. The battle took place Saturday near Richmond, 45 miles west of the port city of Durban. It was the latest round of black-on-black violence in the southeastern province of Natal. Some 4,000 blacks have been killed in Natal since 1986. Police said the victims were shot, stabbed and bludgeoned to death. An unknown number of people were injured and about 60 huts were burned down, police said. Police said one side attacked the other in apparent revenge for an earlier killing.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Walesa Takes Over While Lech Rests
With AM-Poland-Strike, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: After Lech Walesa returned home exhausted from a second middle-of-the-night meeting with striking rail workers, his normally reclusive wife was ready to do the talking when Polish radio called. ``He didn't say anything,'' Danuta Walesa told the radio interviewer who phoned Monday morning to ask what the Solidarity leader said upon his return home. ``I told him I've had enough of sleepless nights and he said, `Such is the role of a chairman.' Then he went to bed,'' Mrs. Walesa told the radio interviewer. Shortly before midnight, for the second night in a row, Walesa left his Gdansk home for strike headquarters about 80 miles away. He returned home at 3:30 a.m. Monday after persuading rail workers to suspend the work stoppage. ``I wanted him to get some rest. I didn't want to bother him with any questions and so I just read the communique that I saw had been written,'' Mrs. Walesa told state radio. Mrs. Walesa has appeared only infrequently as a public figure during the decade her husband has led Solidarity. In a rare personal comment, she was quoted recently as saying the volatile Walesa is sometimes hard to live with. But Monday, there was no hesitation about his national responsibilities. The strike ``wasn't good and what we needed was an agreement,'' she said. ``And I am happy it was my husband who did it.''

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Falls 13,000 Feet After Chutes Fail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf, `The man ...' to CORRECT victim's first name to Robin, sted Robert.
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian skydiver plummeted 13,000 feet to his death after his main and reserve parachutes became entangled, police said Monday. The man, identified as 42-year-old Robin Sutherland of Montreal, jumped from a small plane with several other skydivers Sunday, police said. After pulling his ripcord, the victim became entangled in the main chute, said state Trooper Timothy Caulfield. He opened his back-up chute, but that became entangled in the main chute, Caulfield said. He landed in a wooded area a quarter-mile south of the landing zone at Gardiner Airport in Ulster County, about 60 miles south of Albany, Caulfield said. Sutherland was pronounced dead at the scene by a doctro from the county medical examiner's office. Police said he died of massive trauma.

DOC.HEAD: Rockets Kill 6 as Traditional Council Opens
DOC.TEXT: A volley of rockets hit the Afghan capital on Monday, killing six people and wounding 20, as a traditional council convened to adopt democratic reforms, state-run radio said. Twenty-two surface-to-surface missiles fired by Moslem guerrillas into neighborhoods in northern and western Kabul caused extensive damage, said Kabul Radio, monitored in Islamabad. The guerrillas, supported by the United States, Saudi Arabia and other Arab states, are trying to oust the Soviet-backed government that seized power in a violent 1978 coup. The guerrillas insist they aim only at military targets, but have admitted their rockets occasionally misfire and hit civilians. Hundreds of rockets have slammed into the capital in recent weeks, killing and wounding scores of people. Diplomats said the attacks appeared to coincide with the convening of the Loya Jirgah, a traditional assembly of 772 people representing different regions and tribal groups in Afghanistan. The council was expected to adopt constitutional reforms that would change the name of the ruling People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan, revise the party charter to remove all references to its Marxist past and initiate steps to end the party's monopoly on power. Diplomats in Kabul and Islamabad have said the changes appear largely cosmetic and cautioned against making parallels between Afghanistan and the countries of East Europe that have undergone dramatic democratic reforms. In his opening address, President Najibullah reiterated his government's proposal for a peaceful settlement of the war that has claimed more than 1.5 million lives and left the country in ruins. Najibullah's plan calls for a six-month cease-fire, an international peace conference and the establishment of a transitional government followed by internationally-supervised elections. The president uses only one name. ``War is not the way to settle the Afghan problem. There is no other way but through negotiation,'' the 44-year-old president said in remarks broadcast Monday night. ``I pledge to utilize my best efforts to bring peace to the country.'' The guerrillas, who are based in Pakistan and control 90 percent of the Afghan countryside, have routinely refused power-sharing arrangements with Najibullah.

DOC.HEAD: Jamaican Prime Minister Hospitalized in Miami with Pneumonia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with aide's comments, additional political background.
DOC.TEXT: Jamaican Prime Minister Michael Manley was flown to Miami early Monday for treatment of pneumonia, the Jamaican government said. Manley, 65, was flown by air ambulance from the Jamaican capital of Kingston at 3 a.m. and was taken to the Miami Heart Institute where a diagnosis of ``atypical pneumonia'' was made, according to a statement from the Jamaica House in Kingston. Last month, it was announced that Manley has cancer. ``He has been undergoing tests and we're waiting now for the results of those tests,'' said Hartley Neita, an aide with Manley in Miami Beach. ``From there on, the doctors will go full blast on treatment.'' He said no one could speculate on how long Manley would be hospitalized. Neita said Manley watched a little of the French Open tennis tournament on television, but spent most of the day resting. ``We're not pressing him at all. The purpose is to rest and recover as soon as possible,'' Neita said. The Jamaica House statement quoted a message by President Bush sent through the U.S. Embassy in Kingston in which the president expressed concern for the prime minister's health. It said Bush offered to send a military aircraft to Kingston but Manley was transported by a private air ambulance. Manley is a socialist who has moderated his positions since losing 1980 elections after eight years as prime minister. He led his People's National Party back back into power in February 1989 after winning 1988 elections. Manley was admitted to University Hospital in Kingston on Sunday where the pneumonia was first diagnosed. The prime minister was to undergo prostate surgery June 5 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York. The cancerous growth was discovered last month during a routine medical examination. At the time, the Jamaican government said his chances for recovery were excellent.

DOC.HEAD: Drought-Stricken LA Gets Heavy Rain; Freeways Flooded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf, `The Santa ...' to ADD another highway blockage, and ADDS one graf at end with amusement park problems.
DOC.TEXT: An unseasonable rainstorm dumped record rain Monday on southern California, which is in the fourth year of a drought, snarling traffic and contributing to two deaths. But the rain came too late to help with the drought. Warm weather will cause it largely to evaporate rather than percolate into the soil. The storm dropped an inch of rain on Los Angeles, the National Weather Service said. The previous high May 28 precipitation was 0.12 of an inch, in 1971.
