The Santa Monica Freeway through downtown Los Angeles was closed for several hours during the night by flooding, and two lanes of the Harbor Freeway was closed during the morning by a mudslide. A California Highway Patrol spokesman said debris and trash had collected in storm drains because so much time had passed since the last storm. Two traffic deaths were blamed on the storm, one in an accident on the Pomona Freeway near Chino, and one on the San Diego Freeway just south of Wilmington. The rain also closed the outdoor Renaissance Pleasure Faire in San Bernardino. A weather service spokesman called it an unusually late winter storm because of its origin in the Gulf of Alaska. Though the rainfall set a record for May 28, it was nowhere near the record for any day in May. That was 2.02 inches, set May 8, 1977. The wet weather almost spoiled the last day of the Memorial Day weekend. Disneyland, Knotts Berry Farm, and Universal Studios reported late starts for the rainy Monday morning, although clearing skies salvaged the rest of the day's business. Universal Studios had fewer than 10 percent of its normal 3,000 visitors for the first tour, said spokesman Sean Armstrong.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Abound In Southeast, Snow In Western Mountains
DOC.TEXT: Wet, stormy weather advanced across the southeastern quarter of the nation Monday, spinning off at least one tornado, and a strong storm in the West blew snow across the mountains. At midday, showers and thunderstorms reached over central and southern Ohio across southwestern Pennsylvania, western Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia, much of Kentucky, much of Tennessee, North Carolina, South Carolina, parts of Georgia, northwestern and southern Florida, southern Mississippi, southern and central Louisiana, and eastern Texas. A tornado touched down in eastern Kentucky, knocking out power to a Rowan County water pumping station and overturning a hangar and destroying an office at a small airport, officials said. No injuries were reported. State Trooper Lon Fields said the tornado overturned several planes at the Morehead-Rowan County Airport, blew debris onto several others and apparently carried off two more. A tornado touched down near Cave Run Lake, Ky., the National Weather Service said. Severe weather watches were posted from northern Florida to southern Virginia and West Virginia. By 7 a.m. the rainfall for May at Louisville, Ky., had reached 10.72 inches, almost a quarter of an inch above the previous record for the whole month of May. And rain continued falling. Rain and showers extended from southern California and Washington state to the Rockies as a strong spring storm moved across southern California with gusty wind. The storm dropped an inch of rain on Los Angeles, the weather service said. The previous record for the date was just 0.12 of an inch, in 1971. Wind gusted to 40 mph during the morning at Show Low, Ariz. Snow fell over the mountains of southern Utah, with rain at lower elevations, and headed into western Colorado. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 1.81 inches at Goldsboro, N.C.; 1.51 inches at Myrtle Beach, S.C.; 1.17 inches at Leesville, La.; and 1.05 inches at McComb, Miss. Parts of California got record rainfall Sunday. Sacramento got 1.56 inches, a record for the date, and downtown San Francisco got 1.47 inches, a record for any date in May. The nation's temperatures at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 43 at Truckee, Calif., to 95 at Beeville, Texas. Monday's low for the Lower 48 was 35 at Hibbing, Minn.

DOC.HEAD: Police Open Fire on Demonstrators, Killing One
DOC.TEXT: Police opened fire Monday on demonstrating students and teachers, killing a 14-year-old student on the doorstep of his home, witnesses said. Hospitals reported at least three people were seriously wounded in the incident, which began when police opened fire with tear gas to disperse some students and teachers demonstrating for better pay and larger student allowances. The protesters responded by pelting police with stones. Witnesses said the slain student, Yakuba Bah, was struck by police gunfire while standing at his front door. There was no immediate comment from officials. It was unclear what prompted the shooting. It was the second such clash between teachers and police in a week. On Thursday, teachers and students rampaged through the city fighting with police. Several teachers were arrested and most teachers have refused to return to work since that incident. The trouble began when police broke up a meeting of teachers who wanted to replace their government-controlled union with an independent body. Government sources said the administration has increased student allowances and was paying overdue student grants. The government also planned to increase teacher allowances, but no details were available. Sierra Leone's government is near bankruptcy and has been forced to reduce spending. On several occasions teachers and other government employees have not been paid on time. The currency, the leone, has been frequently devalued and the elimination of subsidies for food staples and energy has produced soaring inflation. Prices for many staples have doubled or tripled the past two years.

DOC.HEAD: ANC: Nelson Mandela Hospitalized for Physical Checkup
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela has been hospitalized for a physical check-up and a rest before he begins a European tour next week, an ANC spokesman said Monday. ``This is nothing sudden,'' said Ahmed Kathrada, a former prison colleague of Mandela and spokesman for the ANC in South Africa. ``He is there for a routine check-up. We had planned for it.'' Kathrada said Mandela, 71, had been admitted Sunday night to the Parklane Clinic in Johannesburg after addressing a rally in Kimberley. He was expected to be released from the clinic Tuesday morning, Kathrada said. Mandela, who was treated for tuberculosis in 1988, returned last week from a tour of eight African countries. He also made a trip through Africa and to Britain and Sweden shortly after he was freed Feb. 11 from 27 years in prison. ``Now that he has finished a round of rallies, it was time for him to have a check-up before he begins his trip to Europe,'' Kathrada said. ``This is not a new thing. It started when we were in prison, not only him, but some of us, the older ones, were taken for regular checkups at the instruction of the prison authorities.'' He said Mandela has been examined by a doctor since he left prison, but this was his first major check-up in a clinic.

DOC.HEAD: CNN Plans Extensive Shuttle Coverage
With AM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: CNN plans extensive coverage when the space shuttle Columbia lifts off early Wednesday. Cissy Baker, vice president and managing editor of the Cable News Network, said reports will be aired Tuesday at 6 p.m., 8 p.m., 10 p.m. and midnight, followed by launch coverage. NBC plans to carry the liftoff live for five to 10 minutes before returning to regular programming. CBS does not plan to carry it live. ABC news executives could not be reached Monday to discuss that network's coverage. Columbia is scheduled to lift off at 12:38 a.m. EDT Wednesday carrying seven astronauts and a $150 million observatory known as Astro that will be used to study ultraviolet light and X-rays emitted by stars and other objects.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet President Returns to Canada, Site of Introduction to West
With AM-Summit-Bush, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Spelling of Hnatyshyn in 10th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev returns to Canada on Tuesday for a brief visit to the country that introduced him to the Western-style markets he now hopes to install in the Soviet Union. Gorbachev, en route to the United States for his second summit with President Bush, is to meet with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and Canada's governor-general during a 29-hour stopover in Ottawa. The relatively light schedule should give the Soviet leader and his wife, Raisa, a day to adapt to the eight-hour time change before their arrival in Washington late Wednesday. The four hours of scheduled talks with Mulroney will cover a range of issues, from the Soviets' handling of the breakaway republic of Lithuania to differences over the future status of a unified Germany, officials on both sides say. Canada, a member of NATO, wants the new Germany to assume Bonn's seat in the Western alliance. Gorbachev has warned continued German participation in NATO could slow the Soviet military withdrawal from East Europe, particularly in East Germany, the front line of Soviet defenses against a European invasion. Canada has a substantial number of Lithuanians, including some active in their homeland's independence drive. But Mulroney must tread delicately on that issue or risk a lecture from Gorbachev on how to handle the equally sticky problem of separatism by the French-speaking province of Quebec. The Conservative prime minister faces the gravest political crisis of his 6-year tenure as the nation approaches a June 23 deadline for ratification of the Meech Lake accord that would recognize Quebec as a ``distinct society.'' Quebec is the only one of Canada's 10 provinces never to sign the 1982 constitution. It has refused to do so unless the nine English-speaking provinces ratify the Meech Lake agreement affording Quebec special recognition. The refusal of three provinces, Manitoba, New Brunswick and Newfoundland, to approve the accord has rekindled a Quebec separatist movement that threatens to split the Canadian federation. Gorbachev is to arrive in Ottawa at midday Tuesday and go directly to a private lunch with Mulroney at the prime minister's official residence. Later in the afternoon, the president is to meet Governor-General Ray Hnatyshyn, the appointed representative of Queen Elizabeth II. Wednesday is to feature a wreath-laying ceremony at the national War Memorial followed by another meeting with Mulroney. A late-afternoon luncheon at the National Gallery of Art and a brief press conference with Mulroney precede Gorbachev's departure for Washington. The Soviet president first visited Canada in 1983 when, as the youngest member of the Communist Party's ruling Politburo, he toured the country with a parliamentary delegation. Gorbachev, then in charge of the Soviet Union's agriculture program, was introduced to Western production methods and supermarkets brimming with produce. That visit also provided Gorbachev time for extended talks with the Kremlin's ambassador to Canada, Alexander Yakovlev, who had been exiled from the Kremlin leadership for his unorthodox views. After he assumed the leadership of the party in March 1985, Gorbachev brought Yakovlev back and elevated him to the Politburo. Today the former ambassador is widely regarded as the principal architect of Gorbachev's reforms. Yakovlev has helped guide the Soviet Union toward improved relations with the West and advocates a market-oriented economy, which the Soviet leadership is hoping to phase in as a replacement for the ailing system of central planning blamed for the country's protracted economic crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Historic Buildings, Half of Town Sold at Auction
DOC.TEXT: Auctioneer A.L. ``Buck'' Buchanan spent the weekend selling off half of town. And the residents are delighted. ``It couldn't have gone any better, really,'' Buchanan said Sunday of the sale that included about 6{ acres, 100-year-old log cabins and antique farm equipment and furnishings. About 1,800 people turned out Saturday for the auction ordered by the Texas Historical Foundation. The properties sold once belonged to the late Jeanne Blocker, a Houston investor, and her husband, John, a former oilman. Mrs. Blocker had a vision: to create a historic village within New Ulm. She painstakingly acquired nearly every rundown log structure in the area. The couple also bought about half the town's acreage and several old buildings, and brought in buildings and furnishings from as far as 50 miles away. Mrs. Blocker had cleared some land, built a pond and small waterfall and restored a handful of buildings when the oil bust stalled her plans in 1984. She died in 1988, and her husband donated everything except three pieces of land to the Texas Historical Foundation. ``Mrs. Blocker worked very hard on all of this,'' said Buchanan. ``She did an awful lot of research and planning.'' But for this town of about 100, what once promised economic boom had become a financial drain. Most of the Blockers' half of town has been tax exempt: They bought it as a non-profit foundation. Meanwhile, the steep prices the Blockers paid drove up property values, and taxes, for everyone else in town, most of whom are retirees on fixed incomes. The take was still being tallied, but Buchanan said the the well-preserved MacKinsky Dogtrot Log House, built in the late 1700s or early 1800s, fetched the top price _ more than $6,000. Also sold was a creamery, a saloon and a Ford Model T repair shop. Buchanan said some structures will be moved, others reopened or renovated. The historical foundation will use the proceeds toward an unspecified project elsewhere.

DOC.HEAD: Patient Dies After Surgical Sheets Catch Fire in Operating Room
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with further details, fire started during surgery. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Sheets covering a patient caught fire during surgery Monday, filling an operating room with smoke so thick that staff members couldn't extinguish the flames. The patient died. ``The sheets just caught on fire. It's bizarre,'' said Fire Department spokesman Pat Marek. Investigators were seeking the cause of the fire at the sprawling UCLA Medical Center on the campus of the University of California, Los Angeles, Marek said. An autopsy was ordered to determine the cause of death of the patient, 26-year-old Angela Hernandez, who had been undergoing surgery for injuries suffered in an automobile accident, said campus spokeswoman Vicki Beck. It was not immediately known if Ms. Hernandez died because of the fire and smoke, her injuries, or a combination of the two. Eight to 10 medical staff members, including doctors and nurses, were performing the surgery when flames engulfed the surgical cloth over the patient, said Ms. Beck. ``There was a serious attempt by the staff to extinguish the fire,'' she said. But the smoke became so bad that the operating room staff members had to leave the room, and university police arriving at the scene could not get inside the room, said Ms. Beck. About five minutes after the fire broke out, city firefighters arrived, but by then the blaze had mostly burned itself out, said Marek. ``The fire was just kind of smoldering,'' he said. The fire was isolated to the operating table and the hospital had no structural damage. Nobody else was injured, but the smoke forced the closure of all operating rooms for the day so they could be sterilized. It was the second time in 1{ years a patient died in an operating room blaze in a southern California hospital. In October 1988, a 15-day-old boy was fatally burned at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center when a spark from an electric cauterizer, used to stop bleeding, started a fire that was strengthened by a high concentration of oxygen in the room. UCLA Medical Center officials declined to say if doctors had been using a cauterizer Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Legislator, 27 others Slain in Domestic Violence
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen killed a leading opposition member of Parliament and at least 27 others Monday in a new outbreak of ethnic violence in Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's home province, authorities said. Ms. Bhutto flew to this troubled port Monday night for an emergency meeting with the leaders of Sind Province and the army chief of staff, Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg, who cut short a visit to Bangladesh. Ms. Bhutto's weak, 17-month-old government, has come under increasing pressure from opposition parties to dismiss the provincial government of Sind, headed by her Pakistan People's Party, and declare a state of emergency to curb escalating violence. Members of her party also began demanding action Monday after Sen. Moshin Siddiqui was shot and killed on his way to a hospital to visit survivors of sniper attacks Sunday that left 40 people dead and 75 injured, police said. ``Organized gangs have become the order of the day. No road in the province is safe and safety of life cannot be assured,'' said Makhdoom Khaleeq-uz-Zaman, who represents Ms. Bhutto's party in the National Assembly, the lawmaking lower house of Parliament. ``The situation has worsened to the extent that even relatives of federal and provincial ministers are not safe. They are being kidnapped for ransom or they are being killed,'' he said. Besides the 65-year-old legislator from the opposition Pakistan Moslem League, at least 27 others, including three policemen, were gunned down in random attacks and clashes between rival ethnic groups and security forces in Karachi, Pakistan's largest city, police said. Another 72 were wounded. Authorities deployed additional troops and clamped an around-the-clock curfew on five districts Monday, including the area around Karachi's international airport. Military curfews were imposed in three districts on Sunday. In Hyderabad, 150 miles to the north, residents took advantage of two two-hour curfew breaks to quickly buy food and return to their businesses, authorities said. The city of 3 million was calm for the first time in two weeks. Soldiers patrolled the streets, stood guard on rooftops and checked all vehicles in an attempt to prevent shootings that have plagued that city since May 15 and claimed at least 135 lives. The army moved into Hyderabad on Sunday after security forces opened fire on a procession of about 10,000 people who defied a curfew imposed to stop the bloodshed. At least 60 people were killed and nearly 300 wounded, officials said. The soldiers, who are trying to stop clashes between rival ethnic groups, were greeted by residents shouting ``Pakistan Zindabad!'' (Pakistan Lives Forever!) from their houses. Military officials have received hundreds of letters in recent months from residents of Sind asking the army to take control of the province and restore law and order. Military officials, tainted by a decade of army rule, have said the civilian government must find a solution to the bloodshed. Kidnappings, assassinations and sniper atacks in Sind Province have left more than 2,000 people dead in the past few years. Police blame the current wave of violence on a militant faction of the Mohajir Qami Movement, a small political party representing descendants of Moslem Indians who immigrated to Pakistan during the 1947 partition of the subcontinent. The movement is demanding recognition for the Indian immigrants as Pakistan's fifth nationality, along with Pathans, Punjabis, Baluch and Sindis. The movement once backed Ms. Bhutto's government but withdrew its support in November and forced a no-confidence vote she narrowly survived. The Mohajirs, or immigrants, constitute a majority in Karachi and Hyderabad and are considered better educated and more politically conscious.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Warns Iraq Would Use `Weapons of Destruction' Against Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, `He did' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with new Saddam quote, Arafat speech. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Baghdad has...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein, opening a two-day Arab League summit, said Monday that if Israel deployed nuclear or chemical weapons against Arabs, Iraq would respond with ``weapons of mass destruction.'' Also speaking to the 15 kings, sheiks and presidents, Jordan's King Hussein urged Arabs to use their oil wealth to influence world politics. The conference was called as a show of Arab unity against what Saddam has said is a Western and Israeli campaign against Iraq. The summit was also to seek ways to stem the large-scale emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel. ``The potentials of any Arab nation have to be in the service of all Arabs to safeguard national security,'' Saddam said. ``Should Israel strike, we shall strike back firmly. Should it use weapons of mass destruction, we shall use all the weapons of mass destruction that are in our possession.'' ``We'll never give up Palestine,'' he added to loud applause. In a late-night closed session, Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat warned that Israel was seeking to occupy more Arab territory to establish ``greater Israel ... from the Nile to the Euphrates.'' He called for a meeting of the Defense Council of Arab League defense ministers to map out a joint strategy on the issue within a month. ``We are duty-bound to use all weapons, including sanctions _ economic boycotts and political and psychological pressures _ against countries, states, establishments and companies that participate in aggression against Arab territory,'' Arafat said in a speech later distributed to reporters. Saddam did not specify what type of weapons Iraq might use against the Jewish state. Arabs commonly use the phrase ``weapons of mass destruction'' to refer to nuclear weapons and more advanced chemical weapons. Baghdad has been building an arsenal of long-range missiles capable of hitting Israel. Saddam also has said Baghdad has stocks of binary chemical weapons, and in March he threatened to use them against Israel if attacked. Arabs claim the Israelis have 200 nuclear weapons, although Israel denies it. In Jerusalem, Yossi Ben-Aharon, a top aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said Israel was concerned about Saddam's threats. He also said Iraq recently moved troops into Jordan near Israel's border but did not specify how many troops were involved. In his speech, Saddam accused the United States of financing and encouraging ``Israeli aggression and expansionism.'' ``The United States bears a basic and primary responsibility for the policy ... practiced by the Zionist entity against the Arabs,'' he told Arab leaders at Baghdad's ornate conference center. Arabs say the West and Israel have mounted a campaign against Baghdad following the arrests in England of several people accused of trying to smuggle nuclear triggers to Iraq. Several European nations also intercepted alleged parts of an Iraqi ``super gun.'' Saddam has said the developments were designed to justify an impending Israeli attack on Iraqi military or industrial facilities similar to the air raid on the Osirak nuclear reactor near Baghdad in 1981. Hussein said Arab leaders should use oil as a political tool. ``Our region contains 65 percent of the oil reserves in the world, and through the Gulf pass 40 percent of oil shipments....'' These resources ``if properly utilized ... place us among the vigorous powers within the movement of history.'' But the summit, designed to foster unity, convened in the shadow of a sharp split between pro-U.S. governments and hard-liners over a letter to be sent to the superpower summit that begins Wednesday in Washington. The letter was to address the expected emigration of as many as 750,000 Soviet Jews to Israel over the next few years. The Arabs fear many Soviet Jews will settle in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Jordan, which neighbors the West Bank, is concerned that large-scale Jewish settlement in the region will drive Palestinians into Jordan and destabilize the kingdom. And there was disagreement between the hard-liners led by Saddam and the moderates, including Egypt and Saudi Arabia, over how tough a line they should take against the United States. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak suggested the summit ``letter to the outside world be humane and rational, devoid of overstatement and understatement.'' The conference was boycotted by Syrian President Hafez Assad, Saddam's archrival in the Arab world, and by President Elias Hrawi of Lebanon. Syrian troops control two-thirds of Hrawi's war-torn country. The opening was delayed by an abortive last-minute attempt by Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi to persuade Assad to attend the conference in the name of Arab unity.

DOC.HEAD: Man Left Hanging Hours at Amtrak Station With Electrical Burns
DOC.TEXT: A man believed to be scavenging copper wire remained in critical condition Monday from electrical burns he suffered at an Amtrak substation, where he hung upside down for hours as rescuers waited to make sure the power was turned off. It took several calls from the District of Columbia Fire Department before Amtrak employees in Philadelphia had power to the 128,000 volt substation cut off and more than an hour for an Amtrak engineering crew to arrive. In the meantime, Wendell Edmondson, 36, was dangling upside down from a beam 15 feet off the ground and was naked, his clothes apparently burned off by the contact with high voltage. Witnesses reported seeing a flash like lightning shortly after noticing him inside the station about 9:30 p.m. Saturday. ``One of the fallacies that people operate under is that if they don't touch any of the wires then they are relatively safe,'' said fire department spokesman Ted Holmes. ``If you come within a certain distance the voltage can arc over to you. But they don't understand the gravity of that much voltage.'' Edmondson, whose last known address was a homeless shelter, was listed in critical condition Monday in the burn unit of the Washington Hospital Center, where he was flown after he was freed at about 11:50 p.m. Saturday. Amtrak spokesman Bruce Heard said the response to the emergency ``is frankly a pretty good response on a Saturday night.'' Holmes said Fire Chief Ray Alfred plans to write Amtrak officials to determine what went wrong and to establish more efficient procedures for the future.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot Buried as Air Force Looks for Clues in Jet Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sub 1st, 4th grafs to CORRECT that memorial service was held, sted funeral and burial. Subs last graf to ADD scheduled burial.
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force pilot killed when his F-16A jet crashed into a rural south Georgia community was eulogized at a memorial service Monday while investigators continued to search for clues to the cause of the crash. One woman was killed on the ground. Although the F-16A has an ejection seat, Maj. Archie E. ``Gene'' Stuart stayed with his plane Friday in Pearson. Some witnesses said the plane initially seemed headed for Atkinson County High School, which houses about 1,000 students, but pulled away before crashing a half-mile away. The Rev. Douglas Reddick of Northside Baptist Church in Valdosta, one of the ministers officiating at the service for Stuart, said that although no one knows yet what happened, if Stuart did stay with the plane to miss the school ``it is consistent with his character.'' Stuart, 39, was stationed with the 68th Tactical Fighter Squadron at Moody Air Force Base at Valdosta The plane went down in a residential area a mile north of Pearson, about 40 miles from Valdosta, six minutes after taking off on a training mission to Lake George Weapons Range near Daytona Beach, Fla. Air Force officials formed a 50-member task force to attempt to determine the cause. Officials said it was too early to tell if Stuart was trying to avoid hitting the school and added that the investigation could take a month or more. Killed on the ground was Marion Lanier, 58, of Pearson. She was buried Sunday. Stuart is to be buried Thursday in Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEAD: Convoy of `Little Ships' Returns from Dunkirk
DOC.TEXT: To the cheers of thousands, a flotilla of 50 vessels returned from Dunkirk, France, on Monday after observances marking the 50th anniversary of the famous World War II evacuation of Allied troops. The flotilla, which left Dunkirk in the morning following a weekend of memorial observances, was accompanied across the busy shipping lanes of the English Channel by four Royal Navy vessels. Thousands of people lining the Ramsgate cliffs on the south coast of England cheered and military bands blared as the oddly assorted convoy of ``Little Ships'' came into view. The seagoing paddle-steamer The Waverley, packed with spectators, went out to mid-channel to escort the boats back. Monday's perfect sailing conditions contrasted with rough seas that caused several boats to abort their passage to France on Thursday. Among those atop the cliffs were some present in 1940 when fishermen, yachtsmen and amateur sailors in their ``Little Ships'' crossed the Channel to rescue Allied troops trapped on the beaches of Dunkirk by German forces. From May 27 to June 2 of that year the armada of civilian vessels rescued more than 330,000 men from the beaches. ``The memories have come flooding back today; some happy because so many of the boys were rescued, but some sad. We must never forget those who died,'' said one of those rescued, Ernie Thompson, who served with the Cameron Scottish Rifles. On Sunday, the beaches of Dunkirk were packed with thousands of veterans, their families and local townspeople commemorating the rescue mission.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Jews Arrive on Christian-Financed Flight
With AM-Arab Summit
DOC.TEXT: More than 200 Soviet immigrants arrived in Israel on Monday on a flight financed by Christian supporters of the Jewish state. Representatives of the Jerusalem-based International Christian Embassy met the immigrants at the Ben-Gurion Airport near Tel Aviv, holding flowers and placards that read ``Operation Second Exodus.'' The immigrants, who arrived via Hungary, were also met by U.S. Reps. William Lehman of Florida and Peter A. DeFazio of Oregon, who are in Israel to study resettlement programs for Soviet Jews. The two Democrats said they would be discussing the issue with Israeli officials, focusing on the settlement of immigrants in the occupied territories. ``We have been told that more than 99 percent of the refugees are choosing to live elsewhere other than in occupied areas, but this will be discussed in detail when we meet government officials,'' DeFazio told reporters. The United States and the Soviet Union strongly object to the settlement of Soviet immigrants in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, areas captured by Israel in 1967. The Arab countries view such resettlement as part of an Israeli expansionist plot to drive Palestinians out. Israel says it has no policy of directing immigrants to the occupied areas although it cannot stop them from choosing to settle there. Only about 200 of the 48,000 Soviet Jews who have arrived since 1989 have settled in the occupied territories. Johann Luckhoff, director of the International Christian Embassy, said his group has managed to raise about $150,000 to fund two flights of Soviet Jews and intends to continue the campaign. The group represents Christian supporters of Israel in more than 70 countries. Luckhoff said in a statement that, ``We are actually involved in saving lives ... and we are also helping the Jewish people fulfill their destiny of returning to their roots in the land of Israel.''

DOC.HEAD: Passenger Train Rams Sludge-Laden Tanker Truck; 9 Hurt
DOC.TEXT: An Amtrak passenger train slammed into a tanker truck loaded with sewage sludge on Monday, injuring nine people, none seriously, authorities said. The accident happened shortly before noon at a rural railroad crossing between Indiantown and Okeechobee in southeast Florida. The northbound train, on the regular Miami-New York Silver Meteor run, was carrying 153 passengers in 10 cars pulled by one locomotive, said Bruce Heard, an Amtrak spokesman in Washington, D.C. ``The train ... hit the trailer part of the truck, which was loaded with sewage,'' said Linda Main, a Florida Highway Patrol dispatcher. ``Stuff flew all over the place.'' The train was running full-speed, said Lt. Jim Howell of the Highway Patrol. ``It was doing 70 to 80 mph, which is pretty standard for that part of the county,'' he said. ``It virtually cut the tanker portion of the truck in half, and heavily damaged the locomotive and two of the passenger cars.'' The engineer escaped injury but the train's fireman suffered facial cuts, and both crew members were covered with sludge, Howell said. The fireman and eight passengers were taken to Martin County Memorial Hospital, where nursing supervisor Louise Frates said all were expected to be released after treatment for cuts, bumps and bruises. Heard said the other passengers were taken to a school, then bused to Okeechobee. They were picked up there by what had been a southbound Silver Meteor that was reversed, Heard said. Southbound passengers continued their journey by bus. CSX Transportation of Jacksonville, which owns the tracks, sent cleanup crews, Heard said. He expected the tracks to be back to normal by early evening. Only some freight trains may be delayed, he added. Howell said the truck driver, Hector Solar, was ticketed for failure to stop at a rilroad crossing, which led to a private ranch and orange groves. The sewage had been treated to a sludge state, ``but it has a potent smell and you still don't want to be around it,'' Howell said.

DOC.HEAD: Ceausescu's Son Drunk When He Ordered Gunfire, Commander Says
DOC.TEXT: Nicu Ceausescu was drunk when he ordered local army and police units to shoot at demonstrators rising against his dictator father, the former military commander of Sibiu garrison testified Monday. The alleged shooting order was not heeded, and under cross-examination, Col. Aurel Dragomir acknowledged it would have been ignored even if repeated. ``An order given by local party organs must be reported through levels to our superiors (the Defense Ministry in Bucharest) and is carried out only after their approval,'' he said, adding such approval was never received. Ceausescu, 39, former Communist Party secretary of Sibiu county, is charged with genocide for his purported part in efforts to suppress the popular revolt that ended Nicolae Ceausescu's 24-year hold on power. He pleaded not guilty. Dragomir repeated charges contained in the indictment read at trial opening Saturday that Nicu Ceausescu demanded institution of a state of war in Romania and ordered the shooting of demonstrators ``without warning.'' Former Interior Minister Tudor Postelnicu testified he received no word of such a command and said a regional party secretary like the defendant was not entitled to order security forces in his area to fire on protesters. Such an order ``should by obligation be reported on a central level'' to the Interior Ministry, but ``I received no information that Nicu ordered shooting or no shooting,'' Postelnicu testified. Postelnicu was sentenced to life imprisonment for backing the elder Ceausescu's order to fire on demonstrators. He was brought from Aiud prison, wearing striped prison garb but not handcuffed. The charges were based on stenographers' notes of a telephone conference call Dec. 17 between Nicu Ceausescu and local officials. Dragomir, 40, said he took part in the conference call and quoted Nicu Ceausescu as saying: ``We are in a state of war and not of emergency. We shoot without warning.'' He told a five-man military panel headed by Maj. Doru Ursu that Nicu Ceausescu telephoned him the evening of Dec. 17 to make sure the army was prepared to start shooting. ``Have you introduced cartridges in the barrels?,'' Dragomir quoted the younger Ceausescu as asking. The colonel said he replied ``No'' and was told, ``You must introduce cartridges in the barrels and shoot, because this is a war.'' According to the indictment, 89 people were killed in Sibiu, 150 miles northwest of Bucharest. Soldiers who sided with the demonstrators battled Nicolae Ceausescu's diehard security troops. Dragomir said Nicu Ceausescu was slightly intoxicated when he gave the shooting order Dec. 17, and never repeated it in the following days. The first bloody clashes in Sibiu occurred Dec. 21 and lasted about a week, he said. Camil Stroe, a veterinary surgeon and former director of the police dog-training school, said Nicu Ceausescu took part in a pheasant-hunting party that day where he and his entourage drank wine and plum brandy. ``After the return to Sibiu, Nicu went straight to the conference call,'' Stroe told the court. Dragomir said ``Nicu was under the influence of alcohol, and he spoke with some difficulty but rather coherently.'' The revolution began in Timisoara Dec. 17 and spread to other Transylvanian cities, including Sibiu, and to Bucharest. Communist dictator Ceausescu was captured on Dec. 22 and was executed on Christmas Day. At least 20 former officials in Sibiu county have sentenced to up to 20 years in prison on charges arising from the revolution.

DOC.HEAD: East, West German Armies Establish Relations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with quotes from press conference, details. ADDS byline
DOC.TEXT: The once-adversarial armies of East Germany and West Germany are establishing ties that include top-level leadership contacts, as both nations put the Cold War further behind them on the way to unification. For decades, the army of West Germany, a NATO member, was on guard against the troops of East Germany, a staunch Warsaw Pact member. West German Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg and his East German counterpart, Rainer Eppelmann, attempted during a news conference to calm neighboring countries' apprehensions about the new cooperation. ``The German-German cooperation in the military sphere must take place with careful consideration of the security interests of the states of both alliances,'' Eppelmann said. Eppelmann, who says the Warsaw Pact is apparently on the verge of breaking up, said Monday a German-German exchange of soldiers during military exercises is not planned. The East German defense chief said relations are to include the ``adoption and promotion of contacts between the leaderships, formations and units as well as institutions'' of both nations' armed forces. ADN, the official East German news agency, said the contacts are to start on Friday. The two sides also agreed on ``intensifying cooperation'' on security and disarmament questions. Stoltenberg emphasized what he referred to as the ``central importance'' of conventional arms talks now under way in Vienna. The Soviets have recently balked at signing an agreement that would reduce Soviet and American soldiers in central Europe to 195,000 for each side. The agreement would include troops in East Germany and West Germany. The West German defense chief said that a pullout of all 250,000 U.S. troops in his country was ``not sensible because of security reasons.'' There are about 380,000 Soviet troops in East Germany. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has vigorously opposed membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for a united Germany. He has vowed to review his military strategy if the reunited country insists on such a step. The West German armed forces total about 480,000 personnel. East Germany's armed forces, estimated at 135,000, have been plagued by low morale and desertions.

DOC.HEAD: Kilauea Volcano Claims Another Home
DOC.TEXT: Kilauea Volcano destroyed the 153rd home of its seven-year eruption Monday and threatened at least two others in this lava-ravaged Hawaii Island community, authorities said. A house located north of the Kalapana Store and Drive-In and Mauna Kea Congregational Church burned at 6 a.m., Hawaii County civil defense spokesman Bruce Butts said. He said the half-mile-wide flow continued to move erratically. It was filling low spots in what remains of Kalapana and was not moving toward the ocean. At last report, lava was within 25 yards of the closest home.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Bans Hunting, Sale of Endangered Turtles
LaserPhoto MO1
DOC.TEXT: No more turtle soup in Mexico as of Monday. No more turtle steaks, turtle eggs that locals favor as aphrodisiacs or turtle shells for combs, computer boards and vanity cases. Turtle skin exports to Japan for shoes, belts and handbags are over. Under pressure from environmental groups, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari signed an executive order declaring an end to Mexico's turtle industry, probably the world's largest. Until Monday, the country was the world's leading exporter of turtle products, but environmentalists say sea turtles are being hunted to extinction here. Mexico is home to 10 of the world's 11 species of sea turtles, and nine of them lay eggs and nest on its beaches. Salinas signed the ban at a ceremony Monday in the capital's historic Chapultepec Castle in the presence of environmentalists from the world over, governors whose states are involved with turtles, and fishing industry leaders. ``In signing this decree, we are taking a definite step to help this species continue its biological developments, ... threatened with extinction because its natural habitat has been considerably reduced,'' Salinas said. The government will close all turtle slaughterhouses and provide money to help turtle fishermen and their families diversify. Todd Steiner of Earth Island Institute said Salinas had received more than 70,000 letters in six months protesting lack of protection for turtles. Steiner said environmentalists talked of declaring a tourism boycott on Mexico and about 10,000 Americans signed a petition saying they would not visit Mexico unless protective laws were passed. Environmentalists on Monday praised the ban but said the test will come in enforcing it. They said Mexico also must join the 107-nation Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Flora and Fauna, known as CITES. Every country in the Western Hemisphere except Mexico has signed the accord, which bars trade in endangered species. Mexico is Japan's biggest supplier of turtle skins, and Japan is the world's biggest importer of turtle products. Japan joined CITES, but excluded turtle products. Steiner said his organization was happy with Monday's ban that was aimed at stopping ``what was the largest killing of an endangered species occurring anywhere in the world.'' ``But we will be monitoring the situation closely to make sure these wonderful words are fully implemented,'' he said. Michael Weber, vice president of the Center for Marine Conservation in Washington, said the ban could help the Olive Ridley turtles, which nest on the Pacific coast, recover from decades of exploitation. Weber said environmentalists are also urging Mexico to require use of turtle excluder devices in shrimp nets. ``They say it's going to end the killing. We hope it's going to end the killing,'' said Andrew Davis, a spokesman for Greenpeace International. But he said enforcement could be difficult on the isolated, remote beaches where turtles lay their eggs. Most eggs are laid on the Pacific beaches of the states of Oaxaca, Michoacan, Guererro and Jalisco. Last year, the government set a quota of 20,000 turtles but more than 35,000 were killed at the state-owned turtle slaughterhouse in Oaxaca state and 40,000 others clandestinely, Earth Island Institute said. The biggest slaughter was of Pacific Olive Ridley turtles, whose skins were sold to Japan. Hawksbill turtles were killed in the Caribbean for tortoise shell. The Kemp's Ridley, whose population has plunged from 100,000 to 300 in two decades, has its main nesting ground at Rancho Nuevo, in northeastern Tamaulipas state on the Gulf of Mexico. Because so many were killed, much of the meat was wasted, Elisabeth Robinson Gunther, also of Earth Island, said. Protection programs sponsored by ecological organizations and the government have been rescuing eggs, caring for them until they hatch and releasing the young turtles into the sea. Turtle soup, eggs and steaks are popular local foods but with Monday's measure would themselves become banned.

DOC.HEAD: Schools Reopen in Christian Enclave
DOC.TEXT: About one-third of the schools in Lebanon's battered Christian enclave opened on Monday for the first time in nearly four months in response to a call by the Vatican to resume classes. But two-thirds of the schools remained closed due to 119 days of brutal clashes between rebel Gen. Michel Aoun's army and militiamen loyal to Christian warlord Samir Geagea. ``The others remained closed either because they had been wrecked by the shelling, or their buses burned or their staff had fled the enclave to safer areas,'' said a police spokesman, who could not be named under standing regulations. The Vatican's nuncio in Lebanon, Pablo Puente, called on Saturday for the opening of schools after both Aoun and Geagea pledged to him to turn a cease-fire called on May 17 into a permanent truce. At least 1,035 people have been killed and 2,770 wounded since the power struggle between the rival leaders broke out Jan. 30. The inconclusive showdown forced about 400,000 of the enclave's 1 million people to seek refuge in safer areas and left large areas of the Christian enclave in ruins.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Parliament Gives Preliminary OK to Electoral Reform Bill
DOC.TEXT: Israel's parliament on Monday took the first step toward legislating direct election of the nation's prime minister and other electoral reforms. The Knesset approved a preliminary reading of four reform bills designed to reduce political horsetrading between parties forming government coalitions, which one legislator called symbolic of Israel's patchwork democratic process. ``I see this day as the first step in healing the system,'' said Amnon Rubinstein, leader of the liberal Shinui Party, which drafted one of the bills. The proposals will now be brought to the parliament law committee, where they will be consolidated into one piece of legislation for the second and third Knesset readings required for the measure to become law. Liberal parties have long sought electoral reforms, without success. But their cause gained momentum recently when the two major political forces, the Labor Party and Likud bloc, raised the public's ire by using political posts and public funds to lure defectors to cross party lines and to woo religious factions. Ultra-Orthodox parties, which currently hold the balance of power between the two largest political blocs, opposed the reforms as an infringement of their influence. In separate votes Monday, the 120-seat Knesset overwhelmingly approved bills submitted by the right-wing Likud bloc, the center-left Labor Party, the right-wing Tzomet and the liberal Shinui. The Labor proposal got the most votes, winning 60-33. It calls for direct election of the premier, as do the other proposals, and empowers the prime minister to put together a Cabinet without parliament approval. Under the current system, voters choose from a selection of national party lists. The head of the party that has the most seats and is able to form a coalition government has traditionally become prime minister. Uriel Lynn of Likud, the law committee chairman, said he would put together a joint bill within three months.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Return Part of Fort to Panamanians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to move higher in story proposal involving U.S. Coast Guard ships. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The United States returned part of Fort Amador to Panamanian forces on Monday after occupying it since the December invasion that toppled dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. Foreign Minister Julio Linares said talks between Panama and the United States continue on a number of issues stemming from the invasion, and also said that a plan has been proposed to let U.S. Coast Guard ships operate in Panamanian waters if a Panamanian officer is on board. Linares said he opposes the idea in principle. ``If the idea really is to put down the drug traffic, it needn't be done at the cost of our jurisdiction or national dignity,'' Linares said. Fort Amador, on a strip of land at the Pacific entrance to the Panama Canal, contained Noriega's main offices and was occupied jointly by American and Panamanian forces. At the transfer ceremony, President Guillermo Endara said the Panamanian portion of Fort Amador would be converted to a tourist site. U.S. forces will remain in the other part. Endara said that on Thursday the Rio Hato military base 70 miles southeast of the capital also will revert to Panamanian control. The United States took over key military installations during the invasion and has gradually been returning them. Noriega's powerful Panama Defense Forces were disbanded after the invasion and are being replaced with a regular police force. Ambassador Dean Hinton represented the United States at Monday's ceremony. The United States invaded Dec. 20, 1989, to capture Noriega, who was sought in the United States on drug trafficking charges. Noriega took refuge in the Vatican Embassy and surrendered to American forces Jan. 3. He was flown to Miami where he faces federal drug charges. Linares said Panamanian and U.S. officials are continuing their talks on U.S.-occupied bases here and on documents captured by American forces. He said the documents are vital to on-going investigations within Panama. Thousands of boxes of documents were captured, partly in hopes of tracing the cocaine-running operation to which Noriega is tied.

DOC.HEAD: Solidarity Claims Big Victories in Local Council Voting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Solidarity claiming sweeping victory in Warsaw. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `But Mateusz ...'
DOC.TEXT: Officials on Monday began adding up the results of the first free elections to local councils since World War II, and Solidarity claimed decisive victories in Warsaw and elsewhere. Candidates from more than 80 parties on Sunday competed in 52,000 races nationwide, a vote that aroused the interest of less than half the electorate. Official results were to be announced Wednesday. The pro-Solidarity daily Gazeta Wyborcza said preliminary tallies indicated candidates of the Solidarity Citizens Committee had won big victories nearly everywhere. Unofficial results in Warsaw indicated the Solidarity trade union movement had won 301 of the 341 council seats, according to Halina Szymula of the Citizens Committee in the capital. But Mateusz Wyrwich, spokesman for the General Election Commission, said it was too early to predict the outcome because of the complexity of the coalitions and multitude of parties. Former Communists appeared to have won seats in the Mokotow district of Warsaw, while Peasant parties were expected to land seats in rural areas. The vote tally is complicated by the difficulty of identifying the political orientation of some parties and groups. Wyrwich said that in central Bydgoszcz, former Communists campaigned as the ``Democratic Opposition.'' The elections were to advance democratic reform by establishing independent local governments. Under four decades of Communist Party rule, councils were subordinate politically and financially to central authorities. The voter turnout, however, was only 42 percent nationwide, according to the General Election Commission. In last June's partially free parliamentary balloting, 62 percent of Poles voted. The sweeping victory of Solidarity candidates in the June vote led to the formation in August of the Solidarity-led government. Solidarity leader Lech Walesa joined political commentators Monday in attributing the lack of enthusiasm to confusion over the new political parties, many of which have yet to define their programs. ``Theoreticians will say that people are discouraged. But I think that in such a short time people cannot get re-oriented to civic activeness,'' Walesa said Monday. ``Fewer people at the polls is the expression of a weaker belief in the program of democratization and the sense of one's participating in it,'' read a front-page commentary in the Gazeta Wyborcza. The government daily Rzeczpospolita said participation is traditionally lower in local elections than in parliamentary or presidential ballots, but turnout was high in communities where local problems aroused voter concern. The paper also attributed the low turnout to confusion over the divisions emerging in Solidarity. Walesa has criticized the pace of reform of the government led by Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. ``The monolothic camp `Solidarity' clearly has split. And the existing political parties have not managed to persuade voters of their program and candidates. People don't know exactly whom to support,'' the commentary said. Local governments were previously dependent on Warsaw for funds, but under a new system they will receive revenue from state businesses that are to be turned over to councils. Parliament is also preparing legislation that would allow local governments to set taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Glass and Ginsberg Bring Their ``Hydrogen Jukebox'' to Festival
DOC.TEXT: A new production joins the words of Allen Ginsberg and the music of Philip Glass to tell a 30-year story _ the decline of ``the American empire.'' ``The Hydrogen Jukebox,'' which premiered over the weekend at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., is based on Ginsberg's poems dating to the 1960s. The poet and the composer, along with visual artist Jerome Sirlin, began putting the show together in 1989. The festival production features six singers and a six-piece orchestra. Glass said he and Ginsberg had discussed collaborating for some time, but only last year sat down to select poems and compose music. ``The Hydrogen Jukebox'' is about the ``decline of the American empire,'' Ginsberg said in an interview during rehearsals at the Sottile Theater. Each scene is built around a poem; the subjects include the Vietnam War, ecology and cocaine trafficking. ``It's basically an emotional and moral decline,'' Ginsberg said of the show's theme. ``It's not an angry accusation. It's more of a meditation on the decline of an empire. The biggest decline of empire is we won't face our problems.'' Glass said most of the 21 poems were written some time ago, and he was faced with the challenge of finding ``a doorway into the poem.'' ``You can do things with the music that you can't do in the poem,'' said Glass, who collaborated on the epic opera ``Einstein on the Beach'' with Robert Wilson. For instance, one scene has a man sitting on a porch and thinking about the Vietnam War. ``He's thinking about the war and he's also thinking about a train,'' Glass said. ``You never see the train on the stage but there is this rolling bass line which becomes the feeling of the train. The music becomes the embodiment of one aspect of the poem.'' Spoleto is billing the production as the premiere of the opera version of ``The Hydrogen Jukebox.'' The poems and music were performed concert-style earlier this year in Philadelphia. Glass said ``Jukebox'' also will be performed later this year at the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy, companion to the festival here. Glass and Ginsberg have both appeared, separately, at the Italian festival. This is the first appearance for each at the festival here. The two already were auditioning singers when they were contacted about bringing the production here. ``We were going to do the piece anyway. We were confident we could get someone to produce it so we went ahead,'' Glass said. ``People ask me if I always work on commission and I do. But the trick is I work on what I want and then I coax somebody into paying for it.'' Asked whether ``Jukebox'' might appeal primarily to aging hippies, Ginsberg said he saw its audience as ``teen-agers as much as anyone. It's like (the show is) filling in the gaps in history in the last 30 to 40 years.'' Glass agreed. ``We're in a festival atmosphere now so this is a little bit different. But, generally speaking, this will be a younger audience,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Earth First! Hires Private Investigator
DOC.TEXT: The group Earth First! has hired a private investigator to look into a car bomb explosion in which two members were injured and later implicated by police, the group's co-founder said Monday. ``The first thing we noticed was that they (police) were looking only for evidence that would show that Judi and Darryl were guilty rather than looking for the people who did it,'' said Mike Roselle, co-founder of the radical environmental group. San Francisco Bay area private investigator Sheila O'Donnel already has begun working with Earth First! lawyer Susan Jordan, Roselle said. Judi Bari, 40, and Darryl Cherney, 33, were booked Friday for investigation of violation of state explosive laws and each held in lieu of $100,000 bail. The Alameda County district attorney's office has until 4 p.m. Tuesday to file charges against Bari and Cherney. A pipe bomb went off in Bari's station wagon as the two were driving through Oakland on Thursday, injuring both. The activists reportedly were driving to Santa Cruz to promote a non-violent campaign to halt logging of old-growth timber. Earth First! is a loose-knit group of environmentalists, some of whom advocate tactics like blockades and tree-spiking to discourage the harvesting of trees. A round-the-clock vigil held by Earth First! supporters outside Oakland police headquarters ended Monday after officers emerged at 5 a.m. and ordered participants to disperse. None of the protesters was arrested, police said. They had vowed to maintain the vigil until Bari and Cherney were released. Friends and sympathizers of the two have insisted since the blast that Bari and Cherney were victims, not bombers. Several Earth First! supporters maintained a vigil for Bari outside Highland Hospital, where she was in serious condition with a broken pelvis and other injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Reopens Spanish Mass Poisoning Case
DOC.TEXT: A judge has renewed hope for Spaniards awaiting compensation in the 1981 sale of cooking oil that victims' groups say killed up to 836 people and felled more than 20,000 others. Judge Carlos Bueren began proceedings Monday to subpoena 10 former public officials accused of negligence for allowing import and sale of the rapeseed oil, which was meant for industrial use. The ruling clears the way for a future trial. The oil was imported from France, adulterated and then sold in working-class neighborhoods as cheap olive oil. Bueren ruled Friday the Spanish state was liable for the former officials' actions at the time and would have to pay any indemnization resulting from a guilty verdict. The case had been shelved by another judge. Bueren's decision came a year after a separate verdict convicted 13 people _none of them government officials _ on public health and fraud charges for importing and selling the oil, but acquitted them of manslaughter. The 1989 verdict fixed indemnization payments, but those convicted claimed insolvency. Victims' groups complained the verdict did not guarantee payment.

DOC.HEAD: Witness to Police Slayings Still Waiting for Reward
DOC.TEXT: It's been eight years since Dwayne Hardin identified the men later convicted of killing two police officers, but he's still waiting for the $60,000 reward. ``I didn't receive nothing but `Thank you. Adios','' said Hardin, 34. When officers William Fahey and Richard O'Brien were fatally shot Feb. 9, 1982, the then mayor, Jane Byrne, offered $50,000 for information leading to the conviction of whoever was responsible. The Fraternal Order of Police offered $10,000. Hardin, who had been driving by the murder scene and stopped to help the officers, saw two men jump into a car and drive away. ``I got out and checked one officer,'' Hardin said. ``He looked like he was dead. The other was trying to get up. Blood was coming out of his mouth and eyes. I told him `Lay down, everything's going to be all right.' ... I reached for the police radio and hollered for help.'' Hardin testified against brothers Andrew and Jackie Wilson at a 1983 trial, and they were convicted. But the mayor had failed to get any official allocation for the $50,000 she offered, and Hardin sued, said his lawyer, Hubert Thompson. The Wilsons' convictions were overturned, partly because they weren't allowed separate trials. And Hardin's lawsuit was dismissed because the convictions no longer existed. The Wilsons were tried again in 1988. Again Hardin testified and again they were convicted. ``He was an excellent witness for us,'' said prosecutor William Merritt. John Dineen, president of the Fraternal Order of Police, said $10,000 has been set aside for Hardin and several other witnesses to share. But he said the reward is based upon a final conviction, and the Wilsons have not exhausted their appeal rights. Dineen said that if the convictions are again reversed, the reward could jeopardize Hardin's testimony. ``A smart defense lawyer would ask, `Did you get paid to say my person committed homicide?''' he said. Andrea Brands, a spokeswoman for the city's legal department, said Byrne's reward offer is under study. Byrne lost her re-election bid in the 1983 primary.

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Employees Hold Silent Protest March
DOC.TEXT: More than 500 Vatican employees held a silent march Monday night to protest an impasse in negotiations over higher wages and other labor demands, the employees' association said. The Association of Vatican Lay Employees said in a statement that the protest was intended to point out the lack of response to its request for meetings with high-ranking Vatican officials. ``This demonstration was aimed especially at obtaining an audience with the Holy Father,'' said the association's president, Mariano Cerullo. He said the association was sure that if such a meeting could be arranged, the problems could be worked out. The workers complained they had not received sufficient cost-of-living increases since 1985, that pensions were too low and that there was no clear procedure through which they could express demands. The 45-minute march went from the workers' cafeteria through Vatican grounds to the San Damaso courtyard on the northern side of St. Peter's Square, the association said. Cerullo said 1,400 of the approximately 1,900 Vatican lay employees belonged to the association. In February 1988, hundreds of Vatican employees took part in a labor protest in which they donated part of their salaries to the pope to call attention to their demands.

DOC.HEAD: Dublin's Gate Theater Presents ``Salome'' At Spoleto Festival U.S.A
DOC.TEXT: A brilliant, stylized production of Oscar Wilde's play ``Salome'' is being presented at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. by the Gate Theater of Dublin. Everybody except John the Baptist is in white face. Everybody walks in slow motion. The costumes are black for Herodias, white for Salome, black and white gowns for Herod's female dinner guests and tuxedos for men. In the fourth of 17 performance Monday at the Dock Street Theater, John the Baptist sat, wearing torn pants, on a square at stage center, presumably at the bottom of a cistern. The lighting was unusual and imaginative. It all worked. Alan Stanford entered as Herod and in a few sentences established his character as a complete hedonist. He was large, soft looking, effete, and looked like one imagines Wilde to have looked. His voice was plummy, sounding rich and dissatisfied. From this beginning, Stanford added to his character as the play progresses. It was an amazing feat of acting. Whether or not Wilde intended to make Herod the central figure in his story of obsession, Stanford has seen to it that he is. Olwen Fouere played Salome, a spoiled teen-ager who spits back with spite when John the Baptist rejects her advances. Her voice was young. She's a nymphette, for the first time attracted sexually to a man who's handsome, strong, authoritative and probably dangerous. Fouere left it ambiguous as to whether Salome knows what she's doing. It's her obsession to kiss John the Baptist that leads Salome to dance for Herod and then demand John the Baptist's head. Her dance is little more than turning slowly in a circle and miming a striptease. Stanford's Herod was superstitious, fearing that if he has John the Baptist beheaded something bad will happen to him. His description of the jewels he would give Salome instead of the head is the most sensuous passage in this production. Barbara Brennan played a brittle, husband-nagging Herodias. Wilde has given her most of his few cynical, clever lines inserted for dramatic relief. To frequent comments on the meaning of the moon's aspect, Herodias says dryly, ``The moon is like the moon.'' Steven Berkoff directed this ``Salome'' for the Gate Theater in 1988. He later directed the play in London, and played Herod. Roger Doyle played piano on stage almost continually, sometimes quite loud when John the Baptist was shouting from his cistern, sometimes new age music behind speeches, sometimes jazz for dinner guests to dance to. At one point, the Gate Theater was dancing an almost-Charleston in Charleston. It's interesting, that while the Spoleto Festival worries whether the avant-garde musical performance art piece ``Pioneer'' may be found objectionable, in 1891 ``Salome'' encountered a British law prohibiting showing biblical characters on stage. And Martha Graham's modern dances based on Greek legends were once considered by some too sensual to be seen. Two of those were on Sunday night's Martha Graham Dance Company program at the Gaillard Auditorium. Now they're clearly seen as masterpieces. ``Errand into the Maze'' had Christine Dakin battling Mario Camacho as the Creature of Fear, her fear of her own sexual nature. Terese Capucilli danced Jocasta and Kenneth Topping as Oedipus, in ``Night Journey,'' in which Jocasta has flashbacks of life with a husband who was also her son. All four danced brilliantly. The company also danced the Martha Graham work that is a favorite with many, ``Appalachian Spring,'' to Aaron Copland music, plus ``Diversion of Angels,'' to music by Norman Dello Joio. Audience members reacted as though they had seen a revelation. Miss Graham, who turned 96 this month, smiled broadly while taking a curtain call and attended a party afterwards. Spoleto Festival U.S.A. runs through June 10 and features 110 performances ranging from high opera to jazz, ballet and concerts. Pulitzer prize-winning composer Gian Carlo Menotti founded the festival in 1977 and modeled it after his Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Key Evidence in Jesuit Murder Case Burned
DOC.TEXT: Two army officers oversaw the removal of log books that might have listed those who left the Military College the night troops allegedly murdered six Jesuits, the Supreme Court said Monday. The court cited a report from the U.S.-funded Special Investigative Unit, the principal agency investigating the pre-dawn Nov. 16 massacre of six Jesuit priest-educators, their housekeeper and her daughter at Central American University. A colonel, three lieutenants and five soldiers have been charged with murder. One of the nine, a private, is a fugitive. The court said the log books, which registered entrances and exits from the school and were considered important evidence, were removed by order of Maj. Carlos Hernandez, then assistant director of the Military College. Lt. Rene Mendoza headed the detail that removed the books, and then burned them, the court said. President Alfredo Cristiani, in an afternoon news conference, said the court statement was ``incorrect'' in the part referring to Hernandez. He said Hernandez had ordered the log books be set aside or otherwise placed at hand so they could be made available to the court handling the Jesuit case. Even so, the president agreed Hernandez should be questioned by the judge about the books. ``The investigation into what happened to the log books was undertaken at our (the presidency's) initiative. In no way have we been trying to cover anything up,'' said Cristiani. Mendoza is a defendant. Col. Guillermo Benavides, then-director of the College and Hernandez' erstwhile boss, is the highest-ranking officer charged in the slayings. Ricardo Zamora, the judge in charge of the Jesuit case, will question both Hernandez and Mendoza in the coming days, the court statement said. A U.S. congressional task force concluded last month that the investigation into the Jesuits' slayings was at ``a virtual standstill.'' The congresssional report cited a lack of forthrightness on the part of the military as a major reason for the failure to build a case against those accused in the massacre. The armed forces and rightist death-squads have usually been blamed for the deaths of suspected political opponents in El Salvador, some of whom are believed to be activist priests. On Sunday, however, a leading international rights organization criticized rebel forces for sentencing scores of people to death in El Salvador, saying such acts violate the Geneva Convention. Americas Watch, in a 38-page document, urged the rebels to discontinue the death penalty. The report summarizes the cases of 28 people either summarily killed by the left or executed after guerrilla trials the past two years. More than 72,000 people, most of them civilians, have been killed in 10 years of civil war between the leftist Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, or FMLN, and a succession of U.S.-backed governments. On Sunday, Jorge Melendez, El Salvador's top rebel leader inside the country, said the guerrillas want to take part in next year's elections, but that electoral reforms and civil guarantees must come first. ``If the necessary changes in our society are not legally enshrined, we cannot lay down our arms,'' Melendez told about 400 rebel troops in the northern guerrilla stronghold of Perquin. The five top FMLN commanders have been outside El Salvador for more than a year on diplomatic and logistical missions. Two took part this month in five days of U.N.-sponsored peace talks with government representatives in Caracas, Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Serbia Protests Lantos' Visit
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia's largest republic of Serbia strongly protested on Monday the visit of Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., to its restive province of Kosovo and neighboring Communist Albania. On Sunday, Lantos was warmly welcomed by thousands of members of Kosovo's ethnic Albanian majority, who are fighting for more autonomy from Serbia. With him was former Rep. Joseph Dioguardi, R-N.Y. The two men arranged to travel to Tirana, Albania, from Pristina, Kosovo's capital, on what Lantos termed an official mission to see if the United States should open diplomatic ties with Albania. A Serbian government statement called the Americans' visit and reception in Pristina ``a serious blow to relations between Yugoslavia and the United States'' and asked the federal Yugoslav government to protest officially to Washington. Serbia has drawn world fire over its human rights policies toward Kosovo's ethnic Albanians.

DOC.HEAD: Paintings Stolen from Two Paris Museums
DOC.TEXT: Two 19th-century paintings valued at about $400,000 have been stolen from Paris museums, police said Monday. They said an evening scene of the town of Delft by Dutch painter Johan Barthold Jongkind, valued at about $360,000, was stolen Friday by robbers who entered the Petit-Palais museum during regular visiting hours and got away without being detected by guards. The 1868 work was owned by the city of Paris. On Saturday, a portrait of Jean-Baptiste Rodin, father of sculptor Auguste Rodin, was stolen from a hallway in the Rodin Museum. The work was valued at about $40,000.

DOC.HEAD: Stormie Jones Returns Home After Brief Stay in Pittsburgh Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, the 12-year-old girl who made medical history as the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient, returned to her suburban Fort Worth home Monday after being hospitalized in Pittsburgh. Clad in a white Ronald McDonald House sweatshirt and clutching a small brown teddy bear, she hid behind her mother as a small group of well-wishers greeted the youngster at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. She also shied away from television cameras and reporters. After several minutes of prodding by reporters, Stormie snapped: ``I don't want to talk. I want to go home.'' But she did say she was feeling ``fine.'' Her mother, Lois ``Suzie'' Purcell, when asked about her daughter's prognosis, replied: ``It looks good at the moment.'' Stormie entered the Pittsburgh hospital May 20 after routine tests showed high liver enzyme levels, an indication of possible organ rejection. Further tests revealed the rejection was moderate and could be controlled with increased doses of an experimental anti-rejection medication Stormie has taken since November. Ms. Purcell said the trip's back and forth to Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh have been frustrating and tiring for the family. She compared the experience to being on a roller-coaster ride. After their brief comments, mother and daughter, surrounded by well-wishers and family members, scurried off to Stormie's home in White Settlement, a Fort Worth suburb. Stormie, who drew national attention when she became the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient on Valentine's Day 1984, will turn 13 on Thursday. Stormie received the double transplant to control a congenital condition that left her cholesterol levels 10 times higher than normal. She returned to Pittsburgh for a second liver transplant, performed early this year, after hepatitis damaged the first liver she received.

DOC.HEAD: Lowest Voter Turnout in Decades in Colombian Elections
with AM-Colombia
DOC.TEXT: Only 42 percent of eligible voters went to the polls in this weekend's presidential elections, the lowest voting rate in decades, official results showed Monday. Observers said many Colombians may have been afraid to leave their homes and vote because of the resurgence of violence across the country. In the two weeks preceding the elections, bombings in Colombia left 37 people dead and 350 injured. Officials blamed the attacks on drug traffickers. The election's winner, Cesar Gaviria, 43, of the ruling Liberal Party, has promised to crush drug terrorism when he takes office on Aug. 7. Gaviria, who took up his candidacy when his predecessor Sen. Carlos Luis Galan was assassinated last Auguest, won the balloting with 47 percent of the vote, compared to 24 percent for his closest rival, Alvaro Gomez of the National Salvation Movement. In Medellin, a major center of cocaine production, Mayor Juan Gomez imposed a pre-election curfew. ``People are afraid to be in public areas,'' said Camilo Castellanos, a political expert. The elections took place in relative calm in the major cities, and the only major incidents were a series of armed confrontations between security forces and leftist guerrillas in the countryside. In southern Colombia, leftist guerrillas ambushed two police vehicles killing at least 10 people and three electoral officials were reported missing after the incident, police Col. Jaime Pena told the RCN radio network. Pre-election violence forced most candidates to conduct their campaigns through television and radio because public appearances were considered too dangerous.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Republican to Battle Own Party's Cuomo Challenger
DOC.TEXT: A conservative Republican threw a wrench Monday into his party's plans for challenging Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo, by pledging to run on the Conservative Party line. ``This is a year to attack both the Republican and the Democratic parties,'' said Herbert London, a New York University professor, after meeting with likely GOP gubernatorial nominee Pierre Rinfret. London, 51, said Rinfret, 66, offered him the lieutenant governor's slot on the GOP ticket, but that he refused. Normally, Republicans and Conservatives agree on a ticket. A split would only make it easier for Cuomo to win an expected bid for a third four-year term. London said he realized his decision would hurt Rinfret's chances of beating Cuomo. ``But I don't think he had a great chance to begin with, let's be perfectly blunt about it,'' said London, adding it was ``unlikely'' he could beat Cuomo running only on the Conservative line. London said his candidacy was ``a way of putting the Republican Party on notice ... As long as they're going to use litmus tests that rule out conservatives, we don't have an alternative.'' London has maintained that his conservative views, including his anti-abortion stance, were unacceptable to the state GOP's leadership and hurt his chances of gaining their support for his gubernatorial candidacy. Rinfret is reported to favor abortion rights, as does Cuomo. State GOP Chairman J. Patrick Barrett said London's decision ``certainly makes our job perhaps more difficult.'' ``But by the same token,'' he added, ``I think we have a superb candidate in Pierre Rinfret and we will still beat Mario Cuomo. It was an uphill fight to begin with, so what's the difference?'' GOP leaders had hoped to end an embarrasingly long search for a Cuomo challenger with a Rinfret-London ticket in place when the party's state convention opens Tuesday. They also hoped such a ticket would bring Conservative Party leaders back into the fold. But Conservatives have objected to Rinfret almost from the first mention of his name as a potential candidate early last week. Conservative Party Chairman Michael Long said he expected to announce London as a formal candidate by Wednesday. Rinfret has consistently refused to be interviewed.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Sikh Militants Kill 14 Hindu Laborers
DOC.TEXT: Suspected Sikh militants stormed a road construction camp in Punjab state on Monday and killed at least 14 Hindu laborers in their tents, police said. Police officials in Chandigarh, the state capital, said Gurjant Singh claimed responsibility for the killings. Singh heads one of the Sikh militant groups operating in Punjab. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the claim was made in a note left at the site of the killings. Also Monday, 11 other people were killed by militants in Punjab, the United News of India reported. The killings were reported from various parts of the rich farming state, which has been the scene of an 8-year-old secessionist campaign by militant Sikhs. The killings raise to 931 the number of people killed by suspected militants in Punjab this year. State police chief K.P.S. Gill claimed the assailants in Chandigarh were based in Pakistan. The international border is 18 miles northwest of the road camp. India has repeatedly accused Pakistan of providing bases for Sikh militant groups, a charge that Islamabad has routinely denied. India and Pakistan often accuse the other side of exacerbating ethnic and religious tensions in the other's territory. Sikhs form a slight majority in Punjab, but comprise only 2 percent of India's 880 million people. Militants from the community have been fighting for an independent nation since 1982, claiming Sikhs are discriminated against by Hindus, who make up 82 percent of India's population.

DOC.HEAD: New President Orders Pinochet to Hand Over Secret Police Files
DOC.TEXT: President Patricio Aylwin summoned former military ruler Augusto Pinochet to the government palace Monday, ordered him to hand over secret police records and told him the army must stay out of politics. Pinochet, who remains army commander, was forced to walk a gantlet of demonstrators shouting ``murderer!'' and other insults when his armored car was denied entrance at the palace gate. Visibly furious, he complained about the treatment to a police guard. Inside, he met privately with Aylwin and Defense Minister Patrico Rojas for an hour. There was no immediate explanation of why palace guards barred Pinochet's car from entering the gate.
