According to a statement issued later by Aylwin's office, the president asked Pinochet for details on the dissolving of the National Information Center, a feared secret police agency that functioned during the 16{-year military rule. ``He also ordered that the files gathered during its (the center's) legal existence be put at the government's disposition, to help prevent and combat terrorism,'' the statement said. In recent weeks, the local press has reported that former secret policemen were caught conducting surveillance on officials of the new government. The center was legally disbanded shortly before Pinochet handed power over to Aylwin's elected government in March. Pinochet later called the meeting with Aylwin ``very pleasant'' and added, ``He said he wants the files and I told him we will provide all the necessary information.'' Aylwin also complained about the ``political connotation'' of an army statement that expressed concern about the creation of a special commission to investigate human rights abuse that occurred during Pinochet's rule. Aylwin told him the army had no authority to question the panel's creation, but instead should be trying to cooperate with it, according to the statement. Pinochet replied he didn't mean to question Aylwin's authority, although he had reservations about the investigation, the president's statement said. ``He expressed the army's willingness to cooperate,'' the statement said. Pinochet left the meeting by a private underground exit, avoiding reporters. He told reporters later, however, that the army statement on the human rights panel was not politically motivated. Aylwin took office March 11, ending the authoritarian rule by Pinochet, who took power in a 1973 coup. The right-wing general's administration was marked by harsh repression of leftists and accusations of systematic rights abuse. It was the first time Aylwin had summoned Pinochet to a meeting. The two men met at the palace three weeks ago at the request of Pinochet, who then complained about the human rights commission. A clause in the 1980 constitution, written by Pinochet's administration, allows him to remain army commander until 1998.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslavian President Withdraws Threat of State of Emergency
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia's president warned Monday that rising nationalism could escalate into civil war, but he withdrew an earlier threat to impose a state of emergency in secessionist-minded regions. Borisav Jovic, a hard-line Serbian Communist who took over the collective presidency earlier this month, had threatened ``urgent measures'' to maintain national unity after center-right parties won free elections in the northern republics of Slovenia and Croatia. Despite the withdrawal of that threat in a speech to the federal parliament, Jovic insisted on strict adherence to the current Communist federal constitution. ``There is a huge escalation of nationalism, and tensions are increasing in relations between different nationalities and even republics,'' Jovic said. ``The process of disintegration is spreading and threatens to get out of control.'' The new governments in Croatia and Slovenia seek a much looser federal alliance, and have threatened to secede altogether if their demands are not met. Their deputies angrily refused to vote on Jovic's proposals for easing the interregional strife that threatens to pull apart Yugoslavia's fragile federation. The deputies argued that they must first clear the proposals with the new multiparty legislatures in their republics. Free elections in Slovenia and Croatia have intensified a dispute with Serbia, the only one of Yugoslavia's six republics that so far has refused to schedule multiparty elections or legalize opposition groups. Jovic, sounding a note of moderation, proposed new talks between the presidency and leaders from all Yugoslavia's regions on a new constitution. ``The Presidency is not considering a state of emergency and is not planning to annul the elections'' in Slovenia and Croatia, Jovic said. He also proposed a new law making it possible for republics to secede from Yugoslavia, but warned that ``constitutional order is seriously jeopardized'' and that Yugoslav laws are flagrantly violated by some of the 130 largely nationalist parties formed in recent months. ``Not one of them has an all-Yugoslav orientation,'' he complained. The president contended that unspecified right-wing forces aided by foreign powers _ also not identified _ could bring the country's ethnic and political tensions to the breaking point. Slovenian deputy Janez Lukac bitterly criticized Jovic's implication that right-wing forces have taken power in his republic and Croatia. ``I would have expected that the president strive for reconciliation, instead of the continuation of hostilities,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Several Injured in Houston Park Disturbance
DOC.TEXT: At least seven people were injured, none seriously, when a melee that included gunshots erupted Monday among nearly 10,000 overheated Memorial Day revelers at an outdoor rap concert, authorities said. Houston Fire Chief Robert Clayton said earlier police reports indicating that two people were shot and two others stabbed in the Hermann Park disturbance had been wrong. The Fire Department runs the city's ambulances. Clayton said all the injuries, mostly cuts and bruises, came from ``blunt objects like bottles and bats'' and that none appeared serious. The 4:15 p.m. disturbance erupted as the headliner band, 2 Live Crew, began its second song. Houston City Parks Director Don Olson told radio station KTRH that an unidentified person threw a bottle into the crowd as the rap music fans surged toward the stage. Then, Olson said, someone in the crowd fired a gun, apparently angered at the people closing in around them. Witnesses said several people had begun spraying each other with beer in the hot afternoon sun. Temperatures here reached 93 degrees for the second day running. ``Some people apparently started throwing beer bottles and then I heard, pop, pop, pop _ someone was shooting _ and then everybody started running,'' said Ron Atkins of KMJQ, a radio station sponsoring the concert at the Miller Outdoor Theater. ``I heard about four gunshots and just started running,'' said George Carver, another witness. The concert was cancelled once the melee began. Police closed the park, sending hundreds running for parking lots and creating a traffic jam that lasted more than an hour. Scores of officers on foot and horseback and in helicopters worked to evacuate the area. KTRH radio said 20 people were arrested, most of them for public intoxication, but a police dispatcher, Berschelle Moore, could confirm just 10 arrests. The radio station also reported two arrests on weapons complaints. Ambulances treated some people for heat exhaustion, but officers said there were no serious injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Guards Thwart Gunmen at Philippine Cabinet Minister's Home
DOC.TEXT: A band of men with M-16 rifles tried to force their way to the home of Trade and Industry Secretary Jose Concepcion but were turned back by guards, Concepcion's office said Tuesday. His staff said in a statement that more than four gunmen arrived about 11:15 p.m. Sunday at the gate of the posh Forbes Park residential district and demanded to get to the secretary's house, but guards refused to admit them. The group's leader then ordered his men to leave because they had been ``burned out,'' the statement said. The term is slang used by the Philippine military for a covert operation that has been exposed. Guard reinforcements were sent to Forbes Park, a wealthy subdivision that includes the homes of leading businessmen, government officials and U.S. Ambassador Nicholas Platt. Newspapers speculated the incident may have been a kidnap or assassination attempt and said the gunmen could have been rebel soldiers responsible for last December's coup attempt. Concepcion, a leading industrialist, is a controversial figure because of allegations he secured preferential government loans for his family business and favors foreign investors, especially Taiwanese. He denies wrongdoing. Last week, a statement issued by the mutineers threatened to kill banker Domingo Lee for ``crimes against the people.'' Lee owns PhilBanking Corp., one of two banks where bombs were discovered last week. Security has been intensified in Manila following bombings and ambushes, blamed on Communist rebels. Maj. Gen. Cesar Nazareno, the national police chief, warned Saturday that Manila was experiencing a ``breakdown in law and order.'' The State Department has warned Americans to be alert for terrorism and rising crime here. Also Monday, the military said troops captured 27 Communist leaders and guerrillas in raids north of Manila and in the southern Philippines. A military report said nine purported members of the outlawed National Democratic Front's Mindanao Commission were arrested Saturday at a house in Davao City, 530 miles southeast of the capital. It said among those seized was a member of the commission's secretariat, Maria Loreto Abella, for whom a $4,300 bounty had been offered.

DOC.HEAD: Gravestone Dedicated During Memorial Day Service
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7th graf, `White ...' to CORRECT that White contracted AIDS through blood products, sted transfusion.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NA2
DOC.TEXT: Etched in granite, ``Kid Of Courage'' tops Ryan White's gravestone. The epitaph, composed by his mother, are three of the more modest words that adorn the monument to the Indiana youth, who spent the last five years educating the public about AIDS. The words of Gov. Evan Bayh, singers Elton John and Michael Jackson join those of the White family on the headstone that was placed Monday at Ryan's gravesite, nearly two months after his death of complications from acquired immune deficiency syndrome. No stone covered the grave before Monday, only flowers and notes from thousands of well-wishers and wax from a candle that was lit twice each day. His mother, Jeanne White, spent the time designing the monument that was dedicated on Memorial Day, when U.S. servicemen are honored for losing their lives in wars. Ryan was remembered at the dedication by friends and family as having fought an equally arduous battle. ``I think about him everyday _ several, several times,'' his uncle, Tom Hale, said before about 75 people who attended the dedication. ``Don't weep for me, meet me. That would be his prayer.'' White, who contracted AIDS through blood products he was taking for his hemophilia, was less than 5 feet tall, but his gravestone _ in black and white, his favorite colors _ stands 6 foot, 8 inches, his mother said. ``He liked to say he was five foot. He always wanted to be tall. He wanted to be big and be like Howie Long,'' Jeanne White said of the defensive lineman for the Los Angeles Raiders. Inscriptions on front and back of the gravestone tell the story of his 18 years. After a lengthy legal dispute between 1985 and 1987, Ryan won the right to attend school outside of Kokomo, but ugly stares and ill feelings drove him, his sister and mother to Cicero, 30 miles north of Indianapolis. In the interim, he endeared thousands as a proponent for AIDS education, including singers John and Jackson. Words from songs performed by both entertainers, who remain close to the Whites, are inscribed on the monument. ``Turn me loose from your hands. Let me fly to distant lands. Fly away skyline pigeon fly, from all the things you left so far behind,'' are words on the stone from ``Skyline Pigeon'' that John sang at Ryan's funeral in Indianapolis. ``Gonna make a difference, gonna make it right,'' are attributed to Jackson on the stone. And from family and friends: ``We're sure going to miss you Ryan.'' Neighbors and friends offered testimonials about encounters with White during the dedication, and the choir director of Hamilton Heights High School, which Ryan attended, sang ``The Lord's Prayer.''

DOC.HEAD: War Dead Remembered, Looming Summer Season Celebrated on Memorial Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 3rd graf, `In Panmunjom ...' to ADD memorial in South China sea, monument to Ryan White; SUBS 22nd graf pvs: `In Davie ...' with two grafs to CORRECT that girl killed was about to join parade, ADD Houston melee. ^With AM-Parks Cutbacks, Bjt
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AD1
DOC.TEXT: A downpour dampened Memorial Day barbecues and beach parties on the West Coast, but sunny skies surprised sunbathers in the East as the nation started its summer fun and commemorated its casualties of war. Fallen veterans were honored nationwide on Monday, and in Maryland a statue remembering U.S. military victims of terrorism was unveiled. In Panmunjom, Korea, the bodies of five U.S. servicemen killed nearly 40 years ago were returned _ the first return of U.S. Korean War dead from the North since 1954. More than 8,000 Americans from the 1950-53 conflict remain unaccounted for. In the South China Sea off Okinawa, Martin Rosenfeld, who lives in a Chicago suburb, lowered a 1,500-pound stone marker at the spot where, 45 years ago to the day, it's believed 159 sailors, including his brother, Robert, drowned when the Japanese sank the USS Drexler destroyer. And in Cicero, Ind., a monument was unveiled to Ryan White, who fought against AIDS discrimination but lost the fight for his own life two months ago at age 18. The less somber side of the holiday that heralds the unofficial start of the summer season was celebrated with parades and family get-togethers. President Bush reviewed a colorful parade of fire engines, school bands and a veterans' brigade in Kennebunkport, Maine. Veterans fired a 24-gun salute and buglers from Kennebunk High School played ``Taps.'' Bush, basking in sunshine and surrounded by his wife, children and grandchildren, called the Memorial Day festivities a ``little piece of Americana.'' At Arlington National Cemetery, Vice President Dan Quayle participated in a wreath-laying ceremony at the Tomb of the Unknowns. Gloomy weather forecasts in the Northeast evaporated Sunday, sending hordes to the beach. Sunny skies prevailed Monday as well, but ocean temperatures in the mid-50s confined most beach frolicking to the shore. The temperature in New York City reached 72 degrees Monday and the fine weather attracted 102,620 people to seven city-run beaches, including about 60,000 who visited Coney Island. The Pacific storm that dumped an inch of rain on Los Angeles by Monday morning forced a downtown highway closure and was blamed for two roadway deaths. The rain also sent costumed minstrels and jugglers packing when officials closed the outdoor Renaissance Pleasure Faire in San Bernardino. In Timonium, Md., the families of 11 Maryland veterans killed by terrorism joined a crowd of 200 at the dedication of the Children of Liberty Memorial. ``They are victims of an undeclared war,'' said Maryland National Guard Maj. Gen. James F. Fretterd. Mary Ervin's son, Ulysses G. Parker, was killed in the Oct. 23, 1983, bombing of the Marine barracks in Beirut. ``It seemed like such a waste for them to have been where they were and not able to protect themselves. It was just plain murder,'' she said. The memorial features a 12-foot bronze and granite statue of a woman's hands holding a folded American flag to her chest. It is inscribed with the names of nine Maryland residents who died in the Beirut attack, one killed during the 1985 hijacking of TWA Flight 847 in Beirut and one who died in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland. ``It is important that we recognize them and give them the same kind of salute as those who have fought in wars,'' said retired Col. Timothy Geraghty, the commanding officer at the time of the barrack bombing. In Illinois, ceremonies honored war dead while mourners in Breese planned a service Tuesday for five high school girls who added to the holiday weekend roadway death toll. The girls, all sophomores at Breese Central High School, were killed along with a 47-year-old woman in a two-vehicle crash Saturday. ``It wasn't a big class, maybe 100 kids, and five percent of them have just been killed,'' said Breese Central health teacher Dick Garrett. In Davie, Fla., a 7-year-old girl on horseback, about to join in a Memorial Day parade, was fatally crushed when her horse fell, police spokeswoman Leslie Richart said. In Houston, where temperatures hit 93 degrees, at least seven people were injured, none seriously, when a melee that included gunshots erupted among nearly 10,000 people at an outdoor rap concert, authorities said. No one was shot; the injuries were mostly cuts and bruises, said Fire Chief Robert Clayton. In Philadelphia, actors portraying historical U.S. soldiers joined real veterans in a military review at Fort Mifflin, where troops held off the British fleet in 1777. After an overnight downpour in San Francisco, a parade wound through the Presidio Army Base, where a military tribute complete with a 21-gun salute and a flag-raising ceremony was staged. In Arkansas, tourists undeterred by recent devastating floods packed hotels and campsites. ``We had a lot of cancellations, but we had a lot of people who came in to take those folks' place,'' said Bonnie Hunter, a desk clerk at DeGray State Park Lodge. All 96 rooms at the lake near the resort town of Hot Springs were full Sunday, she said. Hot Springs was hard-hit by flooding and officials had feared a tourism blight.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Holds the Initiative in Superpower Summit
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Another spring, another summit. The similarity ends there. One year ago today, President Bush was in Brussels at a NATO summit, unveiling his proposal for troop and conventional weapons in Europe and ending a long silence. He had ordered a review of U.S. foreign policy and put things on hold while it was done. That left the stage to Mikhail S. Gorbachev. And Gorbachev certainly had used it, waging a peace offensive and playing to crowds that cheered his visits to Western capitals. Now, as the U.S.-Soviet summit begins on Thursday, Bush holds the initiative and Gorbachev is a leader with dire problems. The summit could help him at home. A year ago, the NATO summit was a boost for Bush after months of criticism of his style, pace and a lack of proposals while Gorbachev was waging his peace offensive. The Soviet leader had announced conventional arms reductions, then proposed negotiations for troop and weapons cuts on both sides, and later said he would scrap 500 short-range nuclear weapons. It was the season of Gorbymania in Western Europe, and Bush had offered little to counter it. Critics said he was timid. Even when he was ready to outline his world view, the plans Bush described were short on drama, nothing to rival the Gorbachev show. He proposed an ``open skies'' system of arms control verification _ reviving an idea that dates from Dwight D. Eisenhower. He challenged Gorbachev to ``open the ledgers'' on Soviet defense budgets, hardly a slogan to rally the Western alliance. But that buttoned-down phase ended in Brussels. Bush called for cuts to 275,000 in U.S. and Soviet troop levels in Europe, with ceilings on tanks, artillery and combat aircraft too. He wanted it done about five years faster than Gorbachev had proposed. Bush also succeeded in shelving Western differences over modernizing short-range nuclear missiles, a major issue then, now overtaken by the collapse of the Iron Curtain. Parts of the 1989 agenda have been outdated by the remodeling of Europe _ the fall of communist governments and the coming reunification of Germany _ but the administration still is pressing for East-West cuts in troops and conventional weapons in Europe, to levels that would secure the new look on the continent. For all that has happened, Western forces still are outgunned and far outnumbered by the Soviet troops that remain in Eastern Europe. Bush said in Brussels that he wanted an East-West treaty within a year, to be implemented by 1992 or 1993. The timetable already has slipped; the administration still hopes for a deal before the end of 1990, and Bush said the process is not going as far or as fast as he would like. Bush said he is looking for a way to move those negotiations forward. ``It's important, and I think it does send a bad signal if the Soviets look like they're refusing to go forward,'' he said Thursday. The stall in conventional arms talks is one of the topics Bush will raise with Gorbachev at their weekend meetings in Washington and at Camp David, Md. That, and strategic weapons reductions, and the Soviet economic situation, and the crisis over breakaway Lithuania. ``I feel that the man has got some enormous problems; he's made some enormous progress,'' Bush said at a pre-summit news conference. ``I think he knows ... that we're not trying to undermine him or make life complicated for him.'' To the contrary, the administration has a stake in Gorbachev's success. ``It is important for perestroika to succeed, because we think that perestroika ... will bring us a more open and stable and secure Soviet Union, and that's very much in the best interests of the United States,'' said Secretary of State James A. Baker III. ``I can't tell you whether or not the summit will ... strengthen him domestically in the Soviet Union.'' That year-ago summit certainly strengthened Bush. ``Here we go now, on the offense,'' he said at the time. That's the position he is trying to hold as he heads into the meetings with Gorbachev and with allied leaders a month later.

DOC.HEAD: Keller Industries Founder Dies at 70
DOC.TEXT: Henry Keller, who helped pioneer the use of prefabricated aluminium products in the home-building industry, died Sunday at his home after a lengthy heart illness. He was 70. Keller was born in Gadsden, Ala., on Feb. 16, 1920, and moved to Miami at age 18. He served in the Navy in World War II and afterward worked for two aluminum manufacturing companies in Miami. In 1950, in the midst of South Florida's post-war housing boom, he founded Air Control Products, which was renamed Keller Industries in 1968. By the time he retired in 1983, 4,000 workers at manufacturing plants and warehouses across the country were producing a wide range of home-building products, from window frames to step-ladders. ``Everything was on a first-name basis,'' said Robert Conners, a 20-year employee. ``He had an open-door policy. Anyone could come see him.'' He added that Keller was ``a tough, hard-driven businessman'' who disdained neckties except for rare occasions, such as board meetings. He also donated more than $1 million to Mount Sinai Medical Center on Miami Beach.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Prices Climb, Currency Devaluation Slows Under New Wage, Price Pact
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline prices climbed but currency devaluation slowed Monday after President Carlos Salinas de Gortari signed the latest in a series of wage-price control pacts. Salinas signed a new Economic Growth and Stability Pact with business, labor and farm leaders of his Institutional Revolutionary Party at a ceremony in the presidential residence Sunday night. ``This is a renewed effort to fight inflation and consolidate the conditions of growth that Mexicans demand and deserve,'' Salinas said. Signers of the new pact agreed not to demand wage or price hikes between now and Jan. 31, 1991, when the accord expires. They also agreed to let the government raise the cost of gasoline and continue devaluing currency, but at a slower rate than before. Gasoline prices were hiked an average 6.7 percent Monday, in accord with a Treasury Department announcement that followed the signing of the pact. The pact stipulated that Mexican money would be devalued against the dollar at a rate of four pesos every five days, beginning Monday. The value of currency had been dropping at the rate of one peso a day before. The current rate is 2,800 pesos to the dollar. ``The business sector . . . promises to absorb these increases and not pass them on in costs for goods and services,'' the pact stipulates. An opposition party spokesman criticized the pact because it was formulated behind closed doors. ``One can make an argument for the prices (of gasoline) going up, but it's not at all clear why wages aren't going up. It seems to be repeating the situation of having Mexican society paying the bill for a very unclear strategy,'' Democratic Revolutionary Party spokesman Ricardo Pascoe said in an interview. The ruling party majority in the lower house of Mexico's congress defeated a proposal by opposition parties on Friday to reveal details of the pact before signing it. The Mexican economy has been governed by similar wage-price control pacts since 1987. The annual inflation rate has dropped from 160 percent to 20 percent during that time. ``The pact has had success because the parties to it have complied and have had enough flexibility to resolve their differences,'' Salinas said. The renewed pact replaces a wage-price control accord signed Dec. 3 that expires on July 31. Following the signing ceremony, the government oil monopoly Petroleos Mexicanos, known as Pemex, announced a jump of 35 pesos in regular and unleaded gas to 560 pesos a liter in most of the country, or about 20 cents a liter. Pemex said it would raise the cost of regular gasoline by 65 pesos in the three largest cities _ Mexico City, Guadalajara and Monterrey _ and along the U.S. border. The higher price in those areas is designed to earn revenues that will be used to improve the quality of gas, provide cleaner public transportation and fight smog, Pemex said in a news release.

DOC.HEAD: Italian and US Carriers Sign Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Alitalia and USAir on Monday signed an agreement aimed at giving their passengers easier access to each other's networks. Under the terms of the accord signed in Rome, passengers of Italy's national flag carrier will be able to fly to 41 U.S. destinations by making connections with USAir flights leaving from Boston, Miami and Los Angeles. In turn, USAir passengers destined for eastern Europe or the eastern Mediterranean can fly Alitalia to Italy and make the appropriate connections in Rome or Milan. The accord will go into effect on June 16. Giovanni Bisignani, managing director of Alitalia, and Randall Malin, vice chairman and executive vice president of USAir, told a news conference that the agreement doesn't call for an exchange of shareholdings, but they would not rule out an equity swap in the future. Alitalia hopes the expanded access to the U.S. destinations, including such commercial and tourist centers as Washington, Philadelphia, Detroit and San Francisco, will help it raise its market share of traffic between the U.S. and Italy. In 1989, Alitalia had 47 percent of that market with 700,000 passengers. Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines share the balance. The accord follows an agreement signed in April between the Italian and U.S. governments that calls for expanded airline service between the two countries. Under that accord, Alitalia will be allowed to service five U.S. gateway cities and intensify its flight schedule, while two more U.S. carriers will be allowed to fly into Italy. The accord also calls for close cooperation in cargo divisions, and will allow USAir passengers to receive frequent flyer bonus points for transatlantic Alitalia flights. USAir's only trans-Atlantic routes are to London and, beginning later this month, to Frankfurt, West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Mood In Sweden Gradually Shifting In Favor Of EC
DOC.TEXT: The independent-minded Swedes are softening their opposition to joining the European Community, but the question of political union remains a stumbling block, politicians and analysts said. Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson, in an article published Sunday, said neutral Sweden must remain outside the EC's ranks if the trading bloc forms a political union. Carlsson said control over foreign policy was the only major question barring Sweden from EC membership. Even the dissolution of the European power blocs, NATO and the Warsaw Pact, would not persuade Sweden to relinquish its neutrality, he wrote in the Dagens Nyheter daily. Sweden has relaxed many of the restrictions of its tightly controlled economy in the last two years to adapt to European conditions. Major Swedish companies also have merged or signed cooperation deals with European companies to protect themselves when the EC dismantles its internal commercial barriers in 1992. Sweden belongs to the six-nation European Free Trade Association, which is negotiating for commercial links with the 12-nation EC. The package would unite the two into an 18-member European Economic Space accord. But Swedish businessmen and the political opposition complain that the idea would bind the EFTA countries to the EC as a junior partner with no decision-making voice. An opinion poll conducted by the respected SIFO organization showed 51 percent of those asked were in favor of seeking EC membership, compared with 48 percent a year ago. The poll had a three percent margin of error, meaning that the change was insignificant. But the number of respondents who opposed asking for EC membership fell to 21 from 25 percent, perhaps indicating a trend, said SIFO analyst Alf Sjostrom. The rest were undecided. ``We have seen from other polls which we have done that opinion in Sweden is more positive to the EC,'' said Sjostrom. But the polls also showed that most Swedes don't know how EC membership would affect them, he said. Danish Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen, speaking in a Stockholm news conference, said Sweden should not consider neutrality an obstacle to seeking EC membership. Denmark, once an EFTA member, is the only Scandinavian country in the EC. ``I see a common foreign policy where there is consensus,'' Ellemann-Jensen said. ``We can work to improve the preconditions for reaching consensus.'' He cautioned that Sweden could not influence EC policy unless it were a full member of the trading bloc. ``We do not want non-members to take part in the decision-making process. It is unthinkable to have far-reaching agreemens that undermine the (EC) integrity and process of decisions,'' he said. Swedish opposition leader Carl Bildt, of the Moderate party, also said the policy of neutrality should not be allowed to exclude Sweden from the EC. ``It is impossible to conduct our neutrality policy as if the Cold War still existed,'' Bildt said. ``It is obvious that we would participate in the cooperation among Europe's democracies.''

DOC.HEAD: Varity Corp. Eyes Move To U.S., But Canadians Opposed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: All dollar figures are U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Canada's Varity Corp., a major farm equipment makers, wants to move headquarters across the border to attract U.S. investors, but a Canadian official said Monday his government would sue to block a move. Varity is considering moving its headquarters from Toronto to Buffalo to make its stock more attractive to U.S. investors, said a company spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Canadian government imposes a 15 percent withholding tax on dividends, the spokesman said. A move ``would make the company's stock available to a number of U.S. institutions who may now be precluded from buying foreign stocks or may have their fill of foreign stocks,'' the spokesman said. But the move would violate a pledge Varity, then known as Massey-Ferguson, made in 1986 in return for a $169.1 million government bailout, said an official of the Ontario Development Corp., a quasi-public agency that funnels government loans to businesses. Varity agreed to maintain or create 1,500 jobs in Canada by 1993, and the agreement ``requires them to keep a headquarters here,'' the official said in a telephone interview from Toronto. He said his agency's rules forbid its employees to be named for attribution. The agreement calls for a fine of $25,365 for each job Varity fails to provide, but includes no specific penalties for failing to keep its headquarters in Canada, the official said. Tobias Levkovich, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in New York, said a move would give Varity the visibility that its $2.3 billion in annual sales merits. ``This company would be in the Fortune 150 if it would be American-based,'' Levkovich said. ``Now, it's nothing.'' A move also would allow Varity to boost its stock price by means of a reverse split, something that is forbidden by the Toronto Stock Exchange, Levkovich said. Varity recently purchased a mansion in Buffalo and won an $11.5 million package of tax exemptions from the Erie County Industrial Development Agency. Those actions prompted public warnings from Canadian officials that Varity would face a court fight if it moved its headquarters. The Ontario official said those warnings still stood, but he and the Varity spokesman said negotiations were under way to find a way around the problem. Neither side would say what concessions Varity might make in return for the government's acquiescence on the move. They said the negotiations might take the better part of a year to complete. Paul Leone, business development officer for the Erie County Industrial Development Agency, said Varity has ``about a year'' to take advantage of the agency's incentive package, but that there is no specific deadline. The company has estimated it would employ 45 people in Buffalo within two years if the headquarters are moved. The Canadian government already has claimed Varity is 450 jobs short of its commitment and has threatened the company with fines, but Varity says it met the commitment by including employees of its U.S. subsidiaries who work in Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Carriers Expand Marketing Partnership
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines and Australian Airlines announced an expansion of their partnership aimed at coordinating schedules and other marketing programs. The carriers plan to offer one-stop check-in for United and Australian connecting flights, through-checking of baggage between the domestic and international terminal at Sydney, concierge service for first-class passengers and joint tour products. The airlines said Monday they also plan to explore sharing ticket office facilities as part of expanding a marketing partnership formed in September 1987, when they began offering passengers reciprocal use of each other's airport club rooms. ``We see Australia as a growth market, and we intend to grow with it,'' said Stephen M. Wolf, chairman and president of United. ``The Australian aviation industry is changing rapidly as we move toward deregulation. Our partnership with United Airlines positions us well to compete in the overseas markets,'' said John W. Schaap, managing director and chief executive offier of Australian Airlines.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Stores Bar Non-Residents; Mood Calmer After Gorbachev Speech
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with rush on more stores; pickup 6th graf pvs, `The woman...'
DOC.TEXT: People from outside the city were barred from shopping in Moscow's stores today in an effort to stop a wave of panic buying caused by government plans to triple bread prices on July 1. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev tried to stem the run on stores by making a hastily scheduled appearance on Soviet television Sunday night. ``Don't panic, comrades!'' he told his television audience. The speech was rebroadcast at midday today. The mood seemed calmer during the morning at grocery stores on Taganskaya and Dorogmilovskaya Streets, but the rush resumed elsewhere after lunch. When food store No. 30 on Gorky Street reopened after the midday break, about 70 people rushed in to buy Vietnamese vodka and Nicaraguan rum, nearly overwhelming policemen who were helping check for residency permits. One shopper at Tanganskaya, where liquor was not being sold, said the panic seemed to be subsiding. Another woman said Gorbachev's speech had a calming effect, ``but he really had nothing concrete to offer.'' The woman, who was traveling with her husband and grandson said she told store clerks ``we were on a trip and needed to get something to eat. Of course they let us in.'' She declined to give her name or native city. A store clerk who initially refused entrance to the travelers said, ``How can you turn away a child? A person must eat.'' A small percentage of those trying to enter the store were turned away. Some of those rejected said they simply forgot to carry the residence permits required to live in the city. In his speech, Gorbachev said that ``an anxious mood has arisen in the country in connection with the consideration by the Supreme Soviet (Parliament) of the government's report on the transition to a market economy.'' Besides touching off panic buying, the reform plan also has drawn criticism from such radicals as Boris N. Yeltsin, who advocate a much more rapid transition to a market economy. Yeltsin, opposed by Gorbachev, was nominated in the third round of voting today for president of the Russian federation, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics. He failed to gain a majority in the first two rounds of balloting in the Russian Congress last week. Yeltsin faces the Russian premier, Alexander Vlasov, plus Ivan Polozkov, the Krasnodar party chief, and five lesser known figures. Gorbachev, in his speech, gave assurances that as part of the reform plans, lower income people would be compensated and that those thrown out of work would be retrained for new jobs. Some economists have estimated that up to 40 million people could lose their jobs in the reforms, which are expected to drive many inefficient businesses into bankruptcy. But he said that ``this transition to a market economy ... cannot be postponed, because negative consequences will develop. Ryzhkov, presenting the plan Thursday, said price hikes would earn the government an additional $320 billion, but that $217 billion would be paid out to compensate the needy. Gorbachev did not mention the possibility of a referendum, as discussed by Ryzhkov's deputies Yuri Maslyukov and Leonid Abalkin on Wednesday. Ryzhkov's plan calls for bread prices to triple to $1.09 a loaf on July 1, and for other food prices to double on average starting Jan 1. The average Soviet monthy salary is $279. Ryzhkov said Thursday that bread makes up 20 percent of the average Soviet diet. The three-phase reform plan, to carry through 1995, calls for about 60 percent of state enterprises to be sold to the public sector and for controls to be lifted on about 60 percent of prices. Other prices would remain under state control, and many industries would stay in state hands, over the opposition of radical reformers. Gorbachev said the increase in bread prices was needed ``because the cheapness of bread does not at all correspond to the the amount of labor in its production ... People buy bread and feed it to their animals. And this at a time when we are forced to buy grain abroad.'' Gorbachev, without mentioning names, criticized those who were skeptical of the government reform program. ``They can inflict irreparable damage. We must put those hecklers in their places. They are guided only by their ambitions and not the interests of the people,'' Gorbachev said.

DOC.HEAD: EC Clamps Down on Semiconductor Protection
DOC.TEXT: The European Community's executive body on Monday proposed a tit-for-tat measure that could allow EC companies to copy semiconductor designs of U.S. chip makers. The proposal by the EC Commission, which must be approved by the community's 12 member nations, would drop protection of chip designs from non-EC countries that do not legally protect designs made within the EC. Unlike other non-EC countries such as Austria, Japan and Sweden, which recognize and protect designs of chips made in the community, the United States protects only its own chip designs. ``If they won't respect our designs, we won't respect theirs,'' an EC Commission official who asked not to be named, said. ``What we are looking for is for other countries to recognize chips made in the EC and to give them legal protection,'' added the official. Currently, the EC protects a third country's chip designs even if that country does not protect EC semiconductor designs. Those interim measures will expire on Nov. 7. The Commission on Monday approved proposals suggesting reciprocal protection be extended indefinitely to Austria, Sweden and Japan. But the Commission also proposed that chips designed in other countries, including the United States and Switzerland, be given protection only until the end of 1992, unless those countries take action to protect EC designs.

DOC.HEAD: EFTA to Open Trade With East Europe
DOC.TEXT: The six-nation European Free Trade Association is preparing a declaration of cooperation with Hungary and Poland, Swedish Trade Minister Anita Gradin said Monday. Mrs. Gradin said the declaration will be presented at an EFTA summit meeting in Goteborg on June 14, and will clear the way to broad trade agreements with eastern Europe. By approving such agreements, ``we can support the democratization process and help stabilize economies'' in countries emerging from decades of central planning under communist governments, she said. Gradin said East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria also have shown interest in cooperating with EFTA. In 1984 EFTA issued a declaration of cooperation with Yugoslavia, and last April EFTA approved a $100 million investment fund for Yugoslavia at favorable terms. The trade bloc is comprised of Sweden, Switzerland, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Austria. Mrs. Gradin said ties with eastern European countries could strengthen EFTA's position in cooperation talks with Europe's dominant trade organization, the European Community. Some observers have said EFTA may die out after the EC's 12-member states form a single market in 1992. Austria has applied to join the EC, and public opinion is swinging towards EC membership in other EFTA countries. But Gradin said ``who knows what will happen in the future. EFTA is a useful organization today.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed in Thin Trading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing rates.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mixed in exceptionally quiet European trading Monday, affected by the Memorial Day holiday in the United States and a bank holiday in Britain. Gold rose in Zurich but was not traded in London or Hong Kong, which also was closed for a holiday. In Frankfurt, the market continued to watch events in the Soviet Union and the progress toward German reunification with great interest, but in the absence of news there was little inspiration for trading. ``One can't even call it technical trading,'' said a trader at a U.S. bank in Frankfurt. ``With New York and London absent, nobody in the forex market is going to take big risks,'' said another trader at a West German bank. A trader in Milan agreed. ``The dollar is looking fairly stable, with a tendency to firm. But I don't expect much movement due to the holidays in London and New York. The market is pretty dead.'' In Tokyo, the dollar fell below 150 yen for the first time in nearly three months, falling 0.60 yen to a closing of 149.45 yen. Later, in Europe, it was quoted lower at 149.39 yen. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday: _1.6790 West German marks, down from 1.6810 _1.4215 Swiss francs, down from 1.4245 _5.6565 French francs, down from 5.6585 _1.8910 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8820 _1,233.50 Italian lire, down from 1,234.15 _1.1828 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1837 The British pound was quoted at $1.6930 in Europe, more expensive for buyers than late Friday's $1.6895 in London. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $367.50, up 50 cents from late Friday. Markets were closed in Hong Kong because of the Dragon Boat Festival.
